headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Devon Energy's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]. This call is being recorded. I'd now like a turn the call over to Mr. Howard Thill, Senior Vice President of Communications and Investor Relatio
componenttext: Welcome to Devon Energy's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]. This call is being recorded. I'd now like a turn the call over to Mr. Howard Thill, Senior Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephen, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to welcome you to the call as well. Today's call is going to consist largely of Q&A, so I hope everyone has had a chance to review our fourth quarter and full year earnings release as it also includ
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephen, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to welcome you to the call as well. Today's call is going to consist largely of Q&A, so I hope everyone has had a chance to review our fourth quarter and full year earnings release as it also includes our forward-looking guidance as well as our detailed operations report.
Also on the call today are Dave Hager, President and CEO; Tony Vaughn, Executive Vice President of E&P; Tom Mitchell, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and a few other members of our senior management team.
Finally, I'll remind you that comments and answers to questions on the call will contain plans, forecasts, expectations and estimates, which are forward-looking statements under U.S. securities laws. These comments and answers are subject to a number of assumptions, risks and uncertainties, many of which are beyond our control. These statements are not guarantees of future performance, and actual results might differ materially. For a review of risk factors relating to the statements, please see our Form 10-K. With that, I will turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard, and welcome, everyone. As we all know, 2015 provided an extremely challenging business environment for our industry. We responded during the year by proactively taking steps to align our business with these conditions by reducing field
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard, and welcome, everyone. As we all know, 2015 provided an extremely challenging business environment for our industry. We responded during the year by proactively taking steps to align our business with these conditions by reducing field level costs by $400 million, delivering efficiencies and cost savings reduced capital requirements by $500 million, and we attained significant productivity gains and improved type curves and IP rates across all our core plays. 
As we look to 2016, our top priority in this environment is to protect the balance sheet by balancing spending requirements with available cash flow. We also see no reason to accelerate production growth into these weak markets, which has led us to take aggressive measures to reduce our capital investment by 75% year-over-year. We also have plans in place to preserve more than $1 billion of cash flow on a go-forward basis through a number of initiatives, including incremental field level cost savings, a reduction of our workforce by about 1,000 people and by adjusting the dividend rate to preserve over $300 million of cash flow. In an effort to further strengthen our balance sheet, we also have noncore divestitures underway with the intent to monetize $2 billion to $3 billion of assets during 2016.
As I've said many times, Devon is in the advantageous position having no long-cycle projects, minimal long-term contracts and nearly all of our acreage is held by production. These favorable attributes allow us to prudently adjust our 2016 capital program to balance cash flows and to protect our balance sheet, but it also gives us the ability to ramp up development activity when commodity prices rebound and to see a quick production response to that ramp when it happens. Our 2016 program -- capital program of 2016 is designed to maximize cash flow and operational continuity with activity directed toward the lowest risk and highest impact opportunities in each of Devon's core areas. This disciplined capital program is expected to maintain relatively flat oil production from Devon's core assets compared to 2015, and we're projecting only a 10% oil decline from Q4 2015 to Q4 2016. This production resiliency is a testament to the quality of our go-forward assets. Overall, top line production in 2016 from core assets is expected to decline by 6%, driven by lower gas volumes. The efficiency of our 2016 budget is also highlighted by our ability to fund our capital program at today's strip pricing within operational cash flow, EnLink distributions and expected Access Pipeline proceeds. Once again, we have the flexibility to ramp up spending or to make additional cuts to our spending plans, depending upon how commodity prices trend going forward. As I mentioned earlier, in addition to balancing near-term spending with cash inflows, we are also working to improve our financial position through the monetization of $2 billion, to $3 billion of assets. We are in the latter stages of discussions for the sale of our 50% interest in Access Pipeline and expect that transaction to occur in the first half of the year, potentially the first quarter. 
We are also in the process of opening data room for the sale of up to 80,000 BOE per day of noncore upstream assets in the U.S. The properties up for sale include 15,000 net undeveloped acres in Martin County, Texas and producing assets in the Southern Midland Wolfcamp, Carthage, Granite Wash and Mississippian Lime plays. We have had direct contact from potential buyers ranging from majors to well-capitalized firms to private equity firms.
We believe these assets are substantially higher quality considered investment by others and are in the market quicker. This gives us a competitive edge. Conversations, thus far, have been encouraging, and we have confidence in our ability to attractively sell these assets throughout 2016 and use the upstream assets sale proceeds for debt retirements. 
Looking at our financial flexibility longer term, if commodity prices remain low, Devon has significant balance sheet strength to withstand an extended downturn. Pro forma for the acquisition, which closed in early January, we had $3.9 billion of liquidity at year-end consisting of $1.5 billion of cash and $2.4 billion of capacity on our senior credit facility. Importantly, this credit facility does not mature until the end of 2019 and contains only 1 material financial covenant, a debt-to-capitalization ratio below 65%. At year-end, this ratio was only 24%. In addition to our strong liquidity, we've done a good job managing our upcoming debt maturities with no significant debt coming due until December 2018. Bottom line, our advantage capital structure provides us a significant amount of financial strength and flexibility. 
So in summary, I hope you come away with 3 important messages today. First, we are committed to living within cash flows in 2016. To do so, we have taken aggressive measures to preserve more than $1 billion of cash flow through operating costs and dividend reductions. Second, we have the financial strength to withstand an extended downturn, and we're looking to further bolster our investment grade balance sheet with ongoing asset divestiture programs. And lastly, the quality, depth and diversification of our go-forward asset base is unmatched. Devon has exposure to some of the best short-cycle projects in the world. We are well positioned to accelerate activity when the markets reward growth again.
With that, will turn the call back to Howard for Q&A.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, I appreciate the clarification on the asset sales process, but I wonder if you could just give a little bit more color on your expected timing and perhaps the associated cash flow that goes along with that $2 billion to $3 billion of proceeds. I don
componenttext: Dave, I appreciate the clarification on the asset sales process, but I wonder if you could just give a little bit more color on your expected timing and perhaps the associated cash flow that goes along with that $2 billion to $3 billion of proceeds. I don't want to risk my follow-up here, but just for clarification, is that still in that $2 billion to $3 billion or is that additive to the $2 billion to $3 billion. And I'll do quick follow-up, please.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Doug. We do include Access in the $2 billion to $3 billion, although there's obviously flexibility around that, and we are trying to predict the market. But that's -- we did make that assumption that's in there higher depending on how everything goe
componenttext: Sure, Doug. We do include Access in the $2 billion to $3 billion, although there's obviously flexibility around that, and we are trying to predict the market. But that's -- we did make that assumption that's in there higher depending on how everything goes. I think there's really a misperception of the market about the quality of these assets to be quite honest with everybody. These are very high quality assets. You may remember that we did a noncore divestiture program about a 1.5 years ago after we acquired Southern, and that was really what we would consider assets that were towards the bottom of the barrel, I'd say, as far as asset quality. These are high-quality assets, and the feedback that we have received from the market, thus far, is very positive regarding the quality of these assets, the ability to transact these assets at the prices that we have assumed here. We are opening data room starting next week and then soon after that. We anticipate that we'd be receiving bids here during the first half of the year and closing on this throughout the year. I'm going to turn over the Tom Mitchell who's going to comment a little bit about the cash flow side.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't given out, Doug, a specific cash flow number. We talked about 80,000 barrels a day. About 23% of that is oil. And I just want to emphasize what Dave said. We've had a number of discussions with parties. The interesting thing is extremely robust
componenttext: We haven't given out, Doug, a specific cash flow number. We talked about 80,000 barrels a day. About 23% of that is oil. And I just want to emphasize what Dave said. We've had a number of discussions with parties. The interesting thing is extremely robust more than you had expect. It does lean closer to the private equity side from an interest level, but that's something that we'd expected when you went out with the package. We're moving very quickly to try to get ahead of what we think may be further asset sales by peers, and we're on that time line right now going out here to open data rooms and move aggressively in early March. So we're well positioned, and it's a great package, and that's the feedback we're getting from the potential buyers. But on a scale basis, they're not seeing anything like this in the market. And on a quality basis, they're not seeing anything like this in the market and that's what gives us the confidence that we'll get it done and within the ranges that we talked about.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate My follow-up is really on the guidance for the 2016, specifically in Canada and the Oil Sands. Based on the differentials that you appear to be assuming and the operating cost, it looks like the real chance that some of those oil sands
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate My follow-up is really on the guidance for the 2016, specifically in Canada and the Oil Sands. Based on the differentials that you appear to be assuming and the operating cost, it looks like the real chance that some of those oil sands projects could be negative cash flow. I'm just wondering about the right interpretation and how you find demand in terms of maintaining production if oil prices remain depressed. And I'll leave it here.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me expand your questions a little bit, Doug. We think we have a great benefit here in Devon as I've been saying. We are just short-term project oriented. We do not have to continue investment into longer-term projects that no longer make economic sens
componenttext: Let me expand your questions a little bit, Doug. We think we have a great benefit here in Devon as I've been saying. We are just short-term project oriented. We do not have to continue investment into longer-term projects that no longer make economic sense such as in the Deepwater LNG projects, anything like that. So we have the ability to flex our capital down, and we have the ability to flex our capital back up very quickly. We have maintained, despite the employee we're reduction going through right now, very important to us to maintain organizational capacity to flex our program back up should we see encouragement in prices. We just don't think it makes a lot of sense to accelerate production into a 30 and 2 price environment currently. But if we set see some encouragement, we have the organizational capacity, we will have the service companies lined up where we can quickly accelerate this, and then we'll be in our commensurate adjustment in our production guidance. We have extremely high quality projects. There's no question about that. We're just showing financial the appropriate financial behavior here, given where prices are currently. Now I'll let Tony talk to you a little bit more about the oil sands, where that stands and where we stand on opportunities in the U.S. on the oil side, too.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Dave. Doug, just going back to your question back in Canada. You know on the coal flow side of the business our our location, we've got a lot of flexibility there, so we evaluate all those wells, and we're capable of shutting in those wells
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Dave. Doug, just going back to your question back in Canada. You know on the coal flow side of the business our our location, we've got a lot of flexibility there, so we evaluate all those wells, and we're capable of shutting in those wells when they become uneconomic on a well-by-well basis concern about the degradation and ultimate recoveries. When you get into the SAGD portion of the inventory there, we think we have the top tier asset in the play, and we would probably be the last company to have the stress on us from a profitability or immediate cash flow projection. You look at our capital demands for 2016, it's minor. It's minor in 2016, so we've got a lot of flexibility. There may be month to month that we have a neutral cash flow in the SAGD operation but again, we probably have the best project there. I guess when I go back and start looking at our ability to grow oil, it's more, we've got the most flexibility and more immediate impact will be in the U.S. side of the business there. We've got the best inventory our access to the best inventory in the Delaware Basin and STACK in the Eagle Ford. So we're ready to ramp up. We got a deep inventory. We have all the permitting and required work done ready for that ramp-up. So as soon as we generate additional cash flow in the company, we'll be back to work, and we'll be growing that oil base.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles. We are currently looking at an anticipated cash flow neutral budget at strip pricing from our operational cash flow, the EnLink distributions plus anticipated Access Pipeline proceeds, which by the way, we still have a high degree of confide
componenttext: Yes, Charles. We are currently looking at an anticipated cash flow neutral budget at strip pricing from our operational cash flow, the EnLink distributions plus anticipated Access Pipeline proceeds, which by the way, we still have a high degree of confidence we are going to execute on. That has not changed. So strip pricing will be cash flow neutral. If we see prices, if we see strip prices moving up and have confidence it is going to continue to move up, that's when we will consider increasing activity. And again, all of our projects are short-term so it doesn't -- and they cannot get a very, very quickly you thought the ramp down quickly we're going to ramp back up just as quickly. There is no issue there. We just feel that we're being prudent given the current commodity price environment. And where would we ramp up? Tony I think answered it. There's 3 areas that really have strong economics for us. Those are the Eagle Ford in the Delaware Basin and the stack play, and we'd be looking at all 3 of those plays to see where we put the rate, but they all would have fairly similar economics and strong economics.

componenttext: I'll let Tony take that, but I mean I'll just say, we think this combined here. We said it last quarter this we are in the best part of the STACK. We're in the heart, just like we are in the Eagle Ford with our position we acquired there in the volatile oil window plus we have and we're moving through the appraisal process right now, and we know it's going to get better. And frankly, it's getting, better it's going to keep getting better. We've got the best inventory in the industry right now. I'll let Tony go through the details on that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, you're right. If you look at our operating report, we commented in about 12 Devon wells we brought on in the Meramec and another 8 -- or another 4 that were brought on in the Phoenix position. All those really were above our type curve. In fact,
componenttext: Charles, you're right. If you look at our operating report, we commented in about 12 Devon wells we brought on in the Meramec and another 8 -- or another 4 that were brought on in the Phoenix position. All those really were above our type curve. In fact, only the majority of those wells that we continue to feel these operations the wells were not only high rate, but they are also about 60% oil, so it's above our overall modeling that we have done previously. I think the work that we're continuing is really a follow-up to the good work that the Phoenix team was doing. They really focused on the optimal landing zone in each of these Meramec intervals. A lot of detail in concern about maintaining the largest amount of drilled across the interval there. We continue to advance the completion designs. We're pumping about 2500 to 2700 pounds per lateral foot, so we're loading these completions up with a lot of sand. We're using majority of our fluid as a slick water-based fluid with some cross-link on that, so we're experimenting with the -- we're experimenting with the fluid type there. So I think all that combined is just waiting to improved completions well to well. And I think we commented last time we were on the call with you that the really the outstanding thing to do really like about the STACK play is really the volatility of the results is very narrow for a very young player like we haven't STACK, so we're very optimistic and we're ready for an increase run rate increased activity level there when the opportunity arises.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, I wanted to start with you. Obviously, Devon has taken some aggressive action on the cost front and CapEx front. So I'm wondering if you could comment on any discussions you've had with the rating agencies and your confidence about maintaining Devon'
componenttext: Tom, I wanted to start with you. Obviously, Devon has taken some aggressive action on the cost front and CapEx front. So I'm wondering if you could comment on any discussions you've had with the rating agencies and your confidence about maintaining Devon's historical investment grade credit rating.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We -- obviously, at the end of the year, you go before the agency has given your year-end results and talk about the reserve profile within the company. So we've been through that exercise. You've seen the results of that, so let me start with that. S&P h
componenttext: We -- obviously, at the end of the year, you go before the agency has given your year-end results and talk about the reserve profile within the company. So we've been through that exercise. You've seen the results of that, so let me start with that. S&P has taken us BBB, and that's stable position. And we've got Fitch having been concluded their rating currently at BBB+ and also stable. So we've got 2 solid investment grade positions there, which pretty much assures us as an investment grade company. Moody's is a different story. I think you're aware of that as well as others listening that they're debating what they're going to do. There are a lot of moving parts in there. And quite frankly, it's hard for us, I think, anybody at this point in time to tell exactly what they are going to do with this proved. They already made it position on the noninvestment grade group, which resulted in multiple notch downgrades. They've taken a very low price deck kind of view of not really rating through the cycle but rating closer to the bottom of the cycle, and they're shifting how they're thinking about investment grade. So on a historic model, I feel pretty comfortable that we would be okay. It's just very difficult at this point in time to tell exactly how they are going to recalibrate what they consider to be investment grade, and that decision-making process is in play as we speak and probably concluding before the end of the month. So wish I could give you a more firm answer on that. I think the decisions that we've taken here, while they were really primarily targeted at the business, not the rating agencies, are also credit-enhancing and should be confidence-inspiring to the agencies. And that's the best we think we can do is to really focus in the business and let the rating agency portion fall where it falls. Given, of course, the fact that you want to continue to maintain our strength in investment grade and position ourselves as best as possible.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: That's helpful. Just wondering if you could comment, if you agree with that in terms of the exit rate, given lower CapEx just talk about that this that would imply quite a bit of loss and operating momentum in 2017, how quickly do you think if you got the pricing note the year regain that operating momentum?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun, what I'm trying to emphasize to everybody here is that we are uniquely positioned with the ability -- with the fact that all of our projects are short-cycle time projects. They're all well-oriented projects. We don't have any long-term projects
componenttext: Yes, Arun, what I'm trying to emphasize to everybody here is that we are uniquely positioned with the ability -- with the fact that all of our projects are short-cycle time projects. They're all well-oriented projects. We don't have any long-term projects within the company. And so that gives us tremendous flexibility to decrease our capitals as we've done just now, when we're in a very low commodity price environment and the ability to ramp up capital spending and see commensurate results on the production side should we get some encouragement. So we can make immediate decisions around ramping production back up. We have the projects ready. We have the permits ready. All we have to do -- we have the wells designed. All we have to do is hire the rigs and the wells and then you'll see production impact anywhere from some would be completed immediately, summer pad drilling and they make take up 6 months or so to see the production impact from those, but you start seeing response from higher capital spend very, very quickly for us. And Tony might even be fill a little bit more detail on that and then what I just said, Arun.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we do our forecasting work for the year, we're confident in the ability to forecast most of our properties. What I would comment on is Eagle Ford has got the wells loss of such a high productivity index as well as have such a high productivity index
componenttext: When we do our forecasting work for the year, we're confident in the ability to forecast most of our properties. What I would comment on is Eagle Ford has got the wells loss of such a high productivity index as well as have such a high productivity index there's a little bit more range there included in that forecast. And as you know, the amount of -- for the pace of our activities is being modified as we go through the year. So that 1 property alone is the one that can drive an outperformance compared to how we had forecast. I'd also like to point out that we know with the limited capital program, we're completely focused on the base management of our business. And we talked about over the course of the last 18 months that we transformed our capabilities internally here. I think you're starting to see a lot of the results from that in public data. We had the highest 90-day [indiscernible] in each of the 4 basins that we're driving capital towards sewer pretty confident that we'll now perform. I think you saw that quarter-to-quarter over the last 6 or 8 quarters from us. A lot of that is going to be driven just by the management of our base. And so we've got -- personally, I've got a lot of confidence that we'll beat the curve that you're describing.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: My question is, I guess, a road map for asset sales and use of proceeds. You talked about paying that down. So if I think of, say, hypothetically $2 billion to $3 billion, how do you think of how that would be deployed? Is it -- would it be 100% for debt reduction, I presume, bank debt and near-term maturities? Or is there some of it that you might reconsider for the drill bit?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. What we said to you guys is that the Access proceeds would be the funding gap in the capital program this year and that the proceeds from asset divestitures, the sale of our producing properties will be targeted for debt repayment. So how we
componenttext: This is Tom. What we said to you guys is that the Access proceeds would be the funding gap in the capital program this year and that the proceeds from asset divestitures, the sale of our producing properties will be targeted for debt repayment. So how we mechanically go about that debt repayment, there's -- we're still debating how exactly to to go about that. Our bonds on the long end of the curve are trading well below par. So you actually get a big bank for the buck if that holds and you're able to redeploy that capital from this the divestiture those bonds. Whether we do that or not is yet to be determined. This is very pretty volatile environment, but that's the target right now. So you'd have Access wherever it comes out, drilling the funding gap and then the rest of it for debt repayment.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: And then, I guess, secondly, is there a way you mentioned that you want to per server optionality, and so you're organizationally capable of high level stuff activity. headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: I think it's going to be driven by our cash flow opportunities that we generate for the company. We've got the capabilities internally to ramp quickly back up to a 20-rig program if we have the business environment to do that. So we really are not inhibited by the ability to execute. We think we have the permits in place in the core -- at the core of each of our 4 areas. So it's really going to be predicated on how we generate cash flow for the year.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes the line of Edward Westlake with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Edward Westlake with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I probably have to stick with balance sheet questions. A downside in upside case, folks are worried about recession. You highlighted the quantity of the assets that you're selling this morning. But say, for example, the strip price even rose into 2017 bec
componenttext: I probably have to stick with balance sheet questions. A downside in upside case, folks are worried about recession. You highlighted the quantity of the assets that you're selling this morning. But say, for example, the strip price even rose into 2017 because of some economic weakness. What would be the game plan to manage the downside? And then I got an upside question to follow.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've already taken a lot of steps, obviously, to reduce our operating and G&A cost by around $800 million. We've -- the dividend payments, we've reduced those significantly by $320 million, adjust for our capital program. The asset sales going on.
componenttext: Well, we've already taken a lot of steps, obviously, to reduce our operating and G&A cost by around $800 million. We've -- the dividend payments, we've reduced those significantly by $320 million, adjust for our capital program. The asset sales going on. So we think we're in a good position even if the strip is slightly lower coming in 2017. We would obviously be looking in 2017 at all available options we have to us as a company, just as we did coming into 2016 today be -- is there availability for further reductions in operating expense and G&A. We could review the dividend policy, equity offerings, asset sales. We have a lot of bullets in our gun, I guess you could say, that we can fire here in order to really maintain our financial strength during these challenging economic times and we just evaluate each of those to see, which makes the most sense.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I hear that you would be willing to sell perhaps some of the Tier 1 acreage if you have to if, say, oil stayed low for 2 years.
componenttext: So I hear that you would be willing to sell perhaps some of the Tier 1 acreage if you have to if, say, oil stayed low for 2 years.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would certainly consider that. I'm not saying we're going to do that but our focus would probably be -- we have to make a decision whether it makes more sense to look at the oil side or we also have some very large gas assets sitting out there, so we h
componenttext: We would certainly consider that. I'm not saying we're going to do that but our focus would probably be -- we have to make a decision whether it makes more sense to look at the oil side or we also have some very large gas assets sitting out there, so we have to look at that as well. So I'm not going to say we would do 1 or the other but there are no stickered cows around here, and we would certainly evaluate all the available options to see which we think generates the greatest value for the shareholders. We always have to be mindful of the cash that's generated by these and we do all the appropriate analysis by making our decision but we look at all available options and see how we can best handle that situation occur.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the upside case, say oil recover to some midcycle pricing. I appreciate everyone will have a different view of what that is. You seem that you're resource-rich and the Access to liquidity is probably constraining what you could do in terms of
componenttext: And then on the upside case, say oil recover to some midcycle pricing. I appreciate everyone will have a different view of what that is. You seem that you're resource-rich and the Access to liquidity is probably constraining what you could do in terms of activity so some of the companies have been relatively successful in doing themselves a startups and issuing equity for growth capital. Is that something in the upside case you would consider?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I hate to rule anything in or out, but if you get price recovery to more like a midcycle case above the current strip, then we would have incremental cash flow available to the reinvest back into the capital program. And I think that's the first pla
componenttext: Well, I hate to rule anything in or out, but if you get price recovery to more like a midcycle case above the current strip, then we would have incremental cash flow available to the reinvest back into the capital program. And I think that's the first place we look for our funding is just from the incremental available cash flow from higher prices.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, it's the first accelerator driver.
componenttext: I guess, it's the first accelerator driver.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Following up a little bit on kind of the '16 and some comments towards what '17 might look like. Maybe to frame that up, could you mind sharing as he talked about managing base decline where base decline was in '15 and where you project it to be in '16. I think that could help give us an indication maybe '17 will shake out.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Overall base decline has really been running about roughly about 20% for the company. On the gas side, especially in north Texas, the technical team and operating group in north Texas of been outstanding job to minimize the decline using plunger lift and
componenttext: Overall base decline has really been running about roughly about 20% for the company. On the gas side, especially in north Texas, the technical team and operating group in north Texas of been outstanding job to minimize the decline using plunger lift and line production pressure reductions you managed the rest that decline it's been running about 11%. Our oil decline, because it's fairly new investments, it much greater and it tends to be over 30%. So on a combined basis, it's still around 20% year-over-year, and I wouldn't expect that to change going into '16. I think we still have a high degree of focus on our base business. We're continuing to improve our artificial lift operations. Our downtime is continuing to be minimized and improved as we go through go through our works. So high optimism that we'll continue to have wins on our large base business.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that. And then thinking just, one, about activity on the Delaware right now. On the last call you talk a little bit about the BLM and permitting process there can be a little bit challenging. But obviously, reduced activity, I would assume, put
componenttext: Appreciate that. And then thinking just, one, about activity on the Delaware right now. On the last call you talk a little bit about the BLM and permitting process there can be a little bit challenging. But obviously, reduced activity, I would assume, puts you in a better position there and trying to get color on the thoughts there and does that fit part and parcel of being able to accelerate their as you're able to maybe permit more ahead of the potential ramp-up.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you mentioned, our activity was down in comparisons where it was 2 years ago. The permitting requirements are not as near as they had been between the have stopped our desire to have a great working relationship with the BLM, especially in southeast of
componenttext: As you mentioned, our activity was down in comparisons where it was 2 years ago. The permitting requirements are not as near as they had been between the have stopped our desire to have a great working relationship with the BLM, especially in southeast of Mexico. That relationship is extremely high. We just entered into the ability to work with that office there under a master agreement type concept, which we believe will be able to communicate more of a full development plan with them and get all the permitting done collectively. It won't include the individual APDs from the wells that will have to come back and follow up with that, but it will greatly accelerate our ability to ramp back up. So we're continuing that relationship and were confident that we can how those wins that we've had in southeastern Mexico and take those to Wyoming and be able to ramp back up in the Powder River Basin and that asset as well.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes the line of John Herrlin with Societe Generale.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: A few questions for you on MLPs and EnLink, Dave. Some of the more leveraged E&Ps are kind of rolling them the market is folks are worried about transportation contract changes, things like that. How do you view EnLink or has your strategy changed at all
componenttext: A few questions for you on MLPs and EnLink, Dave. Some of the more leveraged E&Ps are kind of rolling them the market is folks are worried about transportation contract changes, things like that. How do you view EnLink or has your strategy changed at all with it? Because it seems like you're getting penalized for the carnage at the MLP market.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our strategy has not changed at all with regard EnLink. We think we have a great relationship with them. They provide outstanding service to us. We also like the fact that we are aligned with them and our new acreage in the STACK play that we acquired fro
componenttext: Our strategy has not changed at all with regard EnLink. We think we have a great relationship with them. They provide outstanding service to us. We also like the fact that we are aligned with them and our new acreage in the STACK play that we acquired from with them acquiring the assets that gives us great confidence as we put capital against that program that we're going to have outstanding service to get those wells hooked up in a timely manner. And so our strategy really has not changed in regard to that. We certainly are -- believe the agreements we have a them are important and the volume commitments and the rates that that tariffs we agreed to pay are bound by contract, and we plan to live up to those agreements. So there's really no change that's been in our relationship and our feeling about them from a long-term strategic value. Having said that, we obviously looked at everything in our portfolio and so if there's a reason why that should change, we like it long term, we will never rule any asset or anything as an absolute sacred cow or we don't look at the best business decision if there's -- should we go another direction. But right now, we don't see a reason to go another direction with the EnLink relationship.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: One last one for me. You mentioned tighter spacing in your ops report of the Bone Spring and the Leonard. Is that going to be the kind of the future from a development perspective there that you'll be doing tighter horizontal well spacing?
componenttext: One last one for me. You mentioned tighter spacing in your ops report of the Bone Spring and the Leonard. Is that going to be the kind of the future from a development perspective there that you'll be doing tighter horizontal well spacing?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Tony. I think you're right about that. We're actually having a lot of encouraging results right now on our downspacing pilot, especially on the areas that have original reservoir pressure. So if you look at -- historically, we landed the Sec
componenttext: John, this is Tony. I think you're right about that. We're actually having a lot of encouraging results right now on our downspacing pilot, especially on the areas that have original reservoir pressure. So if you look at -- historically, we landed the Second Bone Spring said the lower section of that package and then we staggered some what the call A sand wells above that and are seeing very encouraging results. It's early on the areas that have partial depletion. We would expect a little bit less ability to down space, but the data is still coming in, and we'll understand that better as you go through 2016. And of course, all this is really tied to oil price. So there'll be a direct relationship to spacing for all of us and the business environment as we go forward.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to the balance sheet, what are the metrics that you regard as most important for Devon? And will the asset sales and the dividend cut get you to where you want to be for a leverage perspective? Or kind of for some of the earlier questions, are
componenttext: Going back to the balance sheet, what are the metrics that you regard as most important for Devon? And will the asset sales and the dividend cut get you to where you want to be for a leverage perspective? Or kind of for some of the earlier questions, are you considering more actions in your base case scenario as opposed to a downsize area?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. I think the asset sales go a long ways towards getting us where we want to be. And if you're on historical metrics, I think that pretty much works, and that's what we're seeing from S&P and Fitch. Now like I said earlier in my previous commen
componenttext: This is Tom. I think the asset sales go a long ways towards getting us where we want to be. And if you're on historical metrics, I think that pretty much works, and that's what we're seeing from S&P and Fitch. Now like I said earlier in my previous comment, it's just really hard to tell where Moody's going to shake out. So we're leaning really more on a historical view what those metrics have been, which is not just cash flow metrics. It also involves a fairly healthy component of size and scale. But on Moody's, it's just extremely difficult at this point to answer your question.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So the underlying goal then here is investment grade credit's whatever metrics they look that would be what you want to gear the strategy towards?
componenttext: Got it. So the underlying goal then here is investment grade credit's whatever metrics they look that would be what you want to gear the strategy towards?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we maintain investment grade status with just 2 rating agencies. So we really -- regardless of what Moody's does, we stay in investment grade indexes. So while we like that, it's -- it doesn't damage our investment grade status if they were to drop
componenttext: Well, we maintain investment grade status with just 2 rating agencies. So we really -- regardless of what Moody's does, we stay in investment grade indexes. So while we like that, it's -- it doesn't damage our investment grade status if they were to drop us below.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up is in regards to the staying within cash flow. If and when oil prices do improve, should we just expect the straight CapEx equals cash flow type strategy and how does the EnLink business apply here outspending including the impact o
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up is in regards to the staying within cash flow. If and when oil prices do improve, should we just expect the straight CapEx equals cash flow type strategy and how does the EnLink business apply here outspending including the impact of distribution that on a consolidated basis that the EnLink level, does that weigh in your decision or is it solely Devon and Devon only?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's essentially Devon and Devon only on that, Brian. And I think that would be the first thing I would say is look at just a straight how much incremental cash flow we'd have and putting that to work back into E&P capital. That's a good first proxy. Obvi
componenttext: It's essentially Devon and Devon only on that, Brian. And I think that would be the first thing I would say is look at just a straight how much incremental cash flow we'd have and putting that to work back into E&P capital. That's a good first proxy. Obviously, we'd look at longer term what we think prices are going to do and greater confidence we're going to moving up significantly the future. We might be willing to ramp up a little bit more than that conversely we think I'd say temporarily phenomenal we will ramp up a little bit less that's a good first proxy you have to think about it.

componenttext: Question on the Access Pipeline sale. Your partner in the pipeline that has made some noise about potentially selling their stake as well. Does that help your process? Does it hinder it or is there push?

componenttext: It's really independent of that, Bob. We have our own processes going on for that. Frankly, we think we're probably a little more advanced in our stage of on the process than our partner is on looking at their 50%, but it's really 2 independent processes at this point. And as I said they are made great confident that we are going to be able to transact on that sometime in the first half of the year potentially as early as the first quarter, but no guarantees on that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, actually, you're in a pretty unique position where you can maintain investment grade you can talk pretty openly about some of the concerns for investors around what happens to any of the company when you lose investment grade. Like what are the steps
componenttext: Tom, actually, you're in a pretty unique position where you can maintain investment grade you can talk pretty openly about some of the concerns for investors around what happens to any of the company when you lose investment grade. Like what are the steps that goes on the about your credit facility being secured, hedging facility, any transportation changes, just curious about your perspective.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just emphasize again, so people are clear. Nothing will happen to us with the Moody's shift. And even if we had a bad result from another rating agencies, our liquidity position is solid and doesn't change at all. So there's no -- there's not
componenttext: Well, let me just emphasize again, so people are clear. Nothing will happen to us with the Moody's shift. And even if we had a bad result from another rating agencies, our liquidity position is solid and doesn't change at all. So there's no -- there's nothing in our revolving capacity or debt or bank debt capacity that changes in that circumstance. Those covenants remain the same. Nothing gets triggered. There's nothing in our public debt or indentures that would occur if that is the case. I think the real impact to those that this occurs to would just be access to the capital markets and primarily, cost. You'd be dealing with higher cost if you tap the markets. Our revolver has got a lot of term into. We're out into '19 where it terms up a lot of it's going to happen between now in that point in time have to renegotiate now are going to be dealing with a totally different environment. And then, I think, the uncertainty that you're seeing at the agencies and how they approach this is going to reach into those types of negotiations or have people to near-term debt concerns just dealing with an uncertain bank market and an uncertain capital market. The bondholders that I've spoken to are equally confused by this and don't know necessarily how exactly it's going to shake out. We don't think in our portfolio level but there's a lot that will be dependent on Moody's, but there potentially selling bonds for those investors who require a Moody's and an S&P rating both the whole deck, so that could also be another impact. But just to reemphasize for Devon, Devon really nothing would happen. If we have taken fully noninvestment grade, which is not going to happen, there would be no change in our debt picture.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: And nothing on the commercial paper either?

componenttext: Well, I mean it's trading today at about where it was trading through the fourth quarter. It's around $0.72 where the exchange rate it. So it hasn't weakened further. It weakened throughout the year and give us a significant uplift on the reduction in cost that you saw but it hasn't continued to weaken in the first part of this year.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes the line of David Tameron Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes the line of David Tameron Wells Fargo.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. If I just think -- and I'm just thinking about what they've seen you do on the Meramec as far as Wolfcamp, Eagle Ford, et cetera. I guess the 2 part question what would be how much more room service costs in the forward strip out ri
componenttext: A couple of questions. If I just think -- and I'm just thinking about what they've seen you do on the Meramec as far as Wolfcamp, Eagle Ford, et cetera. I guess the 2 part question what would be how much more room service costs in the forward strip out right now. How much more room do you have as far as cost reductions available in the next 2 to 3 quarters, which were downsized. And the second piece which you talked about your core assets and they've all been economic today. Philosophically, how do you guys think about the big picture U.S. and crude prices? I'm just trying to chase that marginal cost type number.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start on the operating side. We would estimate that the '16 cost in comparison to '15 might be down another 4%, and it varies by category, of course. We still think there are operating efficiencies gains that we will have. As you roll back about 12
componenttext: Let me start on the operating side. We would estimate that the '16 cost in comparison to '15 might be down another 4%, and it varies by category, of course. We still think there are operating efficiencies gains that we will have. As you roll back about 12 months ago, we saw -- early in the year, we saw a nice improvement in the nervous provider de-escalation component. But in the second half of the year, we saw great efficiency gains with just optimizing all of our well construction designs, optimizing our -- the execution of our wells. We had very little trouble time all that is accelerated our time to TD. We're getting better wells completed because of the focus on that detail. So we'll continue that. And historically, we've always seen somewhere between a 0% and 10% efficiency gain, and I wouldn't expect anything different than that by the time we get to the end of '16.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just expand a little bit on your question. We have certainly seen third-party studies that show that our acreage in the Eagle Ford and DeWitt County is probably the most economic acreage in the Eagle Ford. And I think it competes well with any pla
componenttext: I would just expand a little bit on your question. We have certainly seen third-party studies that show that our acreage in the Eagle Ford and DeWitt County is probably the most economic acreage in the Eagle Ford. And I think it competes well with any play in onshore North America where I can also tell you that we see very similar economics to DeWitt County and our -- the heart of our plays in the Delaware Basin and in the STACK play. So we think that we have 3 certainly 3 of the plays in our portfolio that position us with the most economic opportunities that you might find in onshore North America STACK play  at this point is not a question of the strength of the portfolio at this point it's a question of how much capital recovery going to put against a strong portfolio. And I just want to emphasize one last time we've taken capital down significantly and we understand that. It's because we have a flexibility to do that and this current 30 and 2 price environment, but we have the ability to ramp that capital back up just as quickly and bring production back just as quickly should we see encouragement on the commodity price environment. So the first priority right now is balance sheet that's what we're doing we have the ability to ramp it right back up and get back into game.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I'll draw your attention back to the operating report on Page 12. You can just look at our Cana results in the Woodford, and you'll see that we dropped our time to TD from 40 to 20 days, so we actually decreased the drill time in half. And after 80
componenttext: David, I'll draw your attention back to the operating report on Page 12. You can just look at our Cana results in the Woodford, and you'll see that we dropped our time to TD from 40 to 20 days, so we actually decreased the drill time in half. And after 800 wells, as we've talked about, our continuous improvement in completion side after 800 wells being drilled and completed, we're still seeing the highest IPs of the history of the Cana-Woodford work.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes form the line of Ross Payne with Wells Fargo.

componenttext: I think we've kind of worn out the rating agency discussion, but I just want to ask you a simple question. Are they looking at your metrics excluding EnLink or inclusive of them?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ross, Tom again. It depends on which one you're dealing with. For the most part, they included and included in different ways. And it's really included kind of on the -- even though this is a nonrecourse debt to Devon, Moody's looks at it as a "too big to
componenttext: Ross, Tom again. It depends on which one you're dealing with. For the most part, they included and included in different ways. And it's really included kind of on the -- even though this is a nonrecourse debt to Devon, Moody's looks at it as a "too big to fail" type situation you will come in and support the credit in the event there were issues that's largely how they look at it. S&P takes them down 1 notch from where we are and looks at it a little bit differently.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Jon Wolf with Jefferies. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Guys, looking at the $2.4 billion available of liquidity on the secured credit facility have been $3 billion prior. I was wondering if something was drawn, maybe commercial paper termination or was it related to the facility being reduced? Question number one.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. There are a lot of moving parts going to the end of the year So the only change from our 3 billion capacity is we paid down about $300 million of commercial paper. So net-net, your net available liquidity is pretty much close to what you saw on our re
componenttext: No. There are a lot of moving parts going to the end of the year So the only change from our 3 billion capacity is we paid down about $300 million of commercial paper. So net-net, your net available liquidity is pretty much close to what you saw on our report, just shy of $4 billion.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll reiterate it. We all feel extremely confident that these assets, from all we understand, are higher quality assets than anyone else put on the market, including some of those recently transacted. And we also feel that there may be other compani
componenttext: Well, I'll reiterate it. We all feel extremely confident that these assets, from all we understand, are higher quality assets than anyone else put on the market, including some of those recently transacted. And we also feel that there may be other companies that may be coming out of assets later in the year, but we're beating them to the market. So we -- from all the feedback we get is that our expectations are very realistic for the timing and from the magnitude of proceeds that we can expect to receive from these assets. We have had a significant contact with potential purchasers even before we get the data rooms out there. As Tom said, it ranges from majors to well-capitalized independents to a lot of interest from private equity and, frankly, people become comfortable with this price environment want to make an entry at this point and the high quality of these assets, frankly, can be a company maker type opportunity for some smaller companies and that's what some of these people are looking at and frankly they can start a whole company around 1 or more of these assets and have a very bright future. So you never know for sure obviously until you transact, but all the feedback we have gives us tremendous confidence that we're well positioned from a timing standpoint on this and with a quality standpoint to make this happen.

componenttext: Well, we've already issued the equity associated with those transactions, the $1.35 billion, and Tom can get you give you the exact numbers, but they were issued, I think, a little over $44 for the Felix side and a little over $40, $41, I think, on the Powder River Basin asset. I'm not going to take anything off the table as far as the possibility but we think we've taken some very significant steps to really increase the financial strengths of the company actions that we talked about today.

componenttext: Well, as Tom said, we have had our ratings at S&P. We were downgraded 1 but stay stable. And Fitch, we're not and we're still at the previous rating there. We're not non-investment grade so we are going to do the right decisions for the business period. We can't just chase investment grade rating certainly when it's with Moody's when we're uncertain what the criteria are that they're going to use. So we're going to focus less on that and make sure that we make the right decision for the business overall for our shareholders and for our bondholders.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Devon Energy's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]. This call is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Howard Thill, Senior Vice President of Communications and Investor Rela
componenttext:
Welcome to Devon Energy's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]. This call is being recorded. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Howard Thill, Senior Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephen, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to welcome you to the call as well. Today's call is going to consist largely of Q&A, so I hope everyone has had a chance to review our fourth quarter and full year earnings release as it also incl
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephen, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to welcome you to the call as well. 
Today's call is going to consist largely of Q&A, so I hope everyone has had a chance to review our fourth quarter and full year earnings release as it also includes our forward-looking guidance as well as our detailed operations report.
Also on the call today are Dave Hager, President and CEO; Tony Vaughn, Executive Vice President of E&P; Tom Mitchell, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and a few other members of our senior management team.
Finally, I'll remind you that comments and answers to questions on the call will contain plans, forecasts, expectations and estimates, which are forward-looking statements under U.S. securities laws. These comments and answers are subject to a number of assumptions, risks and uncertainties, many of which are beyond our control. These statements are not guarantees of future performance, and actual results might differ materially. For a review of risk factors relating to these statements, please see our Form 10-K. 
With that, I will turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard, and welcome, everyone. As we all know, 2015 provided an extremely challenging business environment for our industry. We responded during the year by proactively taking steps to align our business with these conditions by reducing field-
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard, and welcome, everyone. As we all know, 2015 provided an extremely challenging business environment for our industry. We responded during the year by proactively taking steps to align our business with these conditions by reducing field-level costs by $400 million, delivering efficiencies and cost savings that reduced capital requirements by $500 million. And we attained significant productivity gains and improved type curves and IP rates across all our core plays. 
As we look to 2016, our top priority in this environment is to protect the balance sheet by balancing spending requirements with available cash flow. We also see no reason to accelerate production growth into these weak markets, which has led us to take aggressive measures to reduce our capital investment by 75% year-over-year. 
We also have plans in place to preserve more than $1 billion of cash flow on a go-forward basis through a number of initiatives, including incremental field-level cost savings, a reduction of our workforce by about 1,000 people and, by adjusting the dividend rate, preserve over $300 million of cash flow. In an effort to further strengthen our balance sheet, we also have noncore divestitures underway with the intent to monetize $2 billion to $3 billion of assets during 2016.
As I have said many times, Devon is in the advantageous position of having no long-cycle projects, minimal long-term contracts, and nearly all of our acreage is held by production. These favorable attributes allow us to prudently adjust our 2016 capital program to balance cash flows and to protect our balance sheet, but it also gives us the ability to ramp up development activity when commodity prices rebound and to see a quick production response to that ramp when it happens. 
Our 2016 program in -- capital program in 2016 is designed to maximize cash flow and operational continuity with activity directed toward the lowest-risk and highest-impact opportunities in each of Devon's core areas. This disciplined capital program is expected to maintain relatively flat oil production from Devon's core assets compared to 2015, and we're projecting only a 10% oil decline from Q4 2015 to Q4 2016. 
This production resiliency is a testament to the quality of our go-forward assets. Overall, top line production in 2016 from core assets is expected to decline by 6% driven by lower gas volumes. 
The efficiency of our 2016 budget is also highlighted by our ability to fund our capital program at today's strip pricing within operational cash flow, EnLink distributions and expected Access Pipeline proceeds. Once again, we have the flexibility to ramp up spending or to make additional cuts to our spending plans depending upon how commodity prices trend going forward. 
As I mentioned earlier, in addition to balancing near-term spending with cash inflows, we are also working to improve our financial position through the monetization of $2 billion to $3 billion of assets. We are in the latter stages of discussions for the sale of our 50% interest in Access Pipeline and expect that transaction to occur in the first half of the year, potentially the first quarter. 
We are also in the process of opening data room for the sale of up to 80,000 BOE per day of noncore upstream assets in the U.S. The properties up for sale include 15,000 net undeveloped acres in Martin County, Texas and producing assets in the Southern Midland Wolfcamp, Carthage, Granite Wash and Mississippian Lime plays. We have had direct contact from potential buyers ranging from majors to well-capitalized peers to private equity firms.
We believe these assets are substantially higher-quality than those being considered for divestment by others and are in the market quicker. This gives us a competitive edge. Conversations thus far have been encouraging, and we have confidence in our ability to attractively sell these assets throughout 2016 and use the upstream asset sale proceeds for debt retirements. 
Looking at our financial flexibility longer term. If commodity prices remain low, Devon has significant balance sheet strength to withstand an extended downturn. Pro forma for the Felix acquisition, which closed in early January, we had $3.9 billion of liquidity at year-end, consisting of $1.5 billion of cash and $2.4 billion of capacity on our senior credit facility. Importantly, this credit facility does not mature until the end of 2019 and contains only one material financial covenant: a debt-to-capitalization ratio below 65%. At year-end, this ratio was only 24%. 
In addition, our strong -- to our strong liquidity, we've done a good job managing our upcoming debt maturities with no significant debt coming due until December 2018. Bottom line, our advantaged capital structure provides us a significant amount of financial strength and flexibility. 
So in summary, I hope you come away with 3 important messages today. First, we are committed to living within cash flows in 2016. To do so, we have taken aggressive measures to preserve more than $1 billion of cash flow through operating cost and dividend reductions. Second, we have the financial strength to withstand an extended downturn, and we're looking to further bolster our investment-grade balance sheet with ongoing asset divestiture programs. And lastly, the quality, depth and diversification of our go-forward asset base is unmatched. Devon has exposure to some of the best short-cycle projects in the world. We are well positioned to accelerate activity when the markets reward growth again.
With that, I will turn the call back to Howard for Q&A.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
