componenttext: Welcome to Devon Energy's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Howard Thill, Senior Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Melissa, and I'd like to wish everyone a good morning as well and welcome you to Devon Energy's first [ph] quarter earnings conference call. I hope you had a chance to review our first quarter earnings release, which includes our forward-lookin
componenttext:
Thank you, Melissa, and I'd like to wish everyone a good morning as well and welcome you to Devon Energy's first [ph] quarter earnings conference call. I hope you had a chance to review our first quarter earnings release, which includes our forward-looking guidance as well as our detailed ops report. Also on the call today are Dave Hager, President and CEO; Tony Vaughn, Chief Operating Officer; Tom Mitchell, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, and a few other members of our senior management team.
Finally, I'd remind you that comments and answers to questions on this call will contain forecasts, plans, expectations and estimates, which are forward-looking statements under U.S. securities law. These comments and answers are subject to a number of assumptions, risks and uncertainties, many of which are beyond our control. These statements are not guarantees of future performance and actual results may differ materially. For a review of risk factors relating to the statements, please see our Form 10-K.
With that, I will turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard, and welcome everyone. There's no question of low commodity prices in the first quarter led to tough conditions for Devon in the industry. However, we respond to these challenges by delivering another outstanding operating performance as
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard, and welcome everyone. There's no question of low commodity prices in the first quarter led to tough conditions for Devon in the industry. However, we respond to these challenges by delivering another outstanding operating performance as we continue to take the appropriate steps to deliver significant cost reductions and accelerate efficiency gains across our portfolio. These successful efforts resulted in us delivering production at the high end of our guidance, driving down both operating cost and G&A down more than 20% over year and increase in our liquidity to $4.6 billion.
This strong execution has improved our full year 2016 outlook with us raising our 2016 production targets by 3%, importantly, without any incremental capital requirements. Additionally, our cost-saving initiatives are well on our way to preserve more than $1 billion of cash flow during the year, and commodity prices are running above our base budgeting expectations.
Even with a meaningful increase in commodity prices from first quarter lows, our disciplined approach to this environment remains unchanged. Our top priority is to protect our balance sheet strength by balancing spending requirements with cash flow, and we see no compelling reason to accelerate production at these improved yet still low pricing points.
As I touched on earlier, our 2016 E&P capital program remains unchanged, and the activity we will deploy is designed to maximize cash flow generation and maintain operational continuity in our top resource plays.
For us to consider adding additional activity, we would need to make additional progress on our asset sales, have the ability to hedge at sustainably higher commodity prices and have comfort that we can secure services and supplies at rational costs. When these conditions are met, we have no shortage of attractive investment opportunities across our research-rich portfolio. 
Our core assets are concentrated in North America's best basins, and we are getting the most out of these assets with best-in-class execution that has consistently exceeded peer results through higher production rates, lower capital cost and reduced operating expenses. While there are several verticals to consider when allocating capital, it is likely that we would initially accelerate activity with our top 2 franchise assets, the STACK and Delaware Basin. Between these 2 world-class resource plays, we have access to over 1 million net acres and thousands of low-risk development opportunities that are delivering rates of return to rank among the very top of our asset portfolio. 
Another strategic imperative for Devon in 2016 is the work we are doing to improve our financial strength through the monetization of $2 billion to $3 billion of noncore assets. In April, we took an important step toward that goal with the announced sale of our Mississippian assets in Northern Oklahoma for $200 million. The daily rooms for our remaining noncore upstream assets have been open since early March, and bids are expected by the end of the second quarter. The interest in our Midland, East Texas and Granite Wash asset packages had been quite strong, and we have great confidence in our ability to sell these assets at attractive prices in 2016. 
In Canada, we're also making progress toward the sale of our 50% interest in Access pipeline. Negotiations are ongoing with discussions centered on contract-related considerations. Given the multi-decade lifespan of heavy oil assets, it is important that we judiciously work through these contractual details to ensure both parties are comfortable with those long-term relationship.
Overall, we are encouraged by the direction of these conversations, and we still expect to announce a transaction in the first half of this year.
Before we move to Q&A, I want to summarize a few key messages from today's call. Even with the recent uptick in pricing, our top priority remains unchanged. We maintain a strong balance sheet. We are committed to balancing capital requirements with cash flow and enhancing our financial strength by utilizing upstream asset sale proceeds to reduce debt.
We are laser-focused on the control -- controllable aspects of our business. This is evidenced by our outstanding operational performance in the first quarter and our continued cost control efforts. We have taken aggressive actions to position Devon not only to weather this downturn but to be positioned to take advantage of our world-class resource plays when market conditions incentivize higher activity levels. And as commodity prices recover, Devon has significant leverage to rising oil, natural gas and NGL prices. For every $1 increase in realized price on a BOE basis, Devon generates more than $200 million of incremental cash flow annually. Additionally, this $1 increase in realized price proportionally expands Devon's margins more than nearly every large producer in North America. Couple this with a catalyst-risk deleveraging of the balance sheet in the asset sales and upside from further delineation of the STACK play, Devon is extremely well positioned for a differential stock price performance.
With that, I will turn the call back to Howard for Q&A.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we continue to work our footprint in the STACK play, we're overwhelmingly positive feel about the results that we see. I think an operating report that we published last night continues to show that our results are above type curve expectations. The in
componenttext: As we continue to work our footprint in the STACK play, we're overwhelmingly positive feel about the results that we see. I think an operating report that we published last night continues to show that our results are above type curve expectations. The interesting thing about this was a lot of the rock and fluid and pressure variability across the play. In fact, the whole play is working from the far northeast to the southwest really well, but there's a lot of different characteristics of the play that are changing across that footprint. And if you look at the results that we've had just in the Devon footprint, our range of results have been very tight. Our P10 to P90 ratio is about 2.4, which is very indicative of a lower risk of element-type play. So I think as we go forward, we'll continue to see optimization of our completion designs. We're changing the fluids. We're changing the profit loads. We're changing the number of stages and tightening up on the perf cluster spacing, just like a lot of people in the industry are doing. So that will continue to optimize our results. We're also engaged in about 6 different pilots across our footprint, and 4 of those are being operated by Devon. We already have the production data coming at us on 2 of those pallets that we commented on in the operations report. It's early but the early indications are on a fairly conservative spacing on a single zone of 5 oils per section, which we're testing in We didn't see interference on the frac work that we were doing. All the well rates are coming in to the type curve, if not better. We published a little bit of information, early information, on the test, which was a staggered-type test in the Meramec and very positive there that we did not see the energy across from one interval to the next. And ultimately, that would be spaced at about 6 wells per common zone, potentially 13 and the 2 that we're testing there. We also had 2 additional pallets that will test 7 and 8 wells per section in a common interval. So I think as the data flow comes in throughout the year, we'll get more information about spacing. We're participating in some other pallets from some of our nonoperated partners in there. They all have information coming in. So really for the second half of '16, I think that spacing question will start being a lot more clear. I think you'll continue to see our performance improve as we optimize the work that we do. But right now, we're extremely pleased. And as you know, if you look at the location camp there, it's just very deep for Devon, and this will be a driver for Devon's future for a long time.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And to give you an idea, we are seeing quarter-over-quarter oil decline here from our core oil of about 25,000 barrels a day, but I think the most important thing to understand is that when you look out for the second half of the year, we expect our
componenttext: Yes. And to give you an idea, we are seeing quarter-over-quarter oil decline here from our core oil of about 25,000 barrels a day, but I think the most important thing to understand is that when you look out for the second half of the year, we expect our oil production to be flat to slightly higher than the Q2 production as our completion activity resumes in the Eagle Ford and our Jackfish 2 ramps up to nameplate capacity. So it is -- and obviously overall, we raised our production guidance. And so overall, I'd say a very positive story. We may be seeing a slightly higher decline in Q2 than some of you may have expected, just mainly because we're such high-rate walls that we delivered, particularly in the Eagle Ford in the last half of 2015 and with the lack of completion activities here early in the year as the completion occurs in the field. But overall, it's a very positive story. I think it may just surprise a couple of people that we're taking it in the second quarter, but the good news is as commodity prices improve, hopefully in the second half of the year, given that we raised our overall guidance would be producing more than originally anticipated second half when prices will be higher. So Tony, you want to add some more detail to that?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just I think you said it well, Dave. Subash, if you go from Q1 to Q2, Dave commented at our total decline on oil will be about 25,000 barrels of oil per day. We actually have a turnaround schedule for Jackfish 2 in the second quarter, which will account f
componenttext: Just I think you said it well, Dave. Subash, if you go from Q1 to Q2, Dave commented at our total decline on oil will be about 25,000 barrels of oil per day. We actually have a turnaround schedule for Jackfish 2 in the second quarter, which will account for about 10,000 BOEs or BOs per day, but if you look at the Delaware Basin and the STACK position oil production, they're essentially flat over the last portion of the year, the second half of the year. So as Dave mentioned, it's a positive story for the company. I think the -- if you look, specifically talk about the Eagle Ford, you'll notice that we had outstanding results in the second half of 2014, and that carried into Q1 of 2015 -- from second half of 2015 that carried into this first quarter of 2016 and go back and look at that the pace of activity was about 50 to 55 IDs per quarter. The number of the wells we brought on in Q1 of '16 was only 22, and that happened to be early in the quarter. So we ramped down that activity along with working network with a partner there. So the Eagle Ford has taken a larger projected to take a larger drop Q1 of '16 to Q2 of '16. But again, as we bring -- we've taken a completion holiday there as we bring completion units back into the field in the latter part of Q2, we'll see that production stabilize from Q2 through Q4 in the Eagle Ford. Month-to-month is going to be pretty cyclic, just depending on the pace of new wells that we bring on.

componenttext: In the Eagle Ford, as I mentioned, we were completing about 50 to 55 wells per quarter, and Q1 is about 22, and we'll take a holiday through Q2 of no new wells brought on in Q2, but then we'll see about -- roughly speaking, about 35 and about 15 in Q3 and Q4. So it's really lumpy. We've got 2 drilling rigs. We've got 2 drilling rigs working in the field. And as we build up a little bit of inventory there, we will tend to work that down with 1 to 1.5 frac crews and maintain a fairly flat duck inventory from beginning of the year to the end of the year, just be a little bit lumpy from month-to-month.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, you'd talked in the past about a question about when you go back to work, but you guys have been a little more specific about requiring the asset sales to be done pretty much irrespective of where the oil price goes. I just wondered if I could ask y
componenttext: Dave, you'd talked in the past about a question about when you go back to work, but you guys have been a little more specific about requiring the asset sales to be done pretty much irrespective of where the oil price goes. I just wondered if I could ask you to revisit your thoughts there and obviously, so predicated on your confidence level in getting our sales done. So you do go back to working on oil price recovery before the asset sales done or did the asset sales still have to come first?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The asset sales still have to come first. Now having said that, I recognize this is a show-me environment, and we understand that very well, but I reiterate our confidence in the asset sales that we are going to get of those asset sales executed without g
componenttext: The asset sales still have to come first. Now having said that, I recognize this is a show-me environment, and we understand that very well, but I reiterate our confidence in the asset sales that we are going to get of those asset sales executed without going into a tremendous amount of detail of the discussions and negotiations. We are -- we think that that is something that is working very positively, and we're confident that we're going to get those done in the time frame that we described. But that is the first priority is to make sure that we do that. After that, then there are a number of things that will factor into increasing our activities: commodity prices, capital costs, operating expenses, many more. But directionally, you could look for us to start adding incremental activity when oil prices are $50 or higher. Now that doesn't mean that we go back from the 2 operated rigs to 20 operated rigs immediately at $50. That means start adding operated rigs at that point. I said during the comments that the most likely first place that we would add the rig would be in the Delaware Basin and then the STACK play, obviously, well results are just outstanding amongst the best in the industry in both of those places. And so we would incrementally add rigs as we -- as prices increase, but it will probably take $60 oil or more to really get back to our capital spend level of close to $2 billion versus $1 billion for at right now, which would really, with our maintenance capital, somewhere between $1.5 billion or $2 billion, and that allow us to really flatten the production. Frankly, our #1 priority is not just flattening the production on a 6:1 conversion rate. We're much more, first, the financial strength of the balance sheet and then second, making sure that every dollar that we invest generating strong economic returns, and we included a graph on the operations report that gives you feel that again we have some of that not only in some of the best plays in onshore North America, but we're in the heart of some of the best plays. We're in the core of the core of these plays. We certainly have we think is good of an economic opportunity is anybody out there but again, first, it's going to take the asset sales; second, starting rigs at 50, again, at small increment and continue to ramp up as prices increase into our strong place.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perhaps, Tony, I was wondering if you could comment on just overall well results and returns that you're seeing in the overpressured versus the normally pressured STACK and perhaps where Devon's well results from an operated and the no-operated have been
componenttext: Perhaps, Tony, I was wondering if you could comment on just overall well results and returns that you're seeing in the overpressured versus the normally pressured STACK and perhaps where Devon's well results from an operated and the no-operated have been concentrated.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess if I had to characterize the results that we're seeing, they're very consistent, if you look at our type curve of about that 1300 to 1500. We brought on about 5 operated wells and 5 nonoperated wells. All of those are the type curve or better. The
componenttext: I guess if I had to characterize the results that we're seeing, they're very consistent, if you look at our type curve of about that 1300 to 1500. We brought on about 5 operated wells and 5 nonoperated wells. All of those are the type curve or better. The footprint -- again, when you look at the all the attributes of the STACK play, the project is working all across the play, but the attributes that describe the subsurface are drastically changing. The rock composition changes from the northwest to the southeast. The pressure gradient is -- for the whole play is largely overpressure. It does tend to increase in pressure as you go through the southwestern portion of the field. And then as you move from the northeast to the southwest, you've got a changing fluid composition. All that's working across the field. If you look at ours, we're seeing type curve type results very consistently. I think the best completion we brought on this quarter was about 2100 BOEs per day, so we're feeling pretty good about that. We find that the sweet spot that we've identified in our operating report for the STACK play has got the best combination of all of those attributes, which incorporate depth and cost to complete, so we think that's going to be the high return portion of the development right now.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And add here. One of the things we tried to clarify by including a map and the operations report is that it's a gradational amount of overpressure throughout the play. And there's a map, I think, on Page 7, that shows it very clearly that essentially all
componenttext: And add here. One of the things we tried to clarify by including a map and the operations report is that it's a gradational amount of overpressure throughout the play. And there's a map, I think, on Page 7, that shows it very clearly that essentially all of our acreage is located in the overpressure part of the play. It's just the degree to which is overpressured and the degree to which its overpressure the increases as you move from northeast to southwest. Now as you move further to the northeast in our acreage position, you get more into the normal pressure of oil window. That worked too. I think, frankly, you just had some good results up there as well of very economic results but essentially all of our acreage is in the overpressured part of the window, it's just the degree to which it's overpressured. If you look at that map, I think that's helpful.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. Just a follow-up. I was wondering if you could go through the staggered lateral testing in the Eagle Ford, just maybe comment on that pilot and expectations going forward to develop the Eagle Ford using that spacing type of pattern.
componenttext: That's very helpful. Just a follow-up. I was wondering if you could go through the staggered lateral testing in the Eagle Ford, just maybe comment on that pilot and expectations going forward to develop the Eagle Ford using that spacing type of pattern.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're encouraged. We drilled 25 wells on a staggered approach in the lower Eagle Ford. We've got a 3D earth model there that the technical team has built, and we got an accurate description of where all the wellbores have penetrated. And if you're just st
componenttext: We're encouraged. We drilled 25 wells on a staggered approach in the lower Eagle Ford. We've got a 3D earth model there that the technical team has built, and we got an accurate description of where all the wellbores have penetrated. And if you're just staying within the lower Eagle Ford section, whether you're in the upper portion of that interval or the lower portion of that, the results have all been the same. So we have now incorporated the staggered approach into the lower Eagle Ford, and results will be coming in on the 25 wells in the next couple of quarters that early indications are that it's extremely favorable. So we're seeing reservoir pressures within the that we're not seeing interference or influence from each of those wells. One thing that we're going to be testing in the last 3 quarters of this year will be how to incorporate the Upper Eagle Ford shale into that development, and there's not a lot of shale barriers between that Upper Eagle Ford and the lower Eagle Ford section, so we're encouraged and I believe BHP is going to be supportive of this work as to pilot the Upper Eagle Ford completion along with staggered approach in the Lower Eagle Ford. So that will be what we think will be ultimately the design that you will go forward from the remaining development of the resource base.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Herrlin from Societe Generale.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: How gradational are the members vertically and -- or how well defined are the various members between the upper and the lower? And will this affect, given the pressure gradients you've already discussed across your acreage, would you have to have kind of
componenttext: How gradational are the members vertically and -- or how well defined are the various members between the upper and the lower? And will this affect, given the pressure gradients you've already discussed across your acreage, would you have to have kind of multiple development plans depending on where you are?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, we're getting -- we got a great description and the surface in there, and a lot of through the vertical wells that had been drilled, a lot of it on the south end of the field been through the 800 hundred wells that we drilled in our Cana-Woodford Pr
componenttext: John, we're getting -- we got a great description and the surface in there, and a lot of through the vertical wells that had been drilled, a lot of it on the south end of the field been through the 800 hundred wells that we drilled in our Cana-Woodford Project, so we've got a great earth model that we built. We continue to refine that with the new data. I think the guys are very comfortable seeing 5 individual potential landing zones, 3 of those in the upper Meramec, 2 in the lower. I think [indiscernible] the teams are very confident with that. A lot of the data to date has been in what we call the Meramec 200 with some data in the Meramec 300. We think we had that well understood. The portions that, I think, us and industry are needing to appraise would be the very upper member of the Meramec, what we call the Meramec 100 and also the lowest member in the lower Meramec, which is the Meramec 500. And I think if you look at the pressure distribution across the footprint there, I think it's a gradational map, if you take an isobar map of that, it's nothing where you go from normal pressure to high pressure in a short distance. It's just a gradual trend from east to west. So I think that's being incorporated. You'll handle that with 3 string design in the Western side of the field on the shallow and east side of the field you will handle it with as few string designs on a cheaper activity on the east and the west, but it's nothing that, I think, some terms of the future development concept.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, I guess, geologically, if you look at the logs, we have a good handle on where each of these zones developed. That's not really the issue. The issue is more just how productive are each of these zones, what spacing can you do in each of these zo
componenttext: And John, I guess, geologically, if you look at the logs, we have a good handle on where each of these zones developed. That's not really the issue. The issue is more just how productive are each of these zones, what spacing can you do in each of these zones and conceptually, just broaden the discussion just a little bit to give you guys an idea what we're doing both in the STACK play and the Delaware Basin. We have so many zones of STACK play in there and in both of these areas we are conducting as many of these pilots as we can early on to assess how to properly develop these areas. It would be really easy right now to just skip the pilots, go in, drill everything on 4 wells per section in 1 zone, produce wells with great rates of returns and then wake up 3 years from now and you've blown through your inventory. That's not what we're doing. We are taking a much more thoughtful approach of understanding the productivity and the spacing in each of these zones so that we can develop each of these areas rather than what may be in this, and I'm talking very conceptually here what may be instead of 4 to 5 wells per section in a single zone when you could have many more wells per section, perhaps 20, 25, 30 wells per section after you understand the proper spacing of each of these -- in each of these intervals and how many of these you can develop within the same area. And so that's why we think it's appropriate at this time of lower activities really do the spacing tests and really understand because it has a huge impact on the ultimate resources going to be recovered in each of these plays and on the value associated with each of these plays. And so that's conceptually where we're trying to go with all these tests.

componenttext: If I could ask another question on the STACK. I'm curious after you get your asset sales done if it would also be an option to perhaps clean up some of the polls in your STACK -- in your STACK position. If you look at it, you guys are having great results there, and I have to imagine that some of those holes in your footprint have to be more valuable to you than they'd be to other people. So I guess, I'm asking what would be your appetite for that or is it an opportunity?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, I think it's -- that's the -- it's an opportunity. It's the way all of our technical teams working these core areas. So we're continuing to work with some of the offset operators in trying to core up where we can. We like the idea of having the a
componenttext: Charles, I think it's -- that's the -- it's an opportunity. It's the way all of our technical teams working these core areas. So we're continuing to work with some of the offset operators in trying to core up where we can. We like the idea of having the ability to drill longer laterals in all the areas that we work, so we're working with some of our offset partners on more of a holistic scale. We've got a great footprint there, and we've got a lot of running room, so it's not like we need to go out and acquire something that size and materiality, so we will continue to look for opportunities and core up, just like you mentioned.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Having said that, I want to make clear, Charles to you and everybody else, we're done with major acquisitions, so what we're talking about here is trying to core up our acreage in these existing plays where, as you say, the acreage immediately adjacent to
componenttext: Having said that, I want to make clear, Charles to you and everybody else, we're done with major acquisitions, so what we're talking about here is trying to core up our acreage in these existing plays where, as you say, the acreage immediately adjacent to our existing acreage may be more viable to us than others. But as far as major acquisitions, that's -- we're done with that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Got it. So that may take the form of trades you can lengthen lateral or something like that?

componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And if I could ask a question about the Leonard, which I don't think anyone has asked about yet, could you give us -- so you guys raised your type curve there, and you seem like you're more positive in that than you were maybe a few months ago. Ca
componenttext: Got it. And if I could ask a question about the Leonard, which I don't think anyone has asked about yet, could you give us -- so you guys raised your type curve there, and you seem like you're more positive in that than you were maybe a few months ago. Can you put that play in context with the other Delaware Basin plays I think my baseline is the Bone Spring is still the big dog out there both on Wolfcamp, but is the Leonard -- or the recent results of Leonard changing that?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, I think we reported now in 3 recent Leonard tests there. We've been extremely happy with that, and you can see this one that we reported on an operations report is outstanding. It's a 2-mile long lateral. It's in the We have about, I believe, abo
componenttext: Charles, I think we reported now in 3 recent Leonard tests there. We've been extremely happy with that, and you can see this one that we reported on an operations report is outstanding. It's a 2-mile long lateral. It's in the We have about, I believe, about 60,000 prospective acres in the Leonard play. So in terms of scale, it probably doesn't -- it's not the same magnitude. It's the Second Bone Springs but in terms of returns, it's every bit the same thing is the Second Bone Springs, and industry has done really good job of derisking the Leonard and the Wolfcamp around us. There's been some industry spacing tests that we've got the data onto that have helped us understand where we go from here. Our location camp that we commented on in the past, specifically for the Leonard, has really been directed towards the work that we see and what we call the Leonard B zones, but the A and the C prospected as well industry is actually working in the A and C we commented on had been in the B. So there's the potential to drive the location count up, both on the risk and unrisked basis. And again as we start thinking about our development plans to ramp up activity, the Leonard and the Second Bone Springs will be at the top of our list in terms of incremental well returns.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes in the line of Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the points you made that you're looking for to accelerate activity is comfort that you can secure supplies at rational costs and wanted to see if you could comment on that point and maybe to try to phrase the question to the degree you were thinkin
componenttext: One of the points you made that you're looking for to accelerate activity is comfort that you can secure supplies at rational costs and wanted to see if you could comment on that point and maybe to try to phrase the question to the degree you were thinking not about $1 billion budget but a $1.5 billion budget. Do you think you could execute on it that within what you would expect to achieve the returns are looking for. And what if it were a $2 billion budget, where, if anywhere, do you see any constraints?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, the lower the level of the incremental activity, the more confidence that we have that we can go out and execute at the -- very similar-type cost what exists today in this he probably doubled the activity, we most likely would be doing th
componenttext: Well, obviously, the lower the level of the incremental activity, the more confidence that we have that we can go out and execute at the -- very similar-type cost what exists today in this he probably doubled the activity, we most likely would be doing that in an environment where we're not the only one that's increasing activity. The rest of the industry would as well. And so the ability to do so from the same service cost, given the great reduction that we've seen in service companies in terms of their capability, availability of services and the availability of people, that becomes more challenged. I don't think any of us have an absolute answer as to what the implications of that are, but it's just something I can say with great confidence that we'd be assessing very carefully to make sure that we are producing still strong returns on these outstanding assets that we have. So I would anticipate if we're going to increase from $1 billion to $1.5 billion, there may be some increases associated with that probably much more manageable increases if we go up to $2 billion, we just have to see. But again, we are in as good a position as anybody in the industry. This is not a problem that's unique to Devon. This is a problem that's going to exist for everybody as prices recover in the service industry tends to recover and rehire people and retool their industry as well, we're all going to have to be assessing. So Darryl, you guys want to add more than that?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Daryl. I would say as we see it right now, the only area where we think there's a big upturn in activity that would cause us immediate concerns would be in the stimulation side of the business. We think there's adequate rigs that are availabl
componenttext: Yes, this is Daryl. I would say as we see it right now, the only area where we think there's a big upturn in activity that would cause us immediate concerns would be in the stimulation side of the business. We think there's adequate rigs that are available even though they are now STACK but not cannibalized, and we're talking the 1500 HP rigs. We think there is ample supply of those if we had to double -- for example, the industry would double their capital expenditure program. We think the tubulars are in really pretty good shape. While there has been some decrease in the amount of labor that's available, we think with modest increases that labor would be back over a period of time with about 6 months or 8 months. The stimulation area is a different animal right now. We think that's been kind of about 33% in terms of capacity. How long it is to get that 33%, that we don't know, but that will be the one area that initially what causes some concern on the cost side of the equation.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up is on -- around the STACK play. If we think about the changes in pressure regimes, the changes in over well life, the strong oil rates that you've shown from, at least an initial production rate basis and your legacy production, how should we
componenttext: My follow-up is on -- around the STACK play. If we think about the changes in pressure regimes, the changes in over well life, the strong oil rates that you've shown from, at least an initial production rate basis and your legacy production, how should we expect oil as a percent of the total mix to evolve as we go over the next 1, 2 -- 1 to 2 years?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, we'll tell you. we're watching that pretty close in the STACK play, and the Meramec is too young to specifically comment. I will highlight though that all of the fluid data that we have seen across the play has been to the optimistic side of our in
componenttext: Brian, we'll tell you. we're watching that pretty close in the STACK play, and the Meramec is too young to specifically comment. I will highlight though that all of the fluid data that we have seen across the play has been to the optimistic side of our initial interpretation. So all the new IPs that we're commenting on have full contents of 60% or greater. We characterize the life of the that we would see something in the order of about 40 -- roughly 40%, 45% oil. I'm not sure how this goes, but we will have to watch that. But so far, across the play, we've been highly encouraged, and I'll tell you that the one anomaly that you've seen has been really testing the far southwest portion of the Meramec there. We've seen oil content is much higher than what we see in the Cana-Woodford, which really we haven't talked much about our legacy acreage position in the Woodford, but that really sets that whole couple of hundred thousand acres of ours for prospective higher-yield production in the future. So really it's a positive story for the play and, specifically, for our footprint.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: David, is there a scenario under which you've done full Access or are we now at the point of crossing the Ts and dotting the Is on that deal? And is there some alternative whereby you would want to keep it?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you're never done until you're done. It's important to remember here that we're not -- it's not just as simple as perhaps the sale of an E&P asset. W3 actually entering into a long-term transportation agreement with the purchaser of this asset. And
componenttext: Well, you're never done until you're done. It's important to remember here that we're not -- it's not just as simple as perhaps the sale of an E&P asset. W3 actually entering into a long-term transportation agreement with the purchaser of this asset. And so given that we're establishing a relationship that's going to exist and we have to make sure that all the provisions in the contract work for both sides, so that's certainly something that we continue to work through. I can tell you, so far, that we're -- that we have been working with a party for quite some time, and we have had additional interest from some other parties as well, so we're very optimistic about where we stand in the overall process with this. It's just a lot of things you have to make sure you get right and also, we also have beyond the tariffs associated with Jackfish itself right now, we obviously have another project setting up there in the pipe project that we think is as high-quality as of the Jackfish project. this is a project we haven't sanctioned yet, but it's something that perhaps we consider strongly sanctioned in a more normalized commodity price environment. So that has some bearing on the associated tariffs on that on how that would be valued by the potential purchasers. So there's -- we're working through all those type things, but I can tell you, discussions are going extremely well on multiple fronts right now. And so you're never done until you're done, and it's obviously more than just dotting an I and crossing a T, I would say. Discussions around some pertinent issues in the contract with discussion so far been very, very positive, and we still think that it's very realistic to have it done by the end of the first half.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. A follow-up, which is separate. You mentioned as you entered your the leverage to Devon to oil prices. We're talking edge ex hedging and could you just go over your hedging strategy again, but given the way things have changed, are you intending may
componenttext: Good. A follow-up, which is separate. You mentioned as you entered your the leverage to Devon to oil prices. We're talking edge ex hedging and could you just go over your hedging strategy again, but given the way things have changed, are you intending maybe to carry more leverage to upside in oil prices now or are you going to be aiming for a similar level of protection as you had previously?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our overall strategy, Paul, is unchanged. We target, and it's not an absolute, but we target to be approximately 50% hedged by the point at which we enter any given year. And that's to help underpin the cash flows of the company to give us around th
componenttext: Well, our overall strategy, Paul, is unchanged. We target, and it's not an absolute, but we target to be approximately 50% hedged by the point at which we enter any given year. And that's to help underpin the cash flows of the company to give us around the capital spend that we can execute. Now we have -- in historical years, with the exception of coming into 2016 but many other years, we had a very, very successful hedging program. In 2015, as you know, we had over -- well over $2 billion of hedge gains. And so it's a program that's worked very well. We have added some very attractive Q2 gas hedges now. We have more than 30% of our expected production hedged at around 2 69 per MCF. And for the remainder of 2016, more than 25% of our oil production is protected primarily through collars with a weighted average ceiling price of 44 and a protected around $39. So we're going to add, on an opportunistic basis, throughout 2016 hedges where we see appropriate. I can also tell you that we have recently implemented a change over to a certain level of the hedging program, not the entire program but the base level of our hedging program on a more programmatic basis where we will enter in a level of hedges each quarter, and we'll probably hedge forward as far as 6 quarters and do it on a consistent programmatic basis, but will still have -- a good portion of the program that's going to be done more in an opportunistic basis as we have historically done a swell with the overall target to be around 50% hedged as we enter in any given year.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So basically you're attaining that 50% target. You just may change the trading strategy to be more ratable, I guess, to a given extent?
componenttext: Got it. So basically you're attaining that 50% target. You just may change the trading strategy to be more ratable, I guess, to a given extent?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, a little bit of change. Adding some programmatic and a little bit less on the opportunistic side and sensitivity those are ex hedges. Those are without hedges.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, a little bit of change. Adding some programmatic and a little bit less on the opportunistic side and sensitivity those are ex hedges. Those are without hedges.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. So just on a totally different topic, most of the questions have been asked and answered but what are you guys seeing on the NGL market guys have a lot of leverage to that product in the STACK, especially in the position and obviously theme i
componenttext: Okay. Great. So just on a totally different topic, most of the questions have been asked and answered but what are you guys seeing on the NGL market guys have a lot of leverage to that product in the STACK, especially in the position and obviously theme in propane prices have come back in you give us her macro thoughts of that overall product category? How you see things going into the second half of '16 into 17 with the potential demand increases?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Darryl, and you are exactly right. We have a large component of NGL is around 20%. Just some background, about 50% of that is ethane, between 25% and 30% is propane and the rest are butanes and natural gasoline. In the macro view, we continue
componenttext: Yes. This is Darryl, and you are exactly right. We have a large component of NGL is around 20%. Just some background, about 50% of that is ethane, between 25% and 30% is propane and the rest are butanes and natural gasoline. In the macro view, we continue to see that improve, although we still think in the short term over the next few months, we're going to see a greater amount of supply and demand. However, that demand is starting to increase as you bring on additional petrochemical plants in we continue to add export capacity by water. That has increased in the last 3 years from about 200,000 barrels a day of export capacity up to about pretty close to 1 million barrels a day. By the end of this year, early next year, we'll have added another 250,000 barrels a day export capacity on the water. About half of that is propane, butane gasolines. About half of that is ethane. So we're starting to see the export opportunities bringing supply in demand back into balance. So we think there's going to be more upward pressure on NGL products over time that we've seen the last year in a half.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of David Tameron from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of David Tameron from Wells Fargo.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One final one. On the the Barnett. If we were to see a ramp in gas prices, would you -- what would it take to accelerate activity there? Or would you set additional cash flow to and allocated to one of the crude plays?
componenttext: One final one. On the the Barnett. If we were to see a ramp in gas prices, would you -- what would it take to accelerate activity there? Or would you set additional cash flow to and allocated to one of the crude plays?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, we look at our entire portfolio. So when we generate incremental cash flow, we look at our entire portfolio, and I would suspect that the entire boat would be lifted. We like the Barnett. We think it's got low-risk opportunities. I think we commente
componenttext: Dave, we look at our entire portfolio. So when we generate incremental cash flow, we look at our entire portfolio, and I would suspect that the entire boat would be lifted. We like the Barnett. We think it's got low-risk opportunities. I think we commented in the past couple of calls that we really have derisked and completely understand the vertical refrac opportunity and, and we got about 30 of the horizontal refrac opportunities under our belt, and we think we've understood how to do that. We've got a real positive relationship with our EnLink partners there, so we would consider the Barnett. We also have some opportunities in Cana in the dryer portion or leaner portion of that property as well that would be just as commercial.

componenttext: Jamaal, we really focus on our work in the Second Bone Springs. We continue to find that Second Bone Spring another Leonard will be the top incremental returns that we can generate in our portfolio. We really like how our industry has derisked around us at Wolfcamp. And as you mentioned, it's come up across the Mexico border. We watch all that work. If you look at the -- if you consider the future development plan for the STACK column of opportunities, it will all hinge on what your outlook is for commodity prices going forward. And so, in kind of the mid-cycle to low cycle case you got a lot of work to do in Second Bone Spring, in the Leonard sands and as you move from the mid cycle to the high cycle, we've got a lot of opportunity in the Wolfcamp that will be incorporated to that. So we're encouraged by the Wolfcamp. We just don't find the commerciality to be as competitive in the Wolfcamp as we do on the Bone Springs in the Leonard.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: But that cycle back to the comments I made on just how many different zones we have here in the Delaware Basin as well as in the STACK play. And what we're trying to do is get an idea of what the productivity is the for each of these zones, what is the op
componenttext: But that cycle back to the comments I made on just how many different zones we have here in the Delaware Basin as well as in the STACK play. And what we're trying to do is get an idea of what the productivity is the for each of these zones, what is the optimum spacing in each of these zones, and we're being very thoughtful about our approach to this so that we are developing and fully developing a resource and the value associated with these versus the alternative of just drilling very quickly in 1 zone and 4 wells per sector are some fairly broad spacing and essentially developing, suboptimally developing the entire inventory that we have. We're not doing that. We are being very thoughtful, very careful because we are sitting truly world-class resources here in the hearts of some of the best plays, and you want to generate as much value as we can long term probably in resources.

And that's a combination of the great portfolio that Dave just mentioned, but it's also attributed to the competency of our technical team that we're extremely proud of those results.

componenttext:
Welcome to Devon Energy's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Howard Thill, Senior Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Melissa, and I'd like to wish everyone a good morning as well and welcome you to Devon Energy's third (sic) [ fourth ] quarter earnings conference call. I hope you had a chance to review our first quarter earnings release, which includes our fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Melissa, and I'd like to wish everyone a good morning as well and welcome you to Devon Energy's third (sic) [ fourth ] quarter earnings conference call. I hope you had a chance to review our first quarter earnings release, which includes our forward-looking guidance as well as our detailed ops report. 
Also on the call today are Dave Hager, President and CEO; Tony Vaughn, Chief Operating Officer; Tom Mitchell, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and a few other members of our senior management team.
Finally, I'll remind you that comments and answers to questions on this call will contain forecasts, plans, expectations and estimates, which are forward-looking statements under U.S. securities law. These comments and answers are subject to a number of assumptions, risks and uncertainties, many of which are beyond our control. These statements are not guarantees of future performance and actual results may differ materially. For a review of risk factors relating to these statements, please see our Form 10-K.
With that, I will turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard, and welcome, everyone. There's no question that low commodity prices in the first quarter led to tough conditions for Devon in the industry. However, we responded to these challenges by delivering another outstanding operating performan
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard, and welcome, everyone. There's no question that low commodity prices in the first quarter led to tough conditions for Devon in the industry. However, we responded to these challenges by delivering another outstanding operating performance as we continue to take the appropriate steps to deliver significant cost reductions and accelerate efficiency gains across our portfolio. These successful efforts resulted in us delivering production at the high end of our guidance, driving down both operating costs and G&A down more than 20% over year and increasing our liquidity to $4.6 billion.
This strong execution has improved our full year 2016 outlook, with us raising our 2016 production targets by 3%, importantly, without any incremental capital requirements. Additionally, our cost-saving initiatives are well on their way to preserve more than $1 billion of cash flow during the year, and commodity prices are running above our base budgeting expectations.
Even with a meaningful increase in commodity prices from first quarter lows, our disciplined approach to this environment remains unchanged. Our top priority is to protect our balance sheet strength by balancing spending requirements with cash flow, and we see no compelling reason to accelerate production at these improved yet still low pricing points.
As I touched on earlier, our 2016 E&P capital program remains unchanged, and the activity, we will deploy, is designed to maximize cash flow generation and maintain operational continuity in our top resource plays.
For us to consider adding additional activity, we would need to make additional progress on our asset sales, have the ability to hedge at sustainably higher commodity prices and have comfort that we can secure services and supplies at rational costs. When these conditions are met, we have no shortage of attractive investment opportunities across our resource-rich portfolio. 
Our core assets are concentrated in North America's best basins, and we are getting the most out of these assets with best-in-class execution that has consistently exceeded peer results through higher production rates, lower capital cost and reduced operating expenses. While there are several verticals to consider when allocating capital, it is likely that we would initially accelerate activity with our top 2 franchise assets, the STACK and Delaware Basin. Between these 2 world-class resource plays, we have access to over 1 million net acres and thousands of low-risk development opportunities that are delivering the rates of return to rank among the very top of our asset portfolio. 
Another strategic imperative for Devon in 2016 is the work we are doing to improve our financial strength through the monetization of $2 billion to $3 billion of noncore assets. In April, we took an important step towards that goal, with the announced sale of our Mississippian assets in Northern Oklahoma for $200 million. The data rooms for our remaining noncore upstream assets have been open since early March, and bids are expected by the end of the second quarter. The interest in our Midland, East Texas and Granite Wash asset packages had been quite strong, and we have great confidence in our ability to sell these assets at attractive prices in 2016. 
In Canada, we're also making progress toward the sale of our 50% interest in Access Pipeline. Negotiations are ongoing with discussions centered on contract-related considerations. Given the multi-decade lifespan of heavy oil assets, it is important that we judiciously work through these contractual details to ensure both parties are comfortable with those long-term relationship.
Overall, we are encouraged by the direction of these conversations, and we still expect to announce a transaction in the first half of this year.
Before we move to Q&A, I want to summarize a few key messages from today's call. Even with the recent uptick in pricing, our top priority remains unchanged. To maintain a strong balance sheet. We are committed to balancing capital requirements with cash flow and enhancing our financial strengths by utilizing upstream asset sale proceeds to reduce debt.
We are laser focused on the control -- controllable aspects of our business. This is evidenced by our outstanding operational performance in the first quarter and our continued cost control efforts. We have taken aggressive actions to position Devon not only to weather this downturn but to be positioned to take advantage of our world-class resource plays when market conditions incentivize higher activity levels. And as commodity prices recover, Devon has significant leverage to rising oil, natural gas and NGL prices. For every $1 increase in realized price on a BOE basis, Devon generates more than $200 million of incremental cash flow annually. Additionally, this $1 increase in realized price proportionally expands Devon's margins more than nearly every large producer in North America. Couple this with the catalyst-risk deleveraging of the balance sheet in the asset sales and upside from further delineation of the STACK play, Devon is extremely well positioned for differential stock price performance.
With that, I will turn the call back to Howard for Q&A.

componenttext: I just wanted to start with the STACK update. You've said that the results are bigger, they're oilier and the downspacing is more interesting. But obviously, you're capital constrained in terms of the amount of cash that you can put there until perhaps the disposals are executed. So maybe just give us a sense of the type of news flow that you might be able to generate in terms of those 3 aspects, particularly EURs and downspacing over the course of this year.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Tony Vaughn is going to take a stab at this Ed.
componenttext: I think Tony Vaughn is going to take a stab at this Ed.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, as we continue to work our footprint in the STACK play, we're overwhelmingly -- have positive feel about the results that we see. I think in the operating report that we published last night continues to show that our results are above type curve expe
componenttext: Ed, as we continue to work our footprint in the STACK play, we're overwhelmingly -- have positive feel about the results that we see. I think in the operating report that we published last night continues to show that our results are above type curve expectations. The interesting thing about this was a lot of the rock and fluid and pressure variability across the play. In fact, the whole play is working from the far northeast to the southwest really well, but there's a lot of different characteristics of the play that are changing across that footprint. And if you look at the results that we've had just in Devon footprint, our range of results have been very tight. Our P10 to P90 ratio is about 2.4, which is very indicative of a lower risk of element-type play. So I think as we go forward, we'll continue to see optimization of our completion designs. We're changing the fluids. We're changing the profit loads. We're changing the number of stages and tightening up on the perf cluster spacing, just like a lot of people in the industry are doing. So that will continue to optimize our results. We're also engaged in about 6 different pilots across our footprint, and 4 of those are being operated by Devon. We already have the production data coming at us on 2 of those pilots that we commented on in the operations report. It's early, but the early indications are on a fairly conservative spacing on a single zone of 5 wells per section, which we're testing in the Alma. We didn't see interference on the frac work that we were doing. All the well rates are coming in to the type curve, if not better. We published a little bit of information, early information, on the Born Free test, which was a staggered-type test in the Meramec, and very positive there that we did not see the energy across from one interval to the next. And ultimately, that would be spaced at about 6 wells per common zone, potentially 13 and the 2 that we're testing there. We also had 2 additional pilots that will test 7 and 8 wells per section in a common interval. So I think as the data flow comes in throughout the year, we'll get more information about spacing. We're participating in some other pilots from some of our nonoperated partners there. They'll have the information coming in. So really for the second half of '16, I think that spacing question will start being a lot more clear. I think you'll continue to see our performance improve as we optimize the work that we do. But right now, we're extremely pleased. And as you know, if you look at the location camp there, it's just very deep for Devon, and this will be a driver for Devon's future for a long time.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And to give you an idea, we are seeing quarter-over-quarter oil decline here from our core oil of about 25,000 barrels a day, but I think the most important thing to understand is that when you look out for the second half of the year, we expect our
componenttext: Yes. And to give you an idea, we are seeing quarter-over-quarter oil decline here from our core oil of about 25,000 barrels a day, but I think the most important thing to understand is that when you look out for the second half of the year, we expect our oil production to be flat to slightly higher than the Q2 production as our completion activity resumes in the Eagle Ford and our Jackfish 2 facility ramps up to nameplate capacity. So it is a -- and obviously overall, we raised our production guidance. And so overall, I'd say a very positive story. We may be seeing a slightly higher decline in Q2 than some of you may have expected, just mainly because we're such high-rate wells that we delivered, particularly in the Eagle Ford in the last half of 2015 and with the lack of completion activity here earlier in the year as the completion crews left the field. But overall, it's a very positive story. I think it may just surprise a couple of people that we're taking it in the second quarter, but the good news is as commodity prices improve, hopefully in the second half of the year, given that we raised our overall guidance we'll be producing more than what was originally anticipated second half when prices will be higher. So Tony, you want to add some more detail to that?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just -- I think you said it well, Dave. Subash, if you go from Q1 to Q2, Dave commented at our total decline on oil will be about 25,000 barrels of oil per day. We actually have a turnaround schedule for Jackfish 2 in the second quarter, which will a
componenttext: Yes. Just -- I think you said it well, Dave. Subash, if you go from Q1 to Q2, Dave commented at our total decline on oil will be about 25,000 barrels of oil per day. We actually have a turnaround schedule for Jackfish 2 in the second quarter, which will account for about 10,000 BOEs or BOs per day, but if you look at the Delaware Basin and the STACK position on oil production, they're essentially flat over the last portion of the year, second half of the year. So as Dave mentioned, it's a positive story for the company. I think the -- if you look and specifically talk about the Eagle Ford, you'll notice that we had outstanding results in the second half of 2014, and that carried into Q1 of 2015 -- second half of 2015 that carried into this first quarter of 2016 and as you go back and look at that pace of activity was about 50 to 55 IDs per quarter. The number of the wells we brought on in Q1 of '16 was only 22, and that happened to be early in the quarter. So we ramped down the activity along with working -- that work with a partner there. So the Eagle Ford has taken a larger -- projected to take a larger drop from Q1 of '16 to Q2 of '16. But again, as we bring -- we've taken a completion holiday there as we bring completion units back into the field in the latter part of Q2. We'll see that production stabilize from Q2 through Q4 in the Eagle Ford. Month-to-month is going to be pretty cyclically, just depending on the pace of new wells that we bring on.

componenttext: In the Eagle Ford, as I mentioned, we were completing about 50 to 55 wells per quarter, and Q1 is about 22, and we'll take a holiday through Q2 of no new wells brought on in Q2, but then we'll see about -- roughly speaking, about 35 and about 15 in Q3 and Q4. So it's really lumpy. We've got 2 drilling rigs. We've got 2 drilling rigs working in the field. And as we build up a little bit of inventory there, we will tend to work that down with 1 to 1.5 frac crews and maintain a fairly flat DUC inventory from beginning of the year to the end of the year, just be a little bit lumpy from month-to-month.

componenttext: Well, I think if you look at it, our Q4 to Q4 decline just on the Eagle Ford, just on oil was roughly about 30%. That doesn't include a lot of new IDs in the second half of the year. Just be a little bit more than that. I think we published in the past that our first year decline on Eagle Ford wells is very high. It's above 50% per year, first and second year declines. So as I mentioned, we had an aggressive activity schedule through 2015 and without continuing that pace of activity, we're just seeing a lot of fairly young immature wells in the high portion of their decline come on right now, and we're not having the new IDs to maintain that total flow rate.
