headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up is as you highlighted on the '17 guidance or preliminary '17 guidance, and I know it's not formalized at this point, but what on oil production would you be able to hold year-end '17 or Q4 -- Q4 '16 oil production flat and then grow
componenttext: And then my follow-up is as you highlighted on the '17 guidance or preliminary '17 guidance, and I know it's not formalized at this point, but what on oil production would you be able to hold year-end '17 or Q4 -- Q4 '16 oil production flat and then grow from there? I'm trying to get a sense of what the -- if you spent that $1.6 billion, what the oil production profile would look like? Or would it continue to decline from the Q4 '16 levels until the middle part of next year and start to come back up.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We would essentially stabilize production at the Q4 levels of Q4 '16 levels. And then later in the year, it would start inclining, later in '17.
componenttext: No. We would essentially stabilize production at the Q4 levels of Q4 '16 levels. And then later in the year, it would start inclining, later in '17.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that'd be stabilizing oil production in Q4 levels but not total production?
componenttext: And that'd be stabilizing oil production in Q4 levels but not total production?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct. That is oil production. As Howard said, we would stabilize the BOEs around mid-year 2017. So we'd still experience some decline. And where we're not investing in gas particularly and to a lesser degree, the NGLs, and then it will be stabil
componenttext: That's correct. That is oil production. As Howard said, we would stabilize the BOEs around mid-year 2017. So we'd still experience some decline. And where we're not investing in gas particularly and to a lesser degree, the NGLs, and then it will be stabilized by mid-year 17 and start an incline on the BOEs as well at the back half of '17. We'll be exiting at a significantly higher rate at mid-year.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Aaron from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Aaron from JPMorgan.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, Dave, is to ask you about the maintenance CapEx number. You previously said about a $2 billion number to keep production flat on the BOE basis, and now you're signaling $1.6 billion. I was wondering if you could maybe highlight what's d
componenttext: My first question, Dave, is to ask you about the maintenance CapEx number. You previously said about a $2 billion number to keep production flat on the BOE basis, and now you're signaling $1.6 billion. I was wondering if you could maybe highlight what's driven that pretty meaningful reduction in maintenance CapEx as we think about 2017.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question on that, Aaron. We're continuing to drive efficiencies in our business, internal efficiencies. We talked about the 40% reduction in drilling and completion costs. About 50%, 50-50 between lower service cost and internal efficiencies. I can
componenttext: Great question on that, Aaron. We're continuing to drive efficiencies in our business, internal efficiencies. We talked about the 40% reduction in drilling and completion costs. About 50%, 50-50 between lower service cost and internal efficiencies. I can tell you, as we sit here today, were finding even more internal efficiencies that are continuing to drive the maintenance capital lower. And so we -- as well as the fact that we're exceeding the type curve on wells. And so if you combine the cost savings, we're still finding with the fact that our wells, we're in the best parts of the best plays and exceeding our expectations. So that's continuing to drive the maintenance capital down.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up, Dave, is on a pro forma basis, $4.6 billion in cash. It's sounds like from the ops report, you'll use roughly $2 billion or so for debt reduction and $1 billion of the $3.2 billion -- $1 billion in proceeds could be reinvesting. Would yo
componenttext: And my follow-up, Dave, is on a pro forma basis, $4.6 billion in cash. It's sounds like from the ops report, you'll use roughly $2 billion or so for debt reduction and $1 billion of the $3.2 billion -- $1 billion in proceeds could be reinvesting. Would you feel comfortable, for example, in '17, if you feel good about oil in the low to mid-50s of outspending by $1 billion or so to take some of these proceeds just given how you have so much cash on the balance sheet.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we do think and we do have the other cash on the balance sheet from essentially the equity offering. We do feel that it's very important to maintain our investment grade rating. And probably longer term, we'd still look at using some of those procee
componenttext: Well, we do think and we do have the other cash on the balance sheet from essentially the equity offering. We do feel that it's very important to maintain our investment grade rating. And probably longer term, we'd still look at using some of those proceeds to pay down debt. But so we are at this point thinking that we want to live within cash flow. And so if we start we said we'd start adding back activity if we had confidence prices somewhere around 50. We have added back activity. We've added back some. We plan to add more. If we do see prices sustain over 50, and gas prices actually the recovering gas has helped out significantly as well with our cash flow. If we see gas prices sustain near to levels where they are now, we may be able to add a little bit more activity in '17, but that would be living within cash flow though. So we don't see a significant cash flow outspend.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two type curve questions, if I may. Obviously, let's start with the Bone Springs. You talked about some of the wells, 50% ahead [indiscernible] at 50% ahead we just had Occi showing that there 120 [ph] from memory double on all the designs. So maybe just
componenttext: Two type curve questions, if I may. Obviously, let's start with the Bone Springs. You talked about some of the wells, 50% ahead [indiscernible] at 50% ahead we just had Occi showing that there 120 [ph] from memory double on all the designs. So maybe just talk through what constrained on raising the overall type curve. It might be across the inventory slowdown spacing tests et cetera. And then I have a question on STACK.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tony Vaughn here. And I think you hit it right. The activity and the number of new completions that we have brought on of later have been fairly small, but we're extremely pleased with performance that we have, especially in the Leonard. Not only
componenttext: This is Tony Vaughn here. And I think you hit it right. The activity and the number of new completions that we have brought on of later have been fairly small, but we're extremely pleased with performance that we have, especially in the Leonard. Not only all the well results that we're making public and the letter well above our type curve industry around us are really experiencing the same things. So we'll make these type curve adjustments both here and in STACK, just as we get a little more comfortable with that and get a few more reps behind us. But really, the operational performance of our new activity in both the Delaware and the STACK are well above our expectations on our current type curves.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then on the STACK what was the average lateral length of the Q2 results? Because obviously again, do get exceeding type curve if you go to longer laterals there should we should be more capital efficient.
componenttext: Okay. Then on the STACK what was the average lateral length of the Q2 results? Because obviously again, do get exceeding type curve if you go to longer laterals there should we should be more capital efficient.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're exactly right. Historically, the industry has -- we've got about 200 wells in the STACK play to date. And there's about 60% of those that are the long laterals. On our well count, Ed, we have just under 50 wells that we operate. And we have
componenttext: I think you're exactly right. Historically, the industry has -- we've got about 200 wells in the STACK play to date. And there's about 60% of those that are the long laterals. On our well count, Ed, we have just under 50 wells that we operate. And we have about just under 50% of those are long laterals. Difficult to better risk average on the full population of that, but it's probably somewhere around 6,000, 6,500 feet. But I'll tell you, a lot of the early wells that were drilled were in the appraisal mindset. They're also in the lease-saving mindset. And now that we're getting a lot of that information behind us being more comfortable with the subsurface, I think Devon is really looking forward to optimizing our completions and our lateral and really that we're going forward is to use as many of the longer laterals as possible.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. A lot of the 10,000 footers we drilled here is not as productive as we anticipate 10,000 foot laterals to be in the future. Some of those wells are drilled by Felix without the benefits of 3D and we have early completion designs not with the feel on
componenttext: Yes. A lot of the 10,000 footers we drilled here is not as productive as we anticipate 10,000 foot laterals to be in the future. Some of those wells are drilled by Felix without the benefits of 3D and we have early completion designs not with the feel on the design so even though there were some 10,000 footers in the mix, they were not of the quality we would anticipate from a go-forward basis.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Kessel from Scotia Howard Weil.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Kessel from Scotia Howard Weil.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just very quickly, looking at 2017, you outlined the $1.6 billion [indiscernible] if you will, on spending, but what sort of obligations do you have for spending above that 1.6? Just trying to think about how much of that could go up or down as you look t
componenttext: Just very quickly, looking at 2017, you outlined the $1.6 billion [indiscernible] if you will, on spending, but what sort of obligations do you have for spending above that 1.6? Just trying to think about how much of that could go up or down as you look to stay within cash flow.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're totally flexible on that, Pete. We don't have any obligations. I think that's one of the great attributes of Devon. We have essentially all of our acreage help our production. We have a minor amount in the Felix acquisition where we need to ha
componenttext: Well, we're totally flexible on that, Pete. We don't have any obligations. I think that's one of the great attributes of Devon. We have essentially all of our acreage help our production. We have a minor amount in the Felix acquisition where we need to have some activity. We're going to have way more activity that is required get all our acreage held by production. We don't have any, obviously, long-term projects going on in the company. So we are totally flexible as cash flow presents itself as to ramping up activity. And of course, we don't like to think about it as much. But if prices do retreat, we have flexibility to decrease activity as well. So it is strictly driven by we have the projects we have is good the projects. We think as anybody in the industry were some of the best plays. It's just a matter of cash flow is available to putting projects.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing you guys have done a great job in the past of is kind of STACK ranking your given plays here. As the STACK has continued to look extremely good, the Delaware Basin looks extremely good, would you mind just reminding us where they all stand in or
componenttext: One thing you guys have done a great job in the past of is kind of STACK ranking your given plays here. As the STACK has continued to look extremely good, the Delaware Basin looks extremely good, would you mind just reminding us where they all stand in order of preference? And maybe ultimately, where the coming to the mix looking to 2017 as you go to have a very big position there but they little activity.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pete, nothing's really changed there. If you look at the returns on a strip basis, we really haven't commented on the absolute number of that. But the the returns that we see in the Delaware, the Eagle Ford and the STACK play are all comparable to each ot
componenttext: Pete, nothing's really changed there. If you look at the returns on a strip basis, we really haven't commented on the absolute number of that. But the the returns that we see in the Delaware, the Eagle Ford and the STACK play are all comparable to each other. If you look at the sensitivity to the number of locations that we have available, that does change. And so if you look we've been some of the best return work we been there, but the inventory is not as deep and as robust as it is in the Delaware and the STACK play. Really, all 4 of those plays are ones that we got the flexibility and ability to drive value for, which really presents an opportunity for us, I think, to prosecute and understand the subsurface even better while still getting a lot of meaningful and competitive returns.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of the 4, Pete, the Powder Basin is the most sensitive to oil prices because it's about 90% light oil. And so when we are early in the year, after we did the acquisition with prices down mid-30s or so, it wasn't competing for capital. But as we get back o
componenttext: Of the 4, Pete, the Powder Basin is the most sensitive to oil prices because it's about 90% light oil. And so when we are early in the year, after we did the acquisition with prices down mid-30s or so, it wasn't competing for capital. But as we get back over $50 a barrel, the economics on that improved dramatically because of high oil cuts there. And so that's what puts it into puts us back up in one of the top-tier plays, we get a the $50-plus environment. Not as deep an inventory but still good economics at the well level.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I apologize if I'm belaboring this point a bit, but I'd like to just see if you could distill some of the comments you made on this call. The $1.6 billion number, that was really useful from what you could do. But I'd like to understand or make sure I und
componenttext: I apologize if I'm belaboring this point a bit, but I'd like to just see if you could distill some of the comments you made on this call. The $1.6 billion number, that was really useful from what you could do. But I'd like to understand or make sure I understand what really is driving your appetite for what you actually choose to do. So I think I heard you say you're going to drop a spend within cash flow regardless of where the client prices go. But is there a scenario where you just wouldn't have the appetite to drill more in the case where you wouldn't have an appetite to buy rates if prices went down?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we look at -- let me try to clarify. It's really 2 things that we look at when we determine our capital allocation and the levels of capital. One would be the returns on at the project level, and so we compare projects across the entire company, tak
componenttext: Well, we look at -- let me try to clarify. It's really 2 things that we look at when we determine our capital allocation and the levels of capital. One would be the returns on at the project level, and so we compare projects across the entire company, take into account any sort of operational considerations, any sort of limitations, and then we fund the highest-return projects across of the company. We do that to the extent that we can live within cash flow. And so that's the second step of the process is what is our cash flow going to be. And you said the $1.6 billion is -- and again, prices are moving around everyday so you can't rerun of these numbers every day and slightly different answer, but it's approximately the level at which we can live within cash flow in 2017 at the current strip and fund the top-tier projects that we have identified with the 9 rigs that we could be adding by the end of the year. And we plan to add up to that 9-rig level unless we see a significant change in commodity prices between now and then.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right That's helpful, Dave. And I imagine these moves in the commodity prices are even more fun for you guys than they offer us. If I could ask a question on the Delaware Basin, you guys introduced this total reservoir access concept, is that -- let's kne
componenttext: Right That's helpful, Dave. And I imagine these moves in the commodity prices are even more fun for you guys than they offer us. If I could ask a question on the Delaware Basin, you guys introduced this total reservoir access concept, is that -- let's knew this quarter but one of the things that challenged particularly understanding a part of the Delaware Basin has been extending the standard length of that 5,000-foot laterals up to 10,000-foot laterals. Is that a correct perception that it's harder in other places to get to the 10,000-foot laterals? And does that interact or play some part in your TRACK concept?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, about 1/3 of our position or our footprint in the Delaware will accommodate the long laterals. It's a little bit tougher to put those together as you move north in Lea and Eddy County footprint in the southern portion of this where this new super
componenttext: Charles, about 1/3 of our position or our footprint in the Delaware will accommodate the long laterals. It's a little bit tougher to put those together as you move north in Lea and Eddy County footprint in the southern portion of this where this new super pattern track concept would be utilized in 2017. It's a little easier to do that. And so I think what we're trying to describe here as a concept when you start thinking about having all the STACK pace that we have both here and the STACK asset in Oklahoma, there's going to be a more creative and efficient way to develop our service facilities. And so we're walking into this with this concept. It provides us a lot of flexibility as we grow. It also allows us to have flexibility as the business environment changes. But for the most part, we're going to for the permitting process to achieve approval for really really more of a fill development concept and passed that will be left to get individual APDs by well as we choose to develop that. So you're right about our footprint as a little bit less contiguous in the north interval position in the southwest of Lea and Eddy is it should be very well suited for the concept.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing that's so great about it, too, Charles, and we showed it on the maps we put that into our investor presentation particularly the southern parts of Lea and Eddy counties, we just have so many perspective zones. We said we have we 9 pers
componenttext: And the other thing that's so great about it, too, Charles, and we showed it on the maps we put that into our investor presentation particularly the southern parts of Lea and Eddy counties, we just have so many perspective zones. We said we have we 9 perspective zones between the Delaware Sands, the Bone Spring, Leonard and the Wolfcamp. And so we are still doing appraisal work, determine how wells perception in an individual zone and how many of these zones and a vertical sands also can be developed in any one geographic location. But the numbers you start seeing start boggling the mind sometimes I'd say how many wells you can have individual sections. We're hesitant to put the numbers up there until we finish more appraisal work, but there could be just a tremendous amount of resource we're developing and each section out there, and that's what's necessitated this super pad concept to figure out. It's great to have the resource, but how are you actually going to develop that resource, and that's what's put that into place a really exciting future both in the Delaware Basin and in the STACK play because of this.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Douglas from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: Well, I think that might be a little bit lower for you where I don't want to get in. I guess, Doug, I appreciate your question, and I'm struggling little bit to get into the details of that right now.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Previously, you said $40 is your CapEx [indiscernible] this year, but that included the contribution from Access of about $800 [ph] million. So your sensitivity is about 80 million per dollar and previously you said that you would hold flat at about $60.
componenttext: Previously, you said $40 is your CapEx [indiscernible] this year, but that included the contribution from Access of about $800 [ph] million. So your sensitivity is about 80 million per dollar and previously you said that you would hold flat at about $60. So when I look through all those numbers it kind of implies $1.6 billion is some in the mid to high 40s.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the big thing that's changed, off the top of my head, here, Doug is that gas prices have gone up significantly. And so that has provided significant incremental cash flow to us as well as some improvement on the NGL side as well. So it's prob
componenttext: Yes, I think the big thing that's changed, off the top of my head, here, Doug is that gas prices have gone up significantly. And so that has provided significant incremental cash flow to us as well as some improvement on the NGL side as well. So it's probably less a product of oil prices -- the breakeven maintenance capital on oil prices going down as it is the fact that our assumptions are around what gas prices we can achieve along with the oil has allowed higher cash flow to allow us to keep production flat.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes a ton of sense. My follow-up is the STACK and the move to 10,000-foot wells. Obviously, you partnered with Continental and a bunch of those wells. What do you think the costs can deliver these wells at? And I guess, this is a related question,
componenttext: That makes a ton of sense. My follow-up is the STACK and the move to 10,000-foot wells. Obviously, you partnered with Continental and a bunch of those wells. What do you think the costs can deliver these wells at? And I guess, this is a related question, what's holding you back from moving up your type curve given what you're seeing from others in the play?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're finding that the well cost varies quite dramatically from the shallow eastern portion of the field all the way across to the southwest portion of where Continental is, as you mentioned. We're finding that we can drill the wells for about $5.5 millio
componenttext: We're finding that the well cost varies quite dramatically from the shallow eastern portion of the field all the way across to the southwest portion of where Continental is, as you mentioned. We're finding that we can drill the wells for about $5.5 million per well with the 2-string design on the eastern half of the field. We go into that the third string as you go past the dividing line that separates the east from the west add third [ph] that's about $1 million. And then as we go from a 5,000-foot lateral up to a 10,000-foot lateral, that's about $1 million to $1.5 million incremental on top of that. So that's -- it might give you a range in the cost as we work across that field. We continue to see positive results on our well performance from the oily section in the northeast to a little bit the gas more volatile as you move into the central portion of the field. But overall, Doug, when you put all of the attributes together we still believe that you're in the heart of the high-return portion of the field. We think all those attributes really lead to what will be the most commercial development going forward for all the competitors there.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the type curve, is it just more on the matter results?
componenttext: And on the type curve, is it just more on the matter results?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is. From an operational perspective, it's nice to see almost -- virtually, every well result that we have is not in that type curve. It's above -- well above the type curve. So we're going to modify that with performance but we have been pleasantly ple
componenttext: It is. From an operational perspective, it's nice to see almost -- virtually, every well result that we have is not in that type curve. It's above -- well above the type curve. So we're going to modify that with performance but we have been pleasantly pleased one of the things I wanted to point out on the STACK play, in general, that while there's a lot of variables that go into the subsurface description of this from depth, from pressure to changing fluid compositions to changing thickness by zone, a lot of variables are going to that but I forgot to tell you that the predictability of the results is very narrow. And we still believe the P10 to P90 range in the 90-day IP is about 2.4, which is extremely tight for a fairly young play. And so while there's a lot of variables that are changing out there, we think the predictability of the play is really unusually good in comparison to a lot of the resource plays that we've been involved in.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if I could ask a question on the STACK. Obviously, you highlighted the great performance in the well results you've had in addition to your massive acreage position. You are producing around 90,000 a day there. But when you step back and l
componenttext: I was wondering if I could ask a question on the STACK. Obviously, you highlighted the great performance in the well results you've had in addition to your massive acreage position. You are producing around 90,000 a day there. But when you step back and look at it -- and I'm assuming kind of generalized some of the numbers, but where do you think that ultimately could grow to? How big is the price here on your acreage there?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I think when we did the acquisition analysis, we had a little bit of a narrative that we were trying to visualize what that would look like us well. And we think with our position, and Woodford continues to expand, the well performance gets larger.
componenttext: Scott, I think when we did the acquisition analysis, we had a little bit of a narrative that we were trying to visualize what that would look like us well. And we think with our position, and Woodford continues to expand, the well performance gets larger. We're seeing more resource potential and the Meramec and the Osage. But also within the underneath the Meramec, we're seeing more potential with the Woodford. We believe we can probably push up north of 150,000 towards 200,000 BOEs per day as all of these zones continue to be derisked and incorporated into our development plans.  Of course, a lot of that Scott is really contingent on the commodity price environment that we're in and the pace of activity that we could prosecute that large resource base.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great color. And my follow-up is in the Eagle Ford. Obviously getting a lot of attention right now. I'm curious on where you could fit into your long-term portfolio, especially considering your operating partner appears to be deemphasizing on
componenttext: Okay. That's great color. And my follow-up is in the Eagle Ford. Obviously getting a lot of attention right now. I'm curious on where you could fit into your long-term portfolio, especially considering your operating partner appears to be deemphasizing onshore development at this point. How do you look at that? And If I could add a question to that, if your partner decided, let's say, to exit the Eagle Ford, what would your reaction be? What would Devon do?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I appreciate the question, Scott. I don't think that's probably appropriate for us to comment on hypothetical situations there. But the Eagle Ford, we've had some tremendous results. And again, we have a position there is really we want to do in all
componenttext: Well, I appreciate the question, Scott. I don't think that's probably appropriate for us to comment on hypothetical situations there. But the Eagle Ford, we've had some tremendous results. And again, we have a position there is really we want to do in all of our plays. It's one of the best plays in onshore North America. And if you look at the historical well results that we delivered out there, we have a large proportion of the best wells that have been drilled in the play. So we certainly have lots of position. Right now, we're just in a position where given that capital constraints that we had earlier in the year, ourselves and our partner, that we decreased drilling activity significantly. And along with that and the completion activity, we thought we are going to resume completion activity here in Q3. It's been pushed back. It looks like about 1 quarter now. So that's, I guess, a very short-term challenge. But frankly, it's going to help us a little bit in 2017 as some of those volumes pushed out of '16 into '17, so I think it's a significant event towards the long-term strategy of the Eagle Ford. We still see some high rate or high return-type opportunities in Eagle Ford. We are maturing our way through the best part of the inventory right now. But we're also seeing some upside from the diamond pattern that we describe in the operations report really staggered laterals in the lower Eagle Ford along with the upside in the operating Eagle Ford. So we still thickness of upside it exists to the resource out there albeit it doesn't have -- and we knew it at the time the acquisition just didn't have the Reading room that we see now in the Delaware in the STACK play. So we still like it very much, and we see how things develop beyond that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: My first question is a follow-up on the Meramec. Given your understanding and the success of the pad, what do you guys think is the ultimate limits here for development spacing? And what size pilot program will need to change your development assumptions off of 4, and should we expect that by 4Q results, given your industry pilots?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We commented that we are testing up to 8 wells per section in a single interval. We're getting a lot of good data from the pilots in now. So you've seen the results in the which gave us confidence that we have the ability to prosecute the zones on top of
componenttext: We commented that we are testing up to 8 wells per section in a single interval. We're getting a lot of good data from the pilots in now. So you've seen the results in the which gave us confidence that we have the ability to prosecute the zones on top of each other with no problem. The [indiscernible] spacing test helped us understand that 5 wells per section is not dense enough even in today's commodity price environment. We're getting some information in right now on the which is a 7 wells per section and we'll give you a little but more field for that. One of the pilots that we got some early data on we call the skipper pilot, and that was in an 8-well per section or almost an 8-well per section. And there, we're highly encouraged that 8 wells will work the right commodity price environment. And it probably will work as technology continues to improve and we can improve our frac or completion designs and maintain more a complex near-wellbore frac. So the 4 that we initially commented on when we did the acquisition is liked. And we think we're at least the 6 and not heading north of that right now. So that information the pilots are coming in. We'll have about another 3 pilots showing us some information in Q3 early in the first quarter of '17 but we're starting to get comfortable with the areas were going to go into full development on. And again, we'll use this track concept in the STACK development as well. And we think will have the ability to prosecute up roughly 27 wells in a section if -- as all these zones continue to work. So play's working really well, and pilot data is all positive and leading us towards our development plan.

componenttext: Well, we like our position. As we said, our transformation is complete. We like our portfolio the way it looks right now. We are always flipping expression all this is we like all our assets but we certainly are not in love with any of them. So we certainly are we like where we are with everything we have no current plans to do anything with the Barnett or any of our other assets, but that's not the say we aren't always thinking at the same time but there's some way we can improve our results as a company, I can tell you there's nothing right now that says we're going to divest, no current plans to invest everything in the Barnett.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: While you're listening Evan, take a look at your writeup this morning, just wanted to make sure clarify a couple of things in there. But one is the -- I think you heard me make some comments there about the predictability of our results in STACK. And so w
componenttext: While you're listening Evan, take a look at your writeup this morning, just wanted to make sure clarify a couple of things in there. But one is the -- I think you heard me make some comments there about the predictability of our results in STACK. And so while it's not going to be uniform across the play it is extremely predictable. And again, there is a note about the debate regarding our acreage position and whether or not it falls in the overpressure window. And I think you may have been I think the industry may have been led to believe there's a north-south line to the east of that, it's under pressure; to the west of that, it's overpressure. That's not the case. As we do work to subsurface data understanding and you look at our map, you can clearly see that the far northeast is normal pressure but it typically goes into about 0.5-psi per foot and gradually moves into about 0.7, 0.7-psi per foot to the southwest. So just want to clear up our mind there's no debate about whether or not we're in the overpressure window or not.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what Tony is trying to say here, I'll try my words, is that there is variability, but it's predictable variability. So you get the same quality results across the entire play, but the variability of what you would expect in the, given part of the
componenttext: I think what Tony is trying to say here, I'll try my words, is that there is variability, but it's predictable variability. So you get the same quality results across the entire play, but the variability of what you would expect in the, given part of the play, is very low, given the face of maturity that we're in the play overall. Dave, just to elaborate what Dave mentioned is as you characterize the reservoir there's a lot of variation in the reservoir thickness by zone. There's a lot of difference in the fluid content as you move from northeast to southwest. The pressure changes, as I just mentioned, from east to west, so there's a lot about variation in that. The actual total depth to get the wells down varies from the east to the west dramatically. But as Dave mentioned, the results that we're seeing as an industry are pretty darn tight. And the only place that we haven't seen predictable result has really been in the far southwest when we were -- and we need a few more data points to understand the gas versus oil content there. There's a little bit of variability in that. But for the most part, everything that we're seeing in the core in the field and our footprint the predictability is extremely tight.

componenttext: Just got a question on completion designs. Can you define your hybrid completion?  And two, with the STACK and also the Woodford, you're putting in a lot more sand. Do you have any sense of what you think economic limit for how much profits you can put in?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can give you a little bit of a feel. I'll remind us of the experience that we have been -- I believe it was mid-14 when we start increasing the sand loads in our Delaware completions, and we really ran up to from about 600 pounds per lateral foot in ear
componenttext: I can give you a little bit of a feel. I'll remind us of the experience that we have been -- I believe it was mid-14 when we start increasing the sand loads in our Delaware completions, and we really ran up to from about 600 pounds per lateral foot in early 2014 up to about 3,000 pounds per lateral foot through 2015. And at the same time, that information gave us a good matrix or a good feel for the performance change in that design but it also helped us understand the commercial the matrix associated with the commodity price environment. So we have backed off in the Delaware from that 3,000 pounds per lateral foot. We think we can get the most commercial returns in the current business environment done at about 1,500 to 2,000. It kind of varies across the field, so that's the way we think about it. And if you move over into the Anadarko Basin, we're using a slick water job in our Woodford-type work, and we continue to increase our profit loads there. So we're up to about 2,000 pounds per lateral foot. And after drilling and completing over 800 wells, this last large pad that we brought on have the best results that we've ever had in the Cana-Woodford play. As we think about the STACK play right now, we're using a hybrid-type job, so we've got a little bit of a jail with the total fluid is more dominated with slickwater. So we're continuing to experiment and modify with our completion designs. But we are increasing our loads up to about 2600 to 2750 pounds per lateral foot and enjoying increasing success of there. So John, we're getting a lot of this information, and we're really all about trying to make the highest return per well, not necessarily just the large jobs. So a lot of data out there, got a lot of data in our library, and we pump a lot of slickwater jobs in a few places like the Eagle Ford and in STACK right now are using a hybrid fluid.

componenttext: I don't believe it does, John. Probably get a little bit more feel from our technical guys, but I think our hybrid fluids are breaking with temperature, and they don't think there's a lot there. So just haven't heard of that complaint.

componenttext: A couple smaller ones. Can you talk about the infrastructure buildout in STACK and the Permian how it matches up with a potential rig count in the second half of 16 and 17 and any potential limitations or bottleneck as you look forward over the next couple of years?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you start with the Delaware, one of the things that has really changed over the last -- I'd say, the last 8 to 12 months, Ryan, has been the buildout of the infrastructure. And as you noticed some notes in our operating report, the majority of our work
componenttext: If you start with the Delaware, one of the things that has really changed over the last -- I'd say, the last 8 to 12 months, Ryan, has been the buildout of the infrastructure. And as you noticed some notes in our operating report, the majority of our work now, we [indiscernible] system to over wells. We also have the majority of our fluid being transported by pipe. And so the infrastructure -- and you can really see that as our LOE per BOE cost ahs dramatically dropped from over $16 a barrel down to the 8-type number over that period of time. So the infrastructure buildout in the Delaware Basin especially is there's no local takeaway issues associated with our work that we anticipate doing in the next couple of years. So really, the Delaware has now caught up to that infrastructure, and the returns are good. The cost of drilling complete wells is down. And certainly, the monthly recurring lease operating cost is down. And if you move over into the STACK play, the Cana-Woodford part of that is very well developed out. We have a great water system there. We're building out our concept for the Meramec play right now. That's in the design phase. We're working very closely with our midstream partner, EnLink, and they're helping us understand what the long-term takeaway opportunities might be. But again, we don't believe that's really a question in our current thought process for our current development until probably 2019. So we're working forward that we'll have the appropriate solution identified will be able to communicate that to you. And just a plug for the guys at EnLink, we highlighted the essentially the flat production in the Barnett from Q1 to Q2 and with no capital, and it's pretty amazing some of the work our team is done. That team consists of both Devon people and their EnLink team, so there's been great work online pressure reductions optimizing artificial lift system up there. So really having that partnership with EnLink is really providing a lot of value across our asset base.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's perfect. And then maybe one logical follow-up on that. You've seen significant downward pressure in both LOE and G&A unit cost over the past 18 months. I mean how much -- how much more room do you have to run there in terms of pushing costs lower?
componenttext: That's perfect. And then maybe one logical follow-up on that. You've seen significant downward pressure in both LOE and G&A unit cost over the past 18 months. I mean how much -- how much more room do you have to run there in terms of pushing costs lower? In the Permian, you've gone from kind of $15 to $8 per barrel over the past 6 quarters? Can it go to 6 or 4 or further? Any thoughts a look we should expect there in the next 12-plus months?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start off with the answer and then hand it over to Tony. On the G&A side, the bulk of the redemptions that we're seeing there were related to reductions in headcount, and we're just now starting to see all of that flow through the financials. But we
componenttext: I'll start off with the answer and then hand it over to Tony. On the G&A side, the bulk of the redemptions that we're seeing there were related to reductions in headcount, and we're just now starting to see all of that flow through the financials. But we have the staffing in place. We are comfortable with to execute the program now and also we could handle somewhat higher levels of activity as well, up to around 15 to 20 operated rigs. So we certainly don't see a reduction in headcount anymore as long as we maintain the path to recovery that we're on right now, and we certainly have the staffing in place in order to execute our capital program. And I'll turn it over to toady to talk a little bit more and LOE and where we can go.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's a real passionate push in the company right now to manage cost. And it's -- while we don't have much of a capital program in comparison to what we had in 2014, a lot of attention here in the last 12 months have really been towards managing
componenttext: I think there's a real passionate push in the company right now to manage cost. And it's -- while we don't have much of a capital program in comparison to what we had in 2014, a lot of attention here in the last 12 months have really been towards managing our base business. And we stood up and operations excellent group here that has really done a great job facilitating this focused effort to drive cost down. All of our field -- men and women in the field locations are doing a good job participating with us. So as we have built out our water handling capacity across all of our fields, we have more of our water going through pipe. We own more SWD capacity than we've had in the past. As we've gotten -- as we've brought power grid system into our business, we've been able to release probably about close to 300 rental generators just in the Delaware Basin alone. Really good thoughtful work there, and we have a supply chain group that is closely linked in with our operating team, and they're doing everything from working  reducing compression costs through renegotiating contracts, doing the same thing for chemicals. We're working on the water that we do have to transport and handle costs down. So we've got a great focused effort going on with our supply chain all of our field people. And again, it's something that is really passionate right now. Where we go from there, I mean you can start looking at some of the costs, and they start to flatten out just in terms of the price per unit, but we're still working on this, and we believe a lot of the wins still live together just through the attention to detail and through changes and through managing our business even better than we have in the past.

Welcome to the Devon Energy's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Howard Thill, Senior Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chrissy and good morning, everyone. I hope you've had a chance, as always, to review our earnings release information last night and this morning. That information includes our forward-looking guidance as well as our detailed ops report. Also o
componenttext:
Thank you, Chrissy and good morning, everyone. I hope you've had a chance, as always, to review our earnings release information last night and this morning. That information includes our forward-looking guidance as well as our detailed ops report. Also on the call today are Dave Hager, President and CEO; Tony Vaughn, Chief Operating Officer; Tom Mitchell, EVP and Chief Financial Officer; and a few other members of our senior management team.
Also, I'd like to remind you that comments and answers to questions on this call today will contain plans, forecasts, expectations and estimates that are forward-looking statements under U.S. securities law. These comments and answers are subject to a number of assumptions, risks and uncertainties, many of which are beyond our control. These statements are not guarantees of future performance, and actual results may differ materially. For review of risk factors relating to these statements, please see our Form 10-K and subsequent 10-Q filings. 
And with that, I will turn it over to Dave.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard, and welcome, everyone. The last several months have been very active for Devon. We've continued to deliver strong operating results from our top-tier North American resource plays, and we significantly outperformed Street expectations o
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard, and welcome, everyone. The last several months have been very active for Devon. We've continued to deliver strong operating results from our top-tier North American resource plays, and we significantly outperformed Street expectations on our assets divestitures, which dramatically improved our financial strength. Overall, it was a great quarter of execution for Devon.
I will touch on 3 key messages today: efficiency gains, the portfolio transformation and the quality of our asset base.
First, we continue to achieve significant efficiency gains across Devon's entire portfolio. Productivity from our top 2 franchise assets, the STACK and Delaware Basin, was once again outstanding. We commenced production on approximately 20 wells from these prolific assets during the second quarter, with 30-day rates averaging nearly 1,500 BOE per day. Not only did these high-rate wells deliver excellent returns, they also exceeded our type curve expectations by a wide margin. Combined with positive base production performance across our entire portfolio, we were able to drive production above midpoint expectations for all products in the second quarter. Importantly, these productivity gains were attained with substantially lower costs. Drilling and completion costs at our U.S. resource plays have now declined by as much as 40% from peak rates, and we are now on pace to save nearly $1 billion of operating and G&A expenses in 2016.
The second key takeaway is that Devon's portfolio transformation is now complete. In December of last year, we announced a bold move to materially add to our position in the STACK play with the Felix acquisition as well as the Rockies, along with our intent to monetize noncore assets across our portfolio. Since that announcement, we've successfully integrated the Felix assets into our portfolio, and their prolific new well results from this asset continue to support our view that the STACK play is the best emerging development play in North America. 
We have also done a tremendous job executing on our noncore asset divestiture program. We have reached agreement to sell $3.2 billion of assets, well above the top end of our $2 billion to $3 billion guidance range, and these accretive transactions have significantly strengthened our investment grade balance sheet. Majority of proceeds will be used for debt reduction. While there has been tremendous volatility in energy markets over the past year, I have unwavering conviction that these strategic actions were the correct long-term decisions for Devon.
And finally, I want to leave you with some thoughts about the quality and depth of Devon's go-forward asset base, which we believe is unmatched in the industry. With the recent high grading of our portfolio, we sharpened our focused on Devon's top resource plays, all concentrated in North America's best basins. Led by our world-class STACK and Delaware Basin assets, we have exposure to more than 1 million net acres and thousands of low-risk opportunities that can deliver sustainable long-term growth for Devon. Importantly, we are taking significant steps in 2016 to accelerate future development in the STACK and Delaware Basin. In the STACK, we are participating in more than 10 spacing pilots to optimize our 2017 development plans in the overpressured oil window. In the Delaware Basin, our total reservoir access concept, otherwise known as TRAC, has future development plans in place to efficiently develop up to 9 intervals of STACK play in a given area from super pads. Looking beyond the massive opportunity set in STACK and Delaware Basin, we also have attractive investment opportunities in the Eagle Ford, Rockies and Barnett Shale. And more importantly, these high-quality assets possess the ability to generate substantial amounts of free cash flow.
Outside of our formidable U.S. resource plays, our top-tier heavy oil asset in Canada provides tremendous optionality. These capital-efficient assets can produce large amounts of cash flow, and also possess significant growth potential with greater than 1 billion barrels of undeveloped resource in the economic core of the Alberta oil sands. Overall, Devon's go-forward asset base is well balanced between scalable growth assets and top-tier cash flow generating assets.
Given the quality of our go-forward asset portfolio, we have no shortage of attractive investment opportunities across our asset base. And with the success of our asset divestiture program, our strong financial position allows us to accelerate investment in these best-in-class resource plays. As we previously announced in June, we are increasing our upstream capital investment by approximately $200 million to a range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion in 2016. This incremental capital investment will be deployed entirely in the STACK and Delaware Basin beginning in the third quarter. By year-end, we expect to add as many as 7 operated rigs between these 2 areas. The annualized upstream capital spend associated with this activity at year-end is approximately $1.6 billion. While it is still a bit too early to provide any formal targets for 2017, I can tell you that this level of investment is sufficient to generate growth in oil production and stabilize Devon's top line production profile by mid-year 2017.
So in summary, I'm pleased with the way Devon is positioned to navigate the current environment and prosper in the future. We have a great collection of assets and experienced team that has a track record of delivering excellent results and in the terms of the financial capacity to efficiently convert our resource-rich opportunity set into production and cash flow.
With that, I'll turn the call back to Howard.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. And before we head to Q&A, I'll take just a few moments to address one of the most, often asked questions that our team has received since our release, and that's our production profile. As we reached our sales values on divested assets in e
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. And before we head to Q&A, I'll take just a few moments to address one of the most, often asked questions that our team has received since our release, and that's our production profile. As we reached our sales values on divested assets in excess of our targets, there are certain assets we haven't sold and, therefore, we have rolled into the Devon go-forward look. Also, the production estimates we previously issued showed a full year of the divested assets while we have already closed several and anticipate closing the remaining assets soon. The largest component of retained assets previously in the other category are select Midland assets, which have a relatively shallow decline rate and are high margin. And to be perfectly clear, we see both U.S. and Canadian production stabilizing in the fourth quarter of 2016, and our projected activity levels at year end 2016, we project top line production for our retained assets to stabilize by mid-year 2017, led by growth in the U.S. oil. A key contributor to mitigating gas and NGL declines in the first half of 2017 will be the Hobson Road development in the STACK that we anticipate bringing on in early 2017, and we expect to return to top line growth in the second half of 2017. Of course, these projections are predicated on an expectation that we see strengthening in commodity prices, which will allow us to add the 3 or 4 additional rigs in the fourth quarter of 2016 we disclosed in our 2Q earnings materials. So based on that level of activity at year-end, you could expect an annual spend of somewhere around $1.6 billion. I hope this helps. And of course, if you have more detailed modeling questions, Scott, Chris or I are happy to visit with you after the call.
With that, and heading to Q&A. [Operator Instructions] With that, Chrissy, we'll take our first question.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
