componenttext:
Welcome to the Devon Energy's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Howard Thill, Senior Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chrissy and good morning, everyone. I hope you've had a chance, as always, to review our earnings release information last night and this morning. That information includes our forward-looking guidance as well as our detailed ops report. Also o
componenttext:
Thank you, Chrissy and good morning, everyone. I hope you've had a chance, as always, to review our earnings release information last night and this morning. That information includes our forward-looking guidance as well as our detailed ops report. Also on the call today are Dave Hager, President and CEO; Tony Vaughn, Chief Operating Officer; Tom Mitchell, EVP and Chief Financial Officer; and a few other members of our senior management team.
Also, I'd like to remind you that comments and answers to questions on this call today will contain plans, forecasts, expectations and estimates that are forward-looking statements under U.S. securities law. These comments and answers are subject to a number of assumptions, risks and uncertainties, many of which are beyond our control. These statements are not guarantees of future performance, and actual results may differ materially. For a review of risk factors relating to these statements, please see our Form 10-K and subsequent 10-Q filings. 
And with that, I will turn it over to Dave.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard, and welcome, everyone. The last several months have been very active for Devon. We've continued to deliver strong operating results from our top-tier North American resource plays, and we significantly outperformed Street expectations o
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard, and welcome, everyone. The last several months have been very active for Devon. We've continued to deliver strong operating results from our top-tier North American resource plays, and we significantly outperformed Street expectations on our assets divestitures, which dramatically improved our financial strength. Overall, it was a great quarter of execution for Devon.
I will touch on 3 key messages today: efficiency gains, the portfolio transformation and the quality of our asset base.
First, we continue to achieve significant efficiency gains across Devon's entire portfolio. Productivity from our top 2 franchise assets, the STACK and Delaware Basin, was once again outstanding. We commenced production on approximately 20 wells from these prolific assets during the second quarter, with 30-day rates averaging nearly 1,500 BOE per day. Not only did these high-rate wells deliver excellent returns, they also exceeded our type curve expectations by a wide margin. Combined with positive base production performance across our entire portfolio, we were able to drive production above midpoint expectations for all products in the second quarter. Importantly, these productivity gains were attained with substantially lower costs. Drilling and completion costs at our U.S. resource plays have now declined by as much as 40% from peak rates, and we are now on pace to save nearly $1 billion of operating and G&A expenses in 2016.
The second key takeaway is that Devon's portfolio transformation is now complete. In December of last year, we announced a bold move to materially add to our position in the STACK play with the Felix acquisition as well as the Rockies, along with our intent to monetize noncore assets across our portfolio. Since that announcement, we've successfully integrated the Felix assets into our portfolio, and their prolific new well results from this asset continue to support our view that the STACK play is the best emerging development play in North America. 
We have also done a tremendous job executing on our noncore asset divestiture program. We have reached agreement to sell $3.2 billion of assets, well above the top end of our $2 billion to $3 billion guidance range, and these accretive transactions have significantly strengthened our investment-grade balance sheet. Majority of proceeds will be used for debt reduction. While there has been tremendous volatility in energy markets over the past year, I have unwavering conviction that these strategic actions were the correct long-term decisions for Devon.
And finally, I want to leave you with some thoughts about the quality and depth of Devon's go-forward asset base, which we believe is unmatched in the industry. With the recent high grading of our portfolio, we sharpened our focused on Devon's top resource plays, all concentrated in North America's best basins. Led by our world-class STACK and Delaware Basin assets, we have exposure to more than 1 million net acres and thousands of low-risk opportunities that can deliver sustainable long-term growth for Devon. Importantly, we are taking significant steps in 2016 to accelerate future development in the STACK and Delaware Basin. In the STACK, we are participating in more than 10 spacing pilots to optimize our 2017 development plans in the overpressured oil window. In the Delaware Basin, our total reservoir access concept, otherwise known as TRAC, has future development plans in place to efficiently develop up to 9 intervals of stack pay in a given area from super pads. Looking beyond the massive opportunity set in STACK and Delaware Basin, we also have attractive investment opportunities in the Eagle Ford, Rockies and Barnett Shale. And more importantly, these high-quality assets possess the ability to generate substantial amounts of free cash flow.
Outside of our formidable U.S. resource plays, our top-tier heavy oil asset in Canada provides tremendous optionality. These capital-efficient assets can produce large amounts of cash flow, and also possess significant growth potential with greater than 1 billion barrels of undeveloped resource in the economic core of the Alberta oil sands. Overall, Devon's go-forward asset base is well balanced between scalable growth assets and top-tier cash flow generating assets.
Given the quality of our go-forward asset portfolio, we have no shortage of attractive investment opportunities across our asset base. And with the success of our asset divestiture program, our strong financial position allows us to accelerate investment in these best-in-class resource plays. As we previously announced in June, we are increasing our upstream capital investment by approximately $200 million to a range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion in 2016. This incremental capital investment will be deployed entirely in the STACK and Delaware Basin beginning in the third quarter. By year-end, we expect to add as many as 7 operated rigs between these 2 areas. The annualized upstream capital spend associated with this activity at year-end is approximately $1.6 billion. While it is still a bit too early to provide any formal targets for 2017, I can tell you that this level of investment is sufficient to generate growth in oil production and stabilize Devon's top line production profile by mid-year 2017.
So in summary, I'm pleased with the way Devon is positioned to navigate the current environment and prosper in the future. We have a great collection of assets and experienced team that has a track record of delivering excellent results and have the financial capacity to efficiently convert our resource-rich opportunity set into production and cash flow.
With that, I'll turn the call back to Howard.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. And before we head to Q&A, I'll take just a few moments to address one of the most, often asked questions that our team has received since our release, and that's our production profile. As we reached our sales values on divested assets in e
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. And before we head to Q&A, I'll take just a few moments to address one of the most, often asked questions that our team has received since our release, and that's our production profile. As we reached our sales values on divested assets in excess of our targets, there are certain assets we haven't sold and, therefore, we have rolled into the Devon go-forward look. Also, the production estimates we previously issued showed a full year of the divested assets while we have already closed several and anticipate closing the remaining assets soon. The largest component of retained assets previously in the other category are select Midland assets, which have a relatively shallow decline rate and are high margin. And to be perfectly clear, we see both U.S. and Canadian production stabilizing in the fourth quarter of 2016, and our projected activity levels at year end 2016, we project top line production for our retained assets to stabilize by mid-year 2017, led by growth in the U.S. oil. A key contributor to mitigating gas and NGL declines in the first half of 2017 will be the Hobson Road development in the STACK that we anticipate bringing on in early 2017, and we expect to return to top line growth in the second half of 2017. Of course, these projections are predicated on an expectation that we see strengthening in commodity prices, which will allow us to add the 3 or 4 additional rigs in the fourth quarter of 2016 we disclosed in our 2Q earnings materials. So based on that level of activity at year-end, you could expect an annual spend of somewhere around $1.6 billion. I hope this helps. And of course, if you have more detailed modeling questions, Scott, Chris or I are happy to visit with you after the call.
With that, and heading to Q&A. [Operator Instructions] With that, Chrissy, we'll take our first question.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Pearce Hammond from Simmons Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Pearce Hammond from Simmons Piper Jaffray.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, thanks for that color just now on the 3 rigs and then potentially on the additions, and then potentially going to the 7 rigs. Dave, as you look at the current forward strip to year-end and then look out to next year's pricing, do you think if thos
componenttext: Howard, thanks for that color just now on the 3 rigs and then potentially on the additions, and then potentially going to the 7 rigs. Dave, as you look at the current forward strip to year-end and then look out to next year's pricing, do you think if those prices hold that you would add those 4 rigs or you’d need to see a little bit higher price to do that?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Yes, great question, Pearce. We see that our cash flow at the current strip being approximately that, that we could add these rigs and live within cash flow. It varies, obviously, a little bit day-to-day, and we're in a little bit of a downturn right
componenttext: No. Yes, great question, Pearce. We see that our cash flow at the current strip being approximately that, that we could add these rigs and live within cash flow. It varies, obviously, a little bit day-to-day, and we're in a little bit of a downturn right now, but we're approximately at the point where we would be cash flow neutral. So we could add those rigs.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up is, as you highlighted on the '17 guidance or preliminary '17 guidance, and I know it's not formalized at this point, but what -- on oil production would you be able to hold year-end '17 or Q4 -- excuse me, Q4 '16 oil production flat
componenttext: And then my follow-up is, as you highlighted on the '17 guidance or preliminary '17 guidance, and I know it's not formalized at this point, but what -- on oil production would you be able to hold year-end '17 or Q4 -- excuse me, Q4 '16 oil production flat and then grow from there? I'm trying to get a sense of what the -- if you spend that $1.6 billion, what the oil production profile would look like. Or would it continue to decline from the Q4 '16 levels until the middle part of next year and then start to come back up?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We would essentially stabilize production at the Q4 levels -- of Q4 '16 levels. And then later in the year, it would start inclining, later in '17.
componenttext: No. We would essentially stabilize production at the Q4 levels -- of Q4 '16 levels. And then later in the year, it would start inclining, later in '17.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that'd be stabilizing oil production at Q4 levels but not total production?
componenttext: And that'd be stabilizing oil production at Q4 levels but not total production?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct. That is oil production. As Howard said, we would stabilize the BOEs around mid-year 2017. So we'd still experience some decline. And where we're not investing in gas particularly, and to a lesser degree, the NGLs, and then it would be stab
componenttext: That's correct. That is oil production. As Howard said, we would stabilize the BOEs around mid-year 2017. So we'd still experience some decline. And where we're not investing in gas particularly, and to a lesser degree, the NGLs, and then it would be stabilized by mid-year '17 and then start an incline on the BOEs as well at the back half of '17. And we'll be exiting at a significantly higher rate than mid-year.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, Dave, is to talk -- to ask you about the maintenance CapEx number. You had previously said about a $2 billion number to keep production flat on a BOE basis, and now you're signaling $1.6 billion. I was wondering if you could maybe highl
componenttext: My first question, Dave, is to talk -- to ask you about the maintenance CapEx number. You had previously said about a $2 billion number to keep production flat on a BOE basis, and now you're signaling $1.6 billion. I was wondering if you could maybe highlight what's driven that pretty meaningful reduction in maintenance CapEx as we think about 2017.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question on that, Arun. We're continuing to drive efficiencies in our business, internal efficiencies. We’ve talked about the 40% reduction in drilling and completion costs, and about 50%, 50-50 between lower service cost and internal efficiencies
componenttext: Great question on that, Arun. We're continuing to drive efficiencies in our business, internal efficiencies. We’ve talked about the 40% reduction in drilling and completion costs, and about 50%, 50-50 between lower service cost and internal efficiencies. I can tell you, as we sit here today, we're finding even more internal efficiencies that are continuing to drive that maintenance capital lower. And so we -- as well as the fact that we're exceeding the type curves on our wells. And so, you combine the cost savings we're still finding with the fact that our wells, we're in the best parts of the best plays and they're exceeding our expectations. So that's continuing to drive the maintenance capital down.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up, Dave, is on a pro forma basis, $4.6 billion in cash. It sounds like from the ops report, you'll use roughly $2 billion or so for debt reduction and $1 billion of the $3.2 billion -- $1 billion in proceeds could be reinvesting. Would you
componenttext: And my follow-up, Dave, is on a pro forma basis, $4.6 billion in cash. It sounds like from the ops report, you'll use roughly $2 billion or so for debt reduction and $1 billion of the $3.2 billion -- $1 billion in proceeds could be reinvesting. Would you feel comfortable, for example, in '17, if you feel good about oil in the low to mid-50s of outspending by $1 billion or so to take some of these proceeds, just given how you have so much cash on the balance sheet?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we do think that, and we do have the other cash on the balance sheet from essentially the equity offering. We do feel that it's very important to maintain our investment grade rating. And probably longer term, we'd still look at using some of those
componenttext: Well, we do think that, and we do have the other cash on the balance sheet from essentially the equity offering. We do feel that it's very important to maintain our investment grade rating. And probably longer term, we'd still look at using some of those proceeds to pay down debt. But -- so we are at this point thinking that we want to live within cash flow. And so if we start -- you know we've said we'd start adding back activity if we had confidence prices are going to be somewhere around $50. We have added back activity. We've added back some. We plan to add back more. If we do see prices sustain over $50, and gas prices -- actually the recovery in gas has helped out significantly as well with our cash flow. If we see gas prices sustain near to levels where they are now, we may be able even to add a little bit more activity in '17, but that would be living within cash flow, though. So we don't see a significant cash flow outspend.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two type curve questions, if I may. Obviously, let's start with the Bone Springs. You talked about some of the wells, 50% ahead. Leonard, 70% ahead. We just had OCCI presentation showing that their 100-day cumes, I think from memory, doubled on older desi
componenttext: Two type curve questions, if I may. Obviously, let's start with the Bone Springs. You talked about some of the wells, 50% ahead. Leonard, 70% ahead. We just had OCCI presentation showing that their 100-day cumes, I think from memory, doubled on older designs. So maybe just talk through what the constraint on perhaps raising the overall type curve. It might just be that across the inventory you still have downspacing tests et cetera. And then I have a question on the STACK.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tony Vaughn here. And I think you hit it right. The activity and the number of new completions that we have brought on of late have been fairly small, but we're extremely pleased with all the performance that we have, especially in the Leonard. No
componenttext: This is Tony Vaughn here. And I think you hit it right. The activity and the number of new completions that we have brought on of late have been fairly small, but we're extremely pleased with all the performance that we have, especially in the Leonard. Not only are all the well results that we're making public in the Leonard well above our type curve, industry around us are really experiencing the same things. So we'll make these type curve adjustments both here and in STACK, just as we get a little more comfortable with that and get a few more reps behind us. But really, the operational performance of our new activity in both the Delaware and the STACK are well above our expectations on our current type curves.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then on the STACK what was the average lateral length of the Q2 results? Because obviously again, exceeding type curve, but if you go to longer laterals, those should be more capital efficient.
componenttext: Okay. Then on the STACK what was the average lateral length of the Q2 results? Because obviously again, exceeding type curve, but if you go to longer laterals, those should be more capital efficient.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're exactly right. Historically, the industry has -- we've got about 200 wells in the STACK play to date. And there's about 60% of those that are the long laterals. On our well count, Ed, we have about just under 50 wells that we operate. And w
componenttext: I think you're exactly right. Historically, the industry has -- we've got about 200 wells in the STACK play to date. And there's about 60% of those that are the long laterals. On our well count, Ed, we have about just under 50 wells that we operate. And we have about just under 50% of those are long laterals. Difficult to better put a arithmetic average on the full population of that, but it's probably somewhere around 6,000, 6,500 feet. But I'll tell you, a lot of the early wells that were drilled were in the appraisal mind-set. They were also in the lease-saving mind-set. And now that we're getting a lot of that information behind us, being more comfortable with the subsurface, I think Devon is really looking forward to optimizing our completions and our lateral links, and really the design that we're going forward is to use as many of the long laterals as possible.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll just add, I think what Tony is saying here is, a lot of the 10,000 footers that we drilled here were probably not as productive as we would anticipate 10,000 foot laterals to be in the future. Some of those were wells that were drilled by Felix
componenttext: Yes. I'll just add, I think what Tony is saying here is, a lot of the 10,000 footers that we drilled here were probably not as productive as we would anticipate 10,000 foot laterals to be in the future. Some of those were wells that were drilled by Felix without the benefits of 3D, and we had early completion designs that are not, what we feel, the optimum design. So even though there were some 10,000 footers in the mix, they were not of the quality we would anticipate from a go-forward basis.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Kissel from Scotia Howard Weil.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Kissel from Scotia Howard Weil.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just very quickly, looking at 2017, you outlined the $1.6 billion bogey, if you will, on spending, but what sort of obligations do you have for spending above that $1.6 billion? Just trying to think about how much of that could go up or down as you look t
componenttext: Just very quickly, looking at 2017, you outlined the $1.6 billion bogey, if you will, on spending, but what sort of obligations do you have for spending above that $1.6 billion? Just trying to think about how much of that could go up or down as you look to stay within cash flow.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're totally flexible on that, Pete. We don't have any obligations. I think that's one of the great attributes of Devon is we have essentially all of our acreage held by production. We have a minor amount in the Felix acquisition where we need to h
componenttext: Well, we're totally flexible on that, Pete. We don't have any obligations. I think that's one of the great attributes of Devon is we have essentially all of our acreage held by production. We have a minor amount in the Felix acquisition where we need to have some activity. We're going to have way more activity than is required to get all our acreage held by production. We don't have any, obviously, long-term projects going on in the company. So we are totally flexible as cash flow presents itself as to ramping up activity. And of course, we don't like to think about it as much. But if prices do retreat, we have flexibility to decrease activity as well. So it is strictly driven by -- we have the projects, we have as good of projects, we think, as anybody in the industry. It would be in the hearts of some of the best plays. It's just a matter of what cash flow is available to put against those projects.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, one thing you guys have done a great job in the past of is kind of stack ranking your returns of your given plays here. As the STACK has continued to look extremely good, the Delaware Basin looks extremely good, would you mind just dusting
componenttext: Okay. And then, one thing you guys have done a great job in the past of is kind of stack ranking your returns of your given plays here. As the STACK has continued to look extremely good, the Delaware Basin looks extremely good, would you mind just dusting that off and reminding us where they all stand in order of preference? And maybe ultimately, where did the PRB come into the mix looking into 2017, as you've grown to have a very big position there but very little activity?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pete, nothing's really changed there. If you look at the returns on a strip basis, we really haven't commented on the absolute number of that. But the returns that we see in the Parkman, the Delaware, the Eagle Ford and the STACK play are all comparable t
componenttext: Pete, nothing's really changed there. If you look at the returns on a strip basis, we really haven't commented on the absolute number of that. But the returns that we see in the Parkman, the Delaware, the Eagle Ford and the STACK play are all comparable to each other. If you look at the sensitivity to the number of locations that we have available, that does change. And so if you look in the Parkman, I mean, we've done some of the best return work we've done there, but the inventory is not as deep and as robust as it is in the Delaware and the STACK play. So really, all 4 of those plays are ones that we've got the flexibility and ability to drive value for, which really presents an opportunity for us, I think, to prosecute and to understand the subsurface even better while still getting a lot of meaningful and competitive returns.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of the 4, Pete, the Powder Basin is the most sensitive to oil prices because it is about 90% light oil. And so, when we are, earlier in the year, I mean, after we did the acquisition with prices down mid-30s or so, it wasn't competing for capital. But as
componenttext: Of the 4, Pete, the Powder Basin is the most sensitive to oil prices because it is about 90% light oil. And so, when we are, earlier in the year, I mean, after we did the acquisition with prices down mid-30s or so, it wasn't competing for capital. But as we get back over $50 a barrel, the economics on that improved dramatically because of the high oil cuts there. And so that's what puts it into the -- is very sensitive, but it puts us back up into one of top-tier plays when we get in a $50-plus environment. Not as deep in inventory but still good economics at the well level.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I apologize if I'm belaboring this point a bit, but I'd like to just see if I could distill some of the comments you've made on this call. The $1.6 billion number, that was really useful for what you could do. But I'd like to try to understand or make sur
componenttext: I apologize if I'm belaboring this point a bit, but I'd like to just see if I could distill some of the comments you've made on this call. The $1.6 billion number, that was really useful for what you could do. But I'd like to try to understand or make sure I understand what really is driving your appetite for what you actually choose to do. So I think I heard you say you're going to draw -- spend within cash flow regardless of where the commodity prices go. But is there a scenario where you just wouldn't have the appetite to drill more in the case where -- or you wouldn't have an appetite to add rigs if the commodity price went down?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we look at -- let me try to clarify. It's really 2 things that we look at when we determine our capital allocation and the levels of capital. One would be the returns on at the project level, and so we compare projects across the entire company, tak
componenttext: Well, we look at -- let me try to clarify. It's really 2 things that we look at when we determine our capital allocation and the levels of capital. One would be the returns on at the project level, and so we compare projects across the entire company, take into account any sort of operational considerations, any sort of limitations, and then we fund the highest-return projects across the company. We do that to the extent that we can live within cash flow. And so that's the second step of the process is, what is our cash flow going to be. And you said the $1.6 billion is -- and again, prices are moving around every day so you can't -- you're going to rerun these numbers every day and get a little, slightly different answer. But it's approximately the level at which we can live within cash flow in 2017 at the current strip and fund the top-tier projects that we have identified with the 9 rigs that we could be adding by the end of the year. And we plan to add up to that 9-rig level unless we see a significant change in commodity prices between now and then.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. That's helpful, Dave. And I imagine these moves in the commodity prices are even more fun for you guys than they offer us. But...
componenttext: Right. That's helpful, Dave. And I imagine these moves in the commodity prices are even more fun for you guys than they offer us. But...

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're having a barrel of laughs.
componenttext: We're having a barrel of laughs.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could ask a question on the Delaware Basin, you guys introduced this total reservoir access concept, is that -- that's new this quarter, but one of the things that I think is going to challenge out, particularly as I understand in your part of the De
componenttext: If I could ask a question on the Delaware Basin, you guys introduced this total reservoir access concept, is that -- that's new this quarter, but one of the things that I think is going to challenge out, particularly as I understand in your part of the Delaware Basin is been extending the standard length like 5,000-foot laterals out to 10,000-foot laterals. Is that a correct perception that it's harder than other places to get to the 10,000-foot laterals? And does that interact or play some part in your TRAC concept?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, about 1/3 of our position or our footprint in the Delaware Basin will accommodate the long laterals. It's a little bit tougher to put those together as you move north in Lea and Eddy County in our footprint, but in the southern portion of this wh
componenttext: Charles, about 1/3 of our position or our footprint in the Delaware Basin will accommodate the long laterals. It's a little bit tougher to put those together as you move north in Lea and Eddy County in our footprint, but in the southern portion of this where this new super pad or TRAC concept would be utilized in 2017. It's a little easier to do that. And so I think what we're trying to describe here is a concept that when you start thinking about having all of the stacked pays that we have, both here and in the STACK asset in Oklahoma, there's going to be a more creative and efficient way to develop our service facilities. And so we're walking into this with this concept. It provides us a lot of flexibility as we grow. It also allows us to have flexibility as the business environment changes. But for the most part, we're going to -- through the permitting process to achieve a -- or to get approval for a really more of a fill development concept and then past that, we will be left to get individual APDs by well as we choose to develop that. So you're right about our footprint. It is a little bit less contiguous in the north end of our position but in the south end of Lea and Eddy, it should be very well suited for this type of a concept.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing that's so great about it, too, Charles is, if you -- and we showed it on the maps that we put into our investor presentations that in particularly the southern parts of Lea and Eddy counties, we just have so many prospective zones. We
componenttext: And the other thing that's so great about it, too, Charles is, if you -- and we showed it on the maps that we put into our investor presentations that in particularly the southern parts of Lea and Eddy counties, we just have so many prospective zones. We said we have up to 9 prospective zones between the Delaware Sands, the Bone Spring, Leonard and the Wolfcamp. And so we are still doing appraisal work, determining how many wells per section in an individual zone and how many of these zones in a vertical sense, also, can be developed in any one geographic location. But the numbers you start seeing start boggling the mind sometimes, I'd say, with how many wells you could have on in individual section. We're hesitant to put the numbers out there until we finish more appraisal work, but there could be just a tremendous amount of resource that we're developing on each section out there, and that's what's necessitated this super pad concept to figure out. It's great to have the resource, but then how are you actually going to develop that resource, and that's what's put that into place. It is a really exciting future both in the Delaware Basin and in the STACK play because of this.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, I want to make sure we're understanding this maintenance capital issue right, because the numbers and if my math is right, you're basically indicating you can hold production flat at an oil price in the mid to high 40s. [indiscernible] through the n
componenttext: Dave, I want to make sure we're understanding this maintenance capital issue right, because the numbers and if my math is right, you're basically indicating you can hold production flat at an oil price in the mid to high 40s. [indiscernible] through the numbers? Is that directionally where you're headed?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that may be a little bit lower for you than where we're at it. I don't want to get in. I guess, Doug, I appreciate your question, and I'm struggling a little bit to get into the details of that right now.
componenttext: Well, I think that may be a little bit lower for you than where we're at it. I don't want to get in. I guess, Doug, I appreciate your question, and I'm struggling a little bit to get into the details of that right now.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me walk you through, very quickly, Dave, where -- how I get there. Previously, you said $40 is your CapEx breakeven this year, but that included the contribution from Access of about $800 million. So your sensitivity is about 80 million per dollar, an
componenttext: Let me walk you through, very quickly, Dave, where -- how I get there. Previously, you said $40 is your CapEx breakeven this year, but that included the contribution from Access of about $800 million. So your sensitivity is about 80 million per dollar, and previously you'd said that you would hold flat at about $60. So when I walk through all those numbers, it kind of implies $1.6 billion is somewhere in the mid to high 40s.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the big thing that's changed, off the top of my head, here, Doug, is that gas prices have gone up significantly. And so that has provided significant incremental cash flow to us as well as some improvement on the NGL side as well. So it's pro
componenttext: Yes, I think the big thing that's changed, off the top of my head, here, Doug, is that gas prices have gone up significantly. And so that has provided significant incremental cash flow to us as well as some improvement on the NGL side as well. So it's probably less a product of oil prices -- the breakeven maintenance capital on oil prices going down as it is the fact that our assumptions around what gas prices we can achieve along with the oil has allowed higher cash flow to allow us to keep production flat.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes a ton of sense. Okay. My follow-up is really going to the STACK and the move to 10,000-foot wells. Obviously, you've partnered with Continental on a bunch of those wells. What do you think the costs are that you can deliver these wells at? And
componenttext: That makes a ton of sense. Okay. My follow-up is really going to the STACK and the move to 10,000-foot wells. Obviously, you've partnered with Continental on a bunch of those wells. What do you think the costs are that you can deliver these wells at? And I guess, this is a related question, what's holding you back from moving up your type curve given what you're seeing from others in the play?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, Doug, we're finding that the well cost vary quite dramatically from the shallow eastern portion of the field all the way across to the southwest portion of where Continental is, as you mentioned. We're finding that we can drill the wells for abo
componenttext: You know, Doug, we're finding that the well cost vary quite dramatically from the shallow eastern portion of the field all the way across to the southwest portion of where Continental is, as you mentioned. We're finding that we can drill the wells for about $5.5 million per well with the 2-string design on the eastern half of the field. We go into that, I have to add a third string as we go past the kind of a dividing line that separates the east from the west, add that third string, it adds about $1 million. And then as we go from a 5,000-foot lateral up to a 10,000-foot lateral, that's about $1 million to $1.5 million incremental on top of that. So that's -- it might give you a range in the cost as we work across that field. We continue to see positive results in our well performance from the oily section in the northeast to the -- a little bit of the gassier, more volatile as you move into the central portion of the field. But overall, Doug, when you put all of the attributes together, we still believe that we're in the heart of the high-return portion of the field. We think all of those attributes really lead to what will be the most commercial development going forward for all the competitors there.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for me, just on the type curve. Is it just a matter of waiting on more well results?
componenttext: And for me, just on the type curve. Is it just a matter of waiting on more well results?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is. You know, it's -- from an operational perspective, it's nice to see almost -- virtually, every well result that we have is not in the type curve. It's above -- well above the type curve. So we're going to modify that with performance but we have be
componenttext: It is. You know, it's -- from an operational perspective, it's nice to see almost -- virtually, every well result that we have is not in the type curve. It's above -- well above the type curve. So we're going to modify that with performance but we have been pleasantly pleased. And one of the things I wanted to point out on the STACK play, in general, that while there's a lot of variables that go into the subsurface description of this from depth, from pressure to changing fluid compositions to changing thickness by zone, a lot of variables are going into that, but I've got to tell you that the predictability of the results is very narrow. And we still believe the P10 to P90 range in the 90-day IP is about 2.4, which is extremely tight for a fairly young play. And so while there's a lot of variables that are changing out there, we think the predictability of the play is really unusually good in comparison to a lot of the resource plays that we've been involved in.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if I could ask a question on the STACK. Obviously, you highlight the great performance in the well results you've had in addition to your massive acreage position. You are producing around 90,000 a day there. But when you step back and loo
componenttext: I was wondering if I could ask a question on the STACK. Obviously, you highlight the great performance in the well results you've had in addition to your massive acreage position. You are producing around 90,000 a day there. But when you step back and look at it -- and I'm assuming you've kind of generalized some of the numbers, but where do you think that ultimately could grow to? How big is the prize here on your acreage there?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know Scott, I think when we did the acquisition analysis, we had a little bit of a narrative that we were trying to visualize what that would look like us well. And we think, though, with our position, and Woodford continues to expand, the well perfor
componenttext: You know Scott, I think when we did the acquisition analysis, we had a little bit of a narrative that we were trying to visualize what that would look like us well. And we think, though, with our position, and Woodford continues to expand, the well performance gets larger. We're seeing more resource potential in the Meramec and the Osage. But also in the -- underneath the Meramec, we're seeing more potential with the Woodford. We believe that we can probably push up north of 150,000 towards 200,000 BOEs per day as all of these zones continue to be derisked and incorporated into our development plans. Of course, a lot of that, Scott, is really contingent on the commodity price environment that we're in and the pace of activity that we can prosecute that large resource base.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great color. And my follow-up is on the Eagle Ford. Obviously getting a lot of less attention right now. I'm curious on where it could fit into your long-term portfolio, especially considering your operating partner appears to be deemphasizin
componenttext: Okay. That's great color. And my follow-up is on the Eagle Ford. Obviously getting a lot of less attention right now. I'm curious on where it could fit into your long-term portfolio, especially considering your operating partner appears to be deemphasizing onshore development at this point. How do you look at that? And if I could add a question to that, if your partner decided, let's say, to exit the Eagle Ford, what would your reaction be? What would Devon do?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I appreciate the question, Scott. I don't think it's probably appropriate for us to comment on hypothetical situations there. But the Eagle Ford, we've had some tremendous results. And again, we have a position there that is really like we want to d
componenttext: Well, I appreciate the question, Scott. I don't think it's probably appropriate for us to comment on hypothetical situations there. But the Eagle Ford, we've had some tremendous results. And again, we have a position there that is really like we want to do in all of our plays. It's in the best of one of the best plays in onshore North America. And if you look at the historical well results that we've delivered out there, we have a large proportion of the best wells that have been drilled in the play. So we certainly have liked our position. Right now, we're just in a position where given that capital constraints that we had earlier in the year, ourselves and our partner, that we decreased drilling activity significantly. And along with that and the completion activity, we thought we are going to resume completion activity here in Q3. It's been pushed back. It looks like about 1 quarter now. So that's, I guess, a very short-term challenge. But frankly, it's going to help us a little bit in 2017 as some of those volumes pushed out of '16 and into '17, so I don't think it's a significant event towards the long-term strategy of the Eagle Ford. We still see some high rate or high return-type opportunities in the Eagle Ford. We are maturing our way through the best part of the inventory right now. But we also are seeing some upside from the diamond pattern that we described in the operations report, which is really a staggered laterals in the lower Eagle Ford along with the upside in the upper Eagle Ford. And so we still think there's some upside that exists to the resource out there, albeit it doesn't have the -- and we knew it at the time of the acquisition. It just didn't have the running room that we see now in the Delaware and in the STACK play. So we still like it very much, and we just have to see how things develop beyond that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is a follow-up on the Meramec. Given your understanding and the success of the Alma pad, what do you guys think is the ultimate limits here for development spacing? And what size pilot program will you need to change your development ass
componenttext: My first question is a follow-up on the Meramec. Given your understanding and the success of the Alma pad, what do you guys think is the ultimate limits here for development spacing? And what size pilot program will you need to change your development assumptions off of 4, and should we expect that by -- in those 4Q results, given your end industry pilots?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've commented that we are testing up to 8 wells per section in a single interval. We're getting a lot of good data from the pilots in now. So while you've seen our results on the Born Free which gave us confidence that we have the ability to prosecute t
componenttext: We've commented that we are testing up to 8 wells per section in a single interval. We're getting a lot of good data from the pilots in now. So while you've seen our results on the Born Free which gave us confidence that we have the ability to prosecute the zones on top of each other with no problem. The Alma spacing test helped us understand that 5 wells per section is not dense enough, even in today's commodity price environment. We're getting some information in right now on the pump house, which is a 7 wells per section and we'll build a -- give you a little bit more feel for that. One of the pilots that we got some early data on was what we call the skipper pilot, and that was in an 8-well per section or almost an 8-well per section. And there, we're highly encouraged that 8 wells will work in the right commodity price environment. And it probably will work as technology continues to improve and we can improve our frac or completion designs and maintain a more complex near-wellbore frac. So the 4 that we initially commented on when we did the acquisition is liked. And we think we're at least at 6 and not heading north of that right now. And so that information, the pilots are coming in. We'll have about another 3 pilots showing us some information in Q3, some of them are in early, in the first quarter of '17, but we're starting to get comfortable with the areas that we're going to go into at full development on. And again, we'll use this TRAC concept in the STACK development as well. And we think will have the ability to prosecute up to roughly 27 wells in a section if -- as all these zones continue to work. So the play is working really well, and the pilot data is all positive and leading us towards our development plan.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's all really helpful information. My second question, you guys significantly increased your Barnett refrac type curve. Should we read this as the play is progressing closer to the point where you'll be willing to monetize a portion of your acreage posi
componenttext: It's all really helpful information. My second question, you guys significantly increased your Barnett refrac type curve. Should we read this as the play is progressing closer to the point where you'll be willing to monetize a portion of your acreage position, given that you can get then paid for that refrac potential?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we like our position. As we said, our transformation is complete. We like our portfolio the way it looks right now. We are always -- my kind of flippant expression on all this is we like all our assets but we're not in love with any of them. So we -
componenttext: Well, we like our position. As we said, our transformation is complete. We like our portfolio the way it looks right now. We are always -- my kind of flippant expression on all this is we like all our assets but we're not in love with any of them. So we -- but we certainly, we like where we are with everything. We have no current plans to do anything with the Barnett or any of our other assets, but that's not to say we aren't always thinking at the same time. If there's some way that we can improve our results as a company, we'll think about it. But I can tell you there's nothing right now that says we're going to divest, no current plans around divesture or anything in the Barnett.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: While you're listening Evan, took a look at your write-up this morning, and just wanted to make sure I clarify a couple of things in there. But one is the -- I think you heard me make some comments there about the predictability of our results in STACK. A
componenttext: While you're listening Evan, took a look at your write-up this morning, and just wanted to make sure I clarify a couple of things in there. But one is the -- I think you heard me make some comments there about the predictability of our results in STACK. And so while it's not going to be uniform across the play, it is extremely predictable. And again, there is a note about the debate regarding our acreage position and whether or not it falls in the overpressured window. And I think you may have been -- I think the industry may have been led to believe that there's a north-south line to the east of that, it's under pressure and to the west of that, it's overpressured. That's not the case. As we -- all of us that worked a subsurface data understanding and if you look at an isobar map, you can clearly see that the far northeast is normal pressure, but it quickly goes into about 0.5 psi per foot and gradually moves into about 0.7, 0.75 psi per foot to the southwest. So just wanted to clear up. And in our mind there's no debate about whether or not we're in the overpressured window or not.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And I did pick up on your predictability comments earlier in the call and I appreciate that.
componenttext: That's helpful. And I did pick up on your predictability comments earlier in the call and I appreciate that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Tameron from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Tameron from Wells Fargo.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Just along those lines, just in the offset that you talked a little bit about the Meramec and some I guess, you used the word variabilities. That's what I jumped on. But can you -- I mean that was my word, but can you just talk about the Meramec. And I know you've alluded to it a little bit, but can just give us more color as to what you're referring to the offset there?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure what your specific question is, David. Could you repeat it?
componenttext: I'm not sure what your specific question is, David. Could you repeat it?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I just pulled up to the page. It says, "IP and well costs can vary significantly across the play" and we've heard others talk about the variability of the Meramec. And so maybe the better question is, can you just talk about the Meramec, how you see
componenttext: Yes. I just pulled up to the page. It says, "IP and well costs can vary significantly across the play" and we've heard others talk about the variability of the Meramec. And so maybe the better question is, can you just talk about the Meramec, how you see it playing out across the portfolio?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what Tony is trying to say here, I'll try my words, is that there is variability, but it's predictable variability. So you aren't going to necessarily get the same well results across the entire play, but the variability of what you would expect i
componenttext: I think what Tony is trying to say here, I'll try my words, is that there is variability, but it's predictable variability. So you aren't going to necessarily get the same well results across the entire play, but the variability of what you would expect in a given part of the play, is very low, given the phase of maturity that we're in, in the play overall.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know Dave, just to elaborate what Dave mentioned is the -- as you characterize the reservoir there's a lot of variation in the reservoir thickness by zone. There's a lot of difference in the fluid content as you move from northeast to southwest. The b
componenttext: You know Dave, just to elaborate what Dave mentioned is the -- as you characterize the reservoir there's a lot of variation in the reservoir thickness by zone. There's a lot of difference in the fluid content as you move from northeast to southwest. The bottom hole pressure changes, as I just mentioned, from east to west. So there's a lot of variation in that. The actual total depth to get the wells down varies from the east to the west dramatically. But as Dave mentioned, the results that we're seeing as an industry are pretty darn tight. And the only place that we haven't seen a predictable result has really been in the far southwest when we were -- and we need a few more data points to understand the gas versus oil content there. There is a little bit of variability in that. But for the most part, everything that we're seeing in the core of the field, especially, in our footprint, the predictability is extremely tight.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then back to the Barnett. If you start thinking about $3.25 gas or $3.50 gas or what's the magic level at which -- just on a returns basis that, that play would start to compete with capital as far as you think about 2017, 2018?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then back to the Barnett. If you start thinking about $3.25 gas or $3.50 gas or what's the magic level at which -- just on a returns basis that, that play would start to compete with capital as far as you think about 2017, 2018?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll tell you it's got commercial returns today. As we have done all of our vertical refracs, we know that those are about at cost of capital, if not just a bit above. And the horizontal refracs are getting much more predictable and we know those are at c
componenttext: I'll tell you it's got commercial returns today. As we have done all of our vertical refracs, we know that those are about at cost of capital, if not just a bit above. And the horizontal refracs are getting much more predictable and we know those are at cost of capital and above. Really, it's more of a question, David, about how competitive that this in the overall portfolio. So as commodity prices increase, a lot of our other opportunities get more attractive as well, but that's a real opportunity for the company going forward in future. And you what the materiality of that is, we got about 3,000 wells out there that have the ability for us to go back into them. So it's something that...

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, didn't mean to interrupt you. So just to clarify, when you start talking -- '17 right now, the strip's at $3.15, $3.16. So at that level, you'll gain commerciality?
componenttext: Sorry, didn't mean to interrupt you. So just to clarify, when you start talking -- '17 right now, the strip's at $3.15, $3.16. So at that level, you'll gain commerciality?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are. We can get cost of capital returns. Well above cost of capital returns at that. In those kind of prices, the challenge is trying to compete on a superteam here. And we got a bunch of all-stars in here. And it's a pretty good player, but it's not g
componenttext: We are. We can get cost of capital returns. Well above cost of capital returns at that. In those kind of prices, the challenge is trying to compete on a superteam here. And we got a bunch of all-stars in here. And it's a pretty good player, but it's not going to see the ball as much. I mean we got the Golden State problem going here.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Herrlin from Societe Generale.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Herrlin from Societe Generale.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just have a question on completion designs. One, can you define your hybrid completion? And two, with the STACK and also the Woodford, you're putting in a lot more sand. Do you have any sense of what you think the economic limit is for how much proppant y
componenttext: Just have a question on completion designs. One, can you define your hybrid completion? And two, with the STACK and also the Woodford, you're putting in a lot more sand. Do you have any sense of what you think the economic limit is for how much proppant you can put in?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can give you a little bit of a feel. I'll remind us of the experience that we had in, I believe it was mid-14 when we started increasing the sand loads in our Delaware completions, and we really ran up to from about 600 pounds per lateral foot in early
componenttext: I can give you a little bit of a feel. I'll remind us of the experience that we had in, I believe it was mid-14 when we started increasing the sand loads in our Delaware completions, and we really ran up to from about 600 pounds per lateral foot in early 2014 up to about 3,000 pounds per lateral foot through 2015. And at the same time, that information gave us a good matrix or a good feel for the performance change in that design but it also helped us understand the commercial -- the matrix associated with the commodity price environment. So we have backed off in the Delaware from that 3,000 pounds per lateral foot. We think we can get the most commercial returns in the current business environment done at about 1,500 to 2,000. It kind of varies across the field, so that's the way we think about it. And then, if you move over into the Anadarko Basin, we're using a slick water job in our Woodford-type work, and we continue to increase our proppant loads there. So we're up to about 2,000 pounds per lateral foot. And after drilling and completing over 800 wells, this last large pad that we brought on had the best results that we've ever had in the Cana-Woodford play. As we think about the STACK play right now, we're using a hybrid-type job, so we've got a little bit of a gel with the total fluid is more dominated with the slickwater. So we're continuing to experiment and modify with our completion designs. But we are increasing our sand loads there up to about 2,600 to 2,750 pounds per lateral foot and enjoying increasing success of there. So, John, we're getting a lot of this information, and we're really all about trying to make the highest return per well, not necessarily just to pop large jobs. So getting a lot of data out there, we got a lot of data in our library, and we pump a lot of slickwater jobs, but in a few places like the Eagle Ford and in STACK right now we are using a hybrid fluid.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does the hybrid take longer to clean up?
componenttext: Does the hybrid take longer to clean up?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't believe it does, John. Probably have to get a little bit more feel from our technical guys, but I think our hybrid fluids are breaking with temperature, and I don't think there's a problem there. So just haven't heard of that complaint.
componenttext: I don't believe it does, John. Probably have to get a little bit more feel from our technical guys, but I think our hybrid fluids are breaking with temperature, and I don't think there's a problem there. So just haven't heard of that complaint.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple smaller ones. Could you talk about the infrastructure buildout in STACK and the Permian, how it matches up with the potential rig count additions in the second half of '16 and '17? And any potential limitations or bottleneck as you look forward o
componenttext: A couple smaller ones. Could you talk about the infrastructure buildout in STACK and the Permian, how it matches up with the potential rig count additions in the second half of '16 and '17? And any potential limitations or bottleneck as you look forward over the next couple of years?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you start in the Delaware, one of the things that has really changed over the last -- I'd say, the last 8 to 12 months, Ryan, has been the buildout of the infrastructure. And as you noticed some notes in our operating report, the majority of our work n
componenttext: If you start in the Delaware, one of the things that has really changed over the last -- I'd say, the last 8 to 12 months, Ryan, has been the buildout of the infrastructure. And as you noticed some notes in our operating report, the majority of our work now, we have power grid system to all of our wells. We also have the majority of our fluid being transported by pipe. And so the infrastructure -- and you can really see that as our LOE per BOE cost has dramatically dropped from over $16 a barrel down to the 8-type number over that period of time. So the infrastructure buildout in the Delaware Basin, especially, is there. There's no local takeaway issues associated with our work that we anticipate doing in the next couple of years. So really, the Delaware has now caught up to that infrastructure, and the returns are good. The cost to drill and complete wells is down. And certainly, the monthly recurring lease operating cost is down. And if you move over into the STACK play, the Cana-Woodford part of that is very well developed out. We got a great water system there. We're building out our concept for the Meramec play right now. That's in the design phase. We're working very closely with our midstream partner, EnLink, and they're helping us understand what the long-term takeaway opportunities might be. But again, we don't believe that's really a question in our current thought process for our current development until probably 2019. So we're working forward to that. When we'll have this, the appropriate solution identified, we'll be able to communicate that to you. And just a plug for the guys at the EnLink. I think we highlighted the, essentially, the flat production in the Barnett from Q1 to Q2 and with no capital, and it's pretty amazing some of the work that our team has done. That team consists of both Devon people and our EnLink team, so there's been great thoughtful work on line pressure reductions, optimizing plunger lifts and the artificial lift system we've got there. So really having that partnership with EnLink is starting to -- is really providing a lot of value across our asset base.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's perfect. And then maybe one logical follow-up on that. You've seen significant downward pressure in both LOE and G&A unit cost over the past 18 months. I mean how much -- how much more room do you have to run there in terms of pushing costs lower?
componenttext: That's perfect. And then maybe one logical follow-up on that. You've seen significant downward pressure in both LOE and G&A unit cost over the past 18 months. I mean how much -- how much more room do you have to run there in terms of pushing costs lower? In the Permian, you've gone from kind of $15 to $8 a barrel over the past 6 quarters. Can that go to $6 or $4 or further? Any thoughts on what we should expect over the next 12-plus months?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start off with this answer, and then hand it over to Tony. On the G&A side, the bulk of the reductions that we're seeing there were related to reductions in headcount, and we're just now starting to see all of that flow through the financials. But we
componenttext: I'll start off with this answer, and then hand it over to Tony. On the G&A side, the bulk of the reductions that we're seeing there were related to reductions in headcount, and we're just now starting to see all of that flow through the financials. But we have the staffing in place that we are comfortable with to execute the program now and also we could handle somewhat higher levels of activity as well, up to around 15 to 20 operated rigs. So we certainly don't see a reduction in headcount anymore as long as we maintain this path to recovery that we're on right now, and we certainly have the staffing in place in order to execute our capital program. And I'll turn it over to Tony, to talk a little bit more on the LOE and where we may be able to go.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, I think there's a real passionate push in the company right now to manage cost. And it's -- while we don't have much of a capital program in comparison to what we had in 2014, a lot of our attention here in the last 12 months have really been toward
componenttext: Ryan, I think there's a real passionate push in the company right now to manage cost. And it's -- while we don't have much of a capital program in comparison to what we had in 2014, a lot of our attention here in the last 12 months have really been towards managing our base business. And we’ve stood up an operations excellence group here that has really done a great job facilitating this focused effort to drive cost down. All of our field -- the men and women in the field locations are doing a good job participating with us. So as we have built out our water handling capacity across all of our fields, we have more of our water going through pipe. We own more SWD capacity than we've had in the past. As we've gotten -- as we've brought power grid system into our business, we've been able to release probably about close to 300 rental generators just in the Delaware Basin alone. Really good thoughtful work there, and we have a supply chain group that is closely linked in with our operating team, and they're doing everything from working -- reducing compression costs through renegotiating some contracts, doing the same thing for chemicals. We're working on the water that we do have to transport and handle. We'll work those costs down. So we've got a great focused effort going on with our supply chain, all of our field people. And again, it's something that is really passionate in the company right now. Where we go from there, I mean you can start looking at some of the cost, and they start to flatten out just in terms of the price per unit, but we're still working on this, and we believe a lot of the wins still left to get are just through attention to detail and through designing changes and through managing our business even better than we have in the past.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's all the time we have left for questions. I will now turn the call back over to Mr. Howard Thill for any closing remarks.
componenttext: That's all the time we have left for questions. I will now turn the call back over to Mr. Howard Thill for any closing remarks.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we appreciate everyone's attention. We apologize we couldn't get to everybody in the hour, but happy to follow up with you after this. If we can do anything else for you, please let us know, and have a great day.
componenttext: Well, we appreciate everyone's attention. We apologize we couldn't get to everybody in the hour, but happy to follow up with you after this. If we can do anything else for you, please let us know, and have a great day.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
