componenttext:
Welcome to the Devon Energy Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Scott Coody, Vice President, Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone. I hope everyone had the chance to review our third quarter financial and operational disclosures that were released last night. This data package includes our earnings release which includes forward-looking guidance
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone. I hope everyone had the chance to review our third quarter financial and operational disclosures that were released last night. This data package includes our earnings release which includes forward-looking guidance and our detailed operations report. Also on the call today are Dave Hager, President and CEO; Tony Vaughn, Chief Operating Officer; Tom Mitchell, Chief Financial Officer, and a few other members of our senior management team. 
Also I would like to remind you that comments and answers to questions on this call today will contain plans, forecasts, expectations and estimates that are forward-looking statements under U.S. securities law. These comments and answers are subject to a number of assumptions, risks and uncertainties, many of which are beyond our control. These statements are not guarantees of future performance, and actual results may differ materially. For a review of risk factors related to these statements, please see our Form 10-K and subsequent 10-Q filings. 
And with that, I will turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and welcome, everyone. Devon delivered another outstanding performance in the third quarter, both operationally and financially. Our development programs delivered the best quarterly drill-bit results in Devon's 45-year history, with new
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and welcome, everyone. Devon delivered another outstanding performance in the third quarter, both operationally and financially. Our development programs delivered the best quarterly drill-bit results in Devon's 45-year history, with new wells reaching peak 30-day rates of nearly 2,000 BOE per day. These prolific drilling results were centered in our world-class STACK play where production increased by nearly 40% year-over-year. Furthermore, the value of Devon's production continues to be enhanced by substantial cost savings achieved during the quarter. We are now on pace to reduce operating and G&A costs by $1 billion for the full year, which provides an uplift to our margins of nearly $5 per BOE produced. 
In addition to our strong operating performance, another important accomplishment for Devon was the recent completion of our $3.2 billion asset divestiture program. These accretive transactions significantly strengthen our investment-grade position. And as a result, our net debt has now declined by 45% since the beginning of the year. To further enhance our financial position going forward, we've also been much more active building out our hedging position with the recent increase in commodity prices. 
With a more focused asset base and improved balance sheet, the next step in our strategic plan is to accelerate investment in our world-class onshore resource plays. By the end of next month, we plan to have 10 operated rigs running, focused within our top 2 franchise assets, the STACK and Delaware Basin. 
Looking ahead to 2017, we are still working toward finalizing the details of our operating and capital plans. However, I can tell you that at $55 WTI pricing, our upstream cash flow in 2017 including EnLink distributions is projected to expand by more than 100% year-over-year to around $2.5 billion. Under this scenario, we would steadily ramp up drilling activity over the next several quarters to as many as 15 to 20 operated rigs in the U.S. by year-end 2017. This program would represent upstream capital spending of around $2 billion, allowing us to invest within available cash flow. 
On a retained asset basis, this focused investment in higher-margin projects is expected to drive double-digit oil growth in the U.S. in 2017 compared to the fourth quarter of 2016, which marks the low point in Devon's production profile. As a result of this growth in oil volumes, top line production in 2017 will range from low to mid-single-digit growth compared to Q4 2016. This range is dependent upon our level of ethane rejection during the year. Importantly, this capital plan is designed to create operational momentum at much stronger growth rates heading into 2018. At a $60 WTI price point in 2018, our upstream cash flow has a potential to reach $3.5 billion, a greater than 200% increase from today's levels. Under this scenario in 2018, we would continue to aggressively ramp up our drilling programs within the U.S. with the majority of this capital directed toward the STACK and Delaware Basin. This low-risk drilling activity is expected to drive production growth of greater than 30% from our STACK and Delaware Basin assets in 2018. This strong growth would further transition Devon's product mix toward higher-margin light oil production in the U.S. 
Now I want to be very clear. While we're excited about the outstanding growth prospects that reside within our portfolio, our capital allocation will be focused on value and rates of return, not the pursuit of top line production growth. And if commodity price volatility continues, our capital programs have significant flexibility with no long cycle project commitments and negligible leasehold expiration issues. This flexibility allows us to be nimble and tailor activity to invest directionally within cash flow. 
Another strategic imperative for Devon in the upcoming year is to further delineate and better characterize the growing resource base associated with our U.S. resource plays. Between the STACK and Delaware Basin alone, we have exposure to more than 1 million net acres and thousands of development-ready drilling locations that are highly economic at today's prices. To advance our understanding of the ultimate recovery and resource potential within these 2 world-class plays, we have an important appraisal work underway. In the STACK, this catalyst-rich activity is concentrated on the Meramec infill spacing pilots and further derisking of the Woodford oil window. 
In the Delaware Basin, the Leonard Shale opportunities set continues to expand and we are now falling back on our first stack lateral test that will help shape our view on how to best develop the three prospective landing zones in this oil-rich shale. 
2017 will also be a breakout year for our Delaware Basin Wolfcamp program as we begin to actively develop this emerging play. The Wolfcamp will have a material impact to Devon's resource potential in the Delaware and we are excited about progressing our understanding of the 9,000-plus potential locations we have identified in this play. 
The bottom line is that Devon's asset portfolio has never been in better shape than it is today and I believe that the quality and depth of our opportunity set is unmatched in the industry. We possess thousands of undrilled locations that are extremely well positioned on the North American cost curve. This high rate of return inventory will continue to expand as we derisk the tremendous resource upside associated with our STACK and Delaware Basin assets. With this resource expansion, it could necessitate additional high grading of our portfolio, monetizing less competitive assets and accelerating the development of our highest rate of return inventory. 
So in summary, before we move to Q&A, I want to leave you with a few key messages from today's call. First, our improved financial positioning now allows us to aggressively accelerate drilling activity across our best-in-class resource plays, while continuing to focus on the value and rate of return of each investment. These accelerated drilling plans will drive attractive cash flow growth in 2017 and 2018 compared to today's level and continue to transition Devon's product mix toward higher-margin, light oil production in the U.S. 
In conjunction with our shift to higher-margin production, do not lose sight of our peer group leading leverage to rising commodity prices. For every $1 increase in realized price on a per BOE basis, Devon generates more than $200 million of incremental cash flow annually. 
Looking beyond prices, Devon is also catalyst-rich over the next several quarters as we further delineate the massive resource upside associated with the STACK and Delaware Basin positions. 
And finally, with the continued growth in the quality and depth of our resource base, we expect to have an overabundance of opportunities. If this is the case, we are very willing to further high-grade our portfolio and deploy additional investment toward the best projects in our portfolio. 
With that, I'll turn the call back to Scott.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Thanks, Dave. We will now open the call to Q&A. [Operator Instructions] With that, operator, we'll take our first question.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, you mentioned you're evaluating the total inventory issue as you prepare 2 core basins to move in to development mode in 2017. That's something that's really supporting a newer 2018 guide here. A higher level question, though, is what do you believe
componenttext: Dave, you mentioned you're evaluating the total inventory issue as you prepare 2 core basins to move in to development mode in 2017. That's something that's really supporting a newer 2018 guide here. A higher level question, though, is what do you believe the optimal inventory depth should be maybe on the years of activity basis? And it sounds like we should expect a continued rationalization program if locations grow well beyond those optimal levels. Any thoughts there?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan, that's always a very difficult question to answer, exactly what is the right inventory level. Somewhat akin to the old R/P ratio we used to talk about for many years. I think you can obviously directionally have so much inventory that you're no
componenttext: Yes, Evan, that's always a very difficult question to answer, exactly what is the right inventory level. Somewhat akin to the old R/P ratio we used to talk about for many years. I think you can obviously directionally have so much inventory that you're not maximizing the value of your inventory or you can have too short of an inventory that there's quite questions about the long-term growth of the company. So there's certainly a balance point in there. To name an exact amount of years of inventory is somewhat difficult, I'd say. I tend to think probably somewhere on the order of 20 or so, it seems about appropriate, but it is certainly a subject that I actually turn the question back over to some of you guys to give your feeling, but I can tell you I am somewhere in that range, 20, 25, something like that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, maybe a 15, 20 gauge from our view. Different question, you provided the year-end '16 and '17 in rig target levels or unit levels. I know the board hasn't approved the budget yet, but can you talk about the ramp that's correlated to the move? Is it b
componenttext: Yes, maybe a 15, 20 gauge from our view. Different question, you provided the year-end '16 and '17 in rig target levels or unit levels. I know the board hasn't approved the budget yet, but can you talk about the ramp that's correlated to the move? Is it back-end loaded as you move into development mode? Or is it -- what's the ramp pace to the 15 units? And is the 5 delta something commodity-related? Or is that maybe asset-supported, asset-sales related? Any color there?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And let me kind of walk you through that. So the 10 at the year-end 2016 is essentially set and we are executing that. I think it's important to understand there's really the 10 rigs plus the completion activity that we are conducting is really drivi
componenttext: Yes. And let me kind of walk you through that. So the 10 at the year-end 2016 is essentially set and we are executing that. I think it's important to understand there's really the 10 rigs plus the completion activity that we are conducting is really driving our 2017 volumes. And so that's why we're very excited about the -- and confident on the volumes that we've talked about in the operations report. The ramp-up to the 15 to 20 rigs really won't add production in 2017, but that's why we're so excited about 2018 as we do ramp up to that level. That's what's going to provide the even higher growth levels as we move into 2018 led by more than 30% growth in the STACK and the Delaware. Now the variability around that is really more, at this point, I'd say more commodity price driven, although, frankly, we do have -- we are committed roughly to live within cash flow. If there's a little bit of variability around that, we're willing to exceed cash flow by a minor amount, perhaps, if necessary, supplement with incremental small-scale asset sales. We also -- as you know, we've been hedging significantly more, so that's helped underpin and provide more comfort to the cash flows that we'll have in 2017, but the opportunities are there. We're confident we have the opportunities there. So I'd say that delta is really more commodity price driven than opportunity-driven.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey Evan, this is John, just one thing I would like to add to that, too. I would also say it's about productivity as well. I mean if you look at where that capital is going, it's going to be focused on the STACK and Delaware Basin and those are 2 of the h
componenttext: Hey Evan, this is John, just one thing I would like to add to that, too. I would also say it's about productivity as well. I mean if you look at where that capital is going, it's going to be focused on the STACK and Delaware Basin and those are 2 of the highest rate of change plays that you're seeing as far as drilling days and improved completion times, right? So I would say that we're getting better and better at that. So that would also have an impact with regards to what that rig ramp would be needed to deliver the production that we've talked about.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Particularly, in just about the Alma [ph] [indiscernible].
componenttext: Particularly, in just about the Alma [ph] [indiscernible].

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Dave, you've raised the type curves, obviously, in the STACK. But you have not addressed the issue of the inventory mark -- my recollection is you were using 4 wells per section, 3 upper and 1 lower if I recollect. What do you need to see in terms of y
componenttext: So Dave, you've raised the type curves, obviously, in the STACK. But you have not addressed the issue of the inventory mark -- my recollection is you were using 4 wells per section, 3 upper and 1 lower if I recollect. What do you need to see in terms of your density spacing in order to update that backlog? And what's your early thoughts on that if you can.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, and Doug, just to be clear -- the inventory's going up, there's no question about that. We've had about 3 successful pilots so far. I think we've tested now one zone up to 7 wells per section that's worked out very well. We have another 10 pilots or s
componenttext: Oh, and Doug, just to be clear -- the inventory's going up, there's no question about that. We've had about 3 successful pilots so far. I think we've tested now one zone up to 7 wells per section that's worked out very well. We have another 10 pilots or so. They're detailed in the operations report, the locations of those pilots. So really it's just a matter of timing when we feel like we have enough information from each of those pilots to increase the number, but there's no questions it's going up. So Tony, do you want to add any details to that?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, I think Dave summed it up perfectly. We're working on a -- coming out of '17 with development in 2 of our areas central to the work that we've been doing with the pilots and as we've got the detailed data already in-house on the 3 operated pilots. W
componenttext: Doug, I think Dave summed it up perfectly. We're working on a -- coming out of '17 with development in 2 of our areas central to the work that we've been doing with the pilots and as we've got the detailed data already in-house on the 3 operated pilots. We got -- starting to get data in right now on 3 nonoperated pilots. And as Dave mentioned, we've got other 6 or 7 pilots that we're engaged in now. So all of that information is helping us inform our 2017 development plans. And I think as we get more data under our belt, we'll come out and see a material increase to that inventory.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I guess I'll have to be a little more patient. My follow-up, if I may, I realize oil is heading the wrong direction again this morning. Who knows what 2017 is going to look like, but you've laid out a trajectory that's got you tripling cash flow bas
componenttext: Okay, I guess I'll have to be a little more patient. My follow-up, if I may, I realize oil is heading the wrong direction again this morning. Who knows what 2017 is going to look like, but you've laid out a trajectory that's got you tripling cash flow basically by 2018 at $60 oil. I'm just kind of curious as to what should we infer by way of your activity level with that level of cash flow? And perhaps, even higher oil price environment where does Devon go in terms of activity? Or do we kind of flatten out at a targeted growth level at a particular rig level, but maybe return cash to shareholders at some point.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Doug, as you well know, we have a very deep inventory of opportunities. And certainly, the 2 franchise assets that we have are the STACK play and the Delaware Basin play. And so we could even -- if prices go even higher than that, we certainly can r
componenttext: Well, Doug, as you well know, we have a very deep inventory of opportunities. And certainly, the 2 franchise assets that we have are the STACK play and the Delaware Basin play. And so we could even -- if prices go even higher than that, we certainly can ramp up activity even further there. We are always going to be mindful about -- I want to emphasize, we're going to be mindful of the returns. So we're not driven by top line production growth. We are driven by getting good returns for every dollar in our capital program, but we feel we have the opportunities. We can further drive up activity in both of those areas, plus we have other areas that we are not funding right now as much could be if we had higher cash flow levels. They already have returned well above the cost of capital, but they just don't compete as well with the Delaware Basin and the STACK. And the Rockies, we are starting to fund now with one rig. We can add activity there with strong returns. And even the Barnett, and we laid out some numbers in the operations report, how we're driving down the cost there. And we think we have a program that we can do both from the horizontal refracs and from additional drilling locations that right now we are well above the cost of capital there. They're just not as good as the Delaware Basin and STACK, so we are focusing our capital there because they're the highest returns. So we do not have a shortage of opportunities. And so I think we would -- if prices are even higher, we'd look at funding some of those opportunities as well.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: David. I don't want to labor and take too much time here, but I do want to be clear what I'm asking because one of your competitors is talking about midcycles at the $55 level. I realize that's totally subjective, but their point is in the higher oil pric
componenttext: David. I don't want to labor and take too much time here, but I do want to be clear what I'm asking because one of your competitors is talking about midcycles at the $55 level. I realize that's totally subjective, but their point is in the higher oil price environment, the industry got itself into a bit of a mess by growing too quickly and they would look upon that as a windfall and would not jerk around their rig count with a view to longer-term sustainable growth. What I'm hearing from you is that you would respond to high oil price with higher activity levels. I guess my question is, is that what the industry wants to see? Is high growth just going to keep this oil price and the problem we got right now or is it an argument that says, what was the growth level and return any perceived "windfall" to shareholders? I guess that's really what I'm asking.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, it's my view that what got the industry in trouble at the higher commodity prices is that there are a lot of projects that were funded out there that were really -- they were very marginal projects, and we didn't pay enough attention to the reservoi
componenttext: Doug, it's my view that what got the industry in trouble at the higher commodity prices is that there are a lot of projects that were funded out there that were really -- they were very marginal projects, and we didn't pay enough attention to the reservoir. We didn't pay enough attention to the fundamental economics, and so I don't think it's so much the activity level in and of itself -- it's the fact that this activity level was really going towards projects that didn't provide the returns that they should. And so I can tell you here at Devon, we are very, very focused on returns and we're very, very focused on the reservoir and making sure that each project that we do is going to provide good returns. So I don't necessarily think it as a problem as long as you can -- on an individual company level, as long as you can be confident you can provide good returns. I think what really happens at $90 oil, all these projects we're funding -- being funded were not providing good returns. We're overcapitalizing some of these fields, frankly, and that's what the big issue was.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ryan Todd of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ryan Todd of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could follow up on STACK activity. Can you talk a little bit about how you view the mix of Meramec versus Woodford activity as we look into 2017? Any thoughts on what the potential swing in non-op CapEx might look like there?
componenttext: Maybe if I could follow up on STACK activity. Can you talk a little bit about how you view the mix of Meramec versus Woodford activity as we look into 2017? Any thoughts on what the potential swing in non-op CapEx might look like there?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, Tony Vaughn here. Our plans are to, as Dave mentioned, we're going to be we are at 6 rigs coming into this year end. And we got the capacity to build up that to roughly about 12 rigs. We have plans in the second half of '17 to engage back into a dri
componenttext: Ryan, Tony Vaughn here. Our plans are to, as Dave mentioned, we're going to be we are at 6 rigs coming into this year end. And we got the capacity to build up that to roughly about 12 rigs. We have plans in the second half of '17 to engage back into a drilling campaign on another row called the Jacobs row and you see that on Page 10 of our operating report. So if I had to -- we haven't gone through the budgeting process yet, so I can't say specifically how this will happen. But for the most part, our drilling activity up until about mid-year of '17, will be concentrated in the Meramec. And then in the second half of '17, we'll take probably roughly about 4 of those rigs and move them into our Woodford campaign. If you look at the magnitude of our OBO spending, in the STACK play, it is quite subtenants substantial. I think we talked to you guys before about the level of participation that we have, not just in operated wells, but we have a 430,000 acres in the play. So we have access to a lot of data, a lot of information, and that drives a spend of about $300 million per year from our non-operated exposure.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then maybe I know this is always a hard thing to quantify, but any thoughts on what inning you're in for LOE and G&A cost reductions? I mean the cost reductions over the past 18 months have been extremely impressive. And should we expe
componenttext: That's helpful. And then maybe I know this is always a hard thing to quantify, but any thoughts on what inning you're in for LOE and G&A cost reductions? I mean the cost reductions over the past 18 months have been extremely impressive. And should we expect to continue to see downward pressure on those? And is there any risk to inflation in either one of those as we see rigs ramp over the next 12 months?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the G&A part and I'll let Tony talk about the LOE side. We obviously did a significant reduction in employees earlier in the year on the order of 25%. That was a big move for us as a company and, obviously, involves some pain of losing some good
componenttext: I'll take the G&A part and I'll let Tony talk about the LOE side. We obviously did a significant reduction in employees earlier in the year on the order of 25%. That was a big move for us as a company and, obviously, involves some pain of losing some good friends. We did maintain the key operational capability and the key value drivers that can allow us to execute -- we feel, comfortably -- a $3 billion capital program or about 20 operated rigs. And so we see really that we are at a -- given what we've laid out here as potential for 2017 and 2018, that we are comfortable with the level of G&A in the company. And so I wouldn't expect a significant change on that one way or the other. Tony may want to talk a little bit about the LOE side of the equation. I think probably we found most of the big gains, but I think that we're always continuing to look more. As the infrastructure increases in some of these fields, there may be some more things that we can do. So Tony?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know Ryan, I think I got to hand it to our operating team both in the field and here in the office. They've taken a very passionate approach to driving cost out of the business, and you can see the improvements that we've made over the last 2 years. A
componenttext: You know Ryan, I think I got to hand it to our operating team both in the field and here in the office. They've taken a very passionate approach to driving cost out of the business, and you can see the improvements that we've made over the last 2 years. And I think if you were to look at the cost or the prices of materials and services, it is starting to level out, starting to flatten out in most of those areas, but that doesn't mean we're still looking for opportunities to continually improve our business. And some of those areas, we've unbundled or decoupled different components of our operations, as an example, separating the saltwater disposal from the water hauling vendors that's offered improvements there. We've continued to build out our infrastructure and have more water in pipe now. We have a better power grid system and especially in the Delaware Basin. All that's tending to drive cost down. So probably the tension that we see in the business is coming. We also have, by virtue of our sale of the Access Pipeline, an increased transportation fee that would be coupled into our LOE cost. But for the most part, our guys are continuing to work our LOE in a very passionate approach.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to see if I could discuss a little bit about your thoughts on guidance, and you gave us a lot of clues how we should be thinking about '17 and '18 in terms of the ops report. But tell me if this is what you're trying to convey. You guided to at l
componenttext: I wanted to see if I could discuss a little bit about your thoughts on guidance, and you gave us a lot of clues how we should be thinking about '17 and '18 in terms of the ops report. But tell me if this is what you're trying to convey. You guided to at least double-digit U.S. oil production growth in '17 versus the Q4 guidance. I think the guide was 105.5 at the midpoint. And then if we assume Canada's relatively flat from Q4 levels including maybe a turnaround in Q2, that to me suggests your overall guidance, soft guide, however you want to call it, would be oil a bit north of 250 MBOE per day versus the Street at 243. IS that -- Am I thinking about that right? And also, can you give us some sense of what capital it would take to achieve that in '17?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me address first the capital, and then I will let Scott address the kind of the detailed question on the volumes. I did say in my opening remarks there that the capital in 207 we anticipate being around $2 billion of E&P spend, but it is also importan
componenttext: Let me address first the capital, and then I will let Scott address the kind of the detailed question on the volumes. I did say in my opening remarks there that the capital in 207 we anticipate being around $2 billion of E&P spend, but it is also important to understand that really, the volumes in '17 are being primarily driven by the completion work that we currently have ongoing and specifically at Eagle Ford but also other areas. And then in addition to that, the 10 rigs that we're going to have working by the end of this year. The incremental capital going to 15 to 20 rigs which really kind of rough numbers increases the capital budget, there would be 10 rigs if we stayed flat there for the year, probably around $1.6 billion versus going to 20, it'd be around $2 billion. That incremental dollar is really driving 2018 volumes, which is why we're really excited just because of the timing of how long it takes to bring these wells on production. So it's not really a matter of $2 billion that's needed to drive those 2017 volumes. We could do that at a lower level. It would just impact 2018, but that's again why we're even more excited about the growth potential in 2018. Scott?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. With regards to the production, Arun, I think directionally, you're absolutely thinking about that correct. We would expect to be when you combine the U.S. and Canada from an oil production perspective, we'd expect to be north of 250,000 barrels. So
componenttext: Yes. With regards to the production, Arun, I think directionally, you're absolutely thinking about that correct. We would expect to be when you combine the U.S. and Canada from an oil production perspective, we'd expect to be north of 250,000 barrels. So we'll firm up that guidance as we get with our fourth quarter call. We're still working through the detailed operating and capital budgets. But directionally, you're absolutely thinking about correctly. And once again, I do want to emphasize, though, that is absolutely being driven by light oil growth in the U.S. So this is -- you're seeing a real-time shift to high margin production for Devon which is going to significantly enhance our profitability.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great, thank you Scott. And just a follow-up. Dave, you commented in your prepared remarks about potentially looking at opportunities given the inventory depth to high-grade -- the overall portfolio. Can you give us a sense of timing and magnitude
componenttext: That's great, thank you Scott. And just a follow-up. Dave, you commented in your prepared remarks about potentially looking at opportunities given the inventory depth to high-grade -- the overall portfolio. Can you give us a sense of timing and magnitude and just what you guys are thinking about in terms of potentially monetizing more assets?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, there are a lot of variables that go into this equation. I can tell you, we want to get a greater sense of the inventory, particularly in the STACK and the Delaware Basin where we are doing these spacing tests and the STACK play, both between t
componenttext: Yes. Well, there are a lot of variables that go into this equation. I can tell you, we want to get a greater sense of the inventory, particularly in the STACK and the Delaware Basin where we are doing these spacing tests and the STACK play, both between the Meramec. You see also there is now Woodford oil potential that's developing underneath the STACK. Want to get a sense for that and how many zones in the Meramec are going to work, we've laid out that we're testing up to 8 wells per section in the primary and 6 in the secondary in the Meramec. Now we're talking about a Woodford zone there. And then in the Wolfcamp, we talked about the Leonard and testing how many zones in the Leonard may work as well as the fact that the Wolfcamp is -- we have 9,000 on risk locations there and we've mode about 500 or so into risk locations. That's going to continue to grow. That's going to take toll -- start getting a better feel for that probably the mid next year. The other -- so that's one factor in it, and then the other big factor in it is really long-term commodity prices because you can see the leverage to the cash flow that we have from the operations report. The levers we have to higher cash flow at higher commodity prices, which is the highest leverage in the industry. And so where do we think long-term commodity prices are going to level out has a big impact on what cash flow we're going to have, which has a big impact on how many other opportunities that we can fund in other areas that already have potential returns well above the cost of capital. They're just not as big as the Delaware and the STACK. But we want to get a bit better handle from both of those variables probably mid-2017 into at the earliest before we make any strategic calls.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Edward Westlake with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Edward Westlake with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats on the risk location update and the cash flow guidance. Just on the Delaware Wolfcamp, I mean you put in 500 risk locations, looks like a large majority in Rattlesnake and the Mi Vida. The 9,000 number maybe just talk through the work that has to
componenttext: Congrats on the risk location update and the cash flow guidance. Just on the Delaware Wolfcamp, I mean you put in 500 risk locations, looks like a large majority in Rattlesnake and the Mi Vida. The 9,000 number maybe just talk through the work that has to be done to sort of unrisk those and what sort of EURs you'd expect on the core 500.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've just talked about in the operations report the Rattlesnake and Mi Vida area and we mentioned that we have about 500 risk locations there, but we have a total of about 9,000 unrisked locations across our position in the Delaware Basin. And I'
componenttext: I think we've just talked about in the operations report the Rattlesnake and Mi Vida area and we mentioned that we have about 500 risk locations there, but we have a total of about 9,000 unrisked locations across our position in the Delaware Basin. And I'd have to say that the industry has done an outstanding job of derisking the play. It's moved from the Texas side of the basin up to the state line and now north of that state line. So we're utilizing a lot of that information. We do participate in some non-operated activity in there. So we're getting a good feel of the potential in the Wolfcamp. I think some of the things that we're still anxious to understand through some of our pilot work that we'll engage in will be the vertical connectivity between that very thick Wolfcamp column. We know that out of the 2,000 wells drilled and we've drilled some of them in the Mexico side as well -- we just haven't really prosecuted that in our development plan -- but we know that from the XY [ph] through the upper -- through the lower portion of the Wolfcamp, it's all productive. And so it would really be a matter of the development style that we choose to engage in. I think one of the elements that we're incorporating into our thoughts as we go into 2017 is bringing in an aggressive approach from the Leonard A, B and C intervals. We've got a STACK piloting and engaged right now to help us understand the vertical connectivity. We spent most of our time in the B zone. Industry has spent most of their activity in the C. So we know each of the 3 intervals are productive. We're seeing some encouraging results. We're not commenting on that because the data is pretty young right now. We'll come back out and clear up the results of that soon. But we'll incorporate the 3 intervals in the Leonard with typical work that we do in the Bone Spring in the 2 -- in the southern portion of the 2 New Mexico counties and have a pretty aggressive approach into the Wolfcamp in both the Rattlesnake and Mi Vida areas. Will be the first 2 areas that we engage in Wolfcamp.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the eastern Woodford, your well cost is 6 to 6.5 and the EUR is 1,600. It's 25% oil and that Old Ricky's Ridge well it's 60% oil. It almost feels like it will be better than the stuff over in Blaine. As Blaine gets deeper, the costs go up. You're
componenttext: Just on the eastern Woodford, your well cost is 6 to 6.5 and the EUR is 1,600. It's 25% oil and that Old Ricky's Ridge well it's 60% oil. It almost feels like it will be better than the stuff over in Blaine. As Blaine gets deeper, the costs go up. You're getting similar types of EURs. Maybe just a little bit of elaboration in terms of why those well results, a, they're cheaper and the EURs are as strong as the thickness of that reservoir in that particular location.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're picking up on it. There's a lot of variability in the subsurface portions of the Meramec and the Woodford. The depth does run from the shallow being in the East to the Northeast to the Southwest as you described. Also about midway between t
componenttext: I think you're picking up on it. There's a lot of variability in the subsurface portions of the Meramec and the Woodford. The depth does run from the shallow being in the East to the Northeast to the Southwest as you described. Also about midway between the Northeast of our position and the far southwest, there's some subsurface intricacies that make us run a third casing string. So as you move up into the Old Ricky's Ridge area, it's a very important data point there that we wanted to highlight simply because the oil cut is 60%. We really hadn't valued that in our thoughts about the Meramec. But as you can see out there, we think there could be substantial NAV add if you move that high oil cut across the upper portion of our Meramec play. So this really sets us up for that stacked development from the 5 intervals in the Meramec and the Woodford. Also unique about Ricky's Ridge, it was a 10,000-foot Woodford test. We incorporated 70 stages in that frac design and pumped about 2,600 pounds per foot of sand. So it was a pretty aggressive attempt to see what we could do there. We're very happy with the results. You can see some of the 90-day IP is solid but the more important thing is the production profile is flat and much more optimistic than our initial expectations. So I think Ricky's Ridge is an important data point for us to keep our eye on.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it's a little bit cheaper over there too because you're shallower to the northeast and get deeper to the southwest, and so that's true both while you're drilling Meramec or Woodford wells.
componenttext: And it's a little bit cheaper over there too because you're shallower to the northeast and get deeper to the southwest, and so that's true both while you're drilling Meramec or Woodford wells.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question on the STACK. It looks like you're going to be increasing activity to these longer 10,000-foot laterals. But could you give us a sense of how much of your acreage ultimately do you think is a minimal to that? And what efforts are ongoing
componenttext: I have a question on the STACK. It looks like you're going to be increasing activity to these longer 10,000-foot laterals. But could you give us a sense of how much of your acreage ultimately do you think is a minimal to that? And what efforts are ongoing to help block up acreage more so this will become part of the long-term development plan?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, that's a good piece of the business that our business unit is engaged in every day. And so we're working with other operators there to block up and try to provide the most opportunity to drill long laterals. We find that to be the right answer and
componenttext: Scott, that's a good piece of the business that our business unit is engaged in every day. And so we're working with other operators there to block up and try to provide the most opportunity to drill long laterals. We find that to be the right answer and especially in this particular play. Data is fairly early on that, but all the long laterals that we have drilled are outperforming initial expectations. We've got a very aggressive type curve that you can see there, so very excited about that -- the ability to drill those long laterals. So we think about 2/3 of our position is currently available to drill the 10,000-footers. And so the majority of our work going into '17 or at least 2/3 of that work will really be directed towards the long lateral type work.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Specifically, do you find right now other operators that are fairly willing? Or are we at the right stage in the STACK for other operators to be willing to help do this and block up their acreage as well as yours?
componenttext: Yes. Specifically, do you find right now other operators that are fairly willing? Or are we at the right stage in the STACK for other operators to be willing to help do this and block up their acreage as well as yours?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's a good dialogue that's just now happening. There's a part of an industry group that we participate in with most of our larger operators in the field. They're working very well together. I think everybody is looking at operatorship. E
componenttext: Well, I think there's a good dialogue that's just now happening. There's a part of an industry group that we participate in with most of our larger operators in the field. They're working very well together. I think everybody is looking at operatorship. Everybody is looking at their position, trying to make sure that we take a very efficient approach. So some of the work that you've seen us and heard us talk about with our Cimarex partner in the Woodford has been very accommodating to both the work that Cimarex does and Devon has done, bringing out the most efficient results. And I think we're just now starting to see some of those type of conversations happening with most of the operators there in the Meramec play.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a follow-up. On the Mi Vida area again. Can you give us a sense of why this has popped under your focus? Is it some work geologically you have done? Or is it more of what you're seeing from industry? And maybe this is looking at a little bi
componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-up. On the Mi Vida area again. Can you give us a sense of why this has popped under your focus? Is it some work geologically you have done? Or is it more of what you're seeing from industry? And maybe this is looking at a little bit too closely, but if I look at that map, you got obviously some acreage outside of the little box that you drew down there. Is there any reason that is not included?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the one thing unique about the Mi Vida area is we've got about I think about 5,500 to 6,000 net acres there, 8,000 gross roughly. So we've got a nice contiguous a position in that portion of the Wolfcamp right there on the border of Reeves a
componenttext: Well, I think the one thing unique about the Mi Vida area is we've got about I think about 5,500 to 6,000 net acres there, 8,000 gross roughly. So we've got a nice contiguous a position in that portion of the Wolfcamp right there on the border of Reeves and Ward County. So it really sets us up for again a more efficient development going forward. So that's really caused us to put that on our radar screen, and we're getting a lot of good competitive data around us. There's some good wells that are being drilled there. Again, we're trying to see and understand the vertical connectivity between that column to understand best how to develop that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Peter Kissel of Scotia Howard Weil.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Peter Kissel of Scotia Howard Weil.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just another on the cost side of things, but more on the CapEx side than the OpEx side. In your supplemental presentation, you mentioned that you're proactively securing services to mitigate inflationary pressure in 2017. I was just curious if you c
componenttext: Maybe just another on the cost side of things, but more on the CapEx side than the OpEx side. In your supplemental presentation, you mentioned that you're proactively securing services to mitigate inflationary pressure in 2017. I was just curious if you could elaborate on that a little bit more, maybe in particular where you see the inflationary pressures and how you're mitigating that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Pete, I'm going to introduce Sue Alberti. Sue is our Senior Vice President here that manages our marketing and supply chain group. She's very well connected and her group is with our operating team. So I'll let Sue kind of describe some of the work th
componenttext: And Pete, I'm going to introduce Sue Alberti. Sue is our Senior Vice President here that manages our marketing and supply chain group. She's very well connected and her group is with our operating team. So I'll let Sue kind of describe some of the work that we're doing on the price of our goods and services.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. I'd like to say, we do think that as commodity prices improve and activity increases we're looking to -- we will get that inflationary pressure next year. We think that, that could be mid- to high-single digits especially in the stimulation are
componenttext: Thank you. I'd like to say, we do think that as commodity prices improve and activity increases we're looking to -- we will get that inflationary pressure next year. We think that, that could be mid- to high-single digits especially in the stimulation area. And I'll tell you a few other things that we're doing to mitigate those cost increases on the capital side. We did, as you said, we talked about proactively securing equipment and crews at competitive prices, and we're locking in rates and terms where it makes sense, given our outlook right now. So for example, on the rig side, we've locked-in 2 long-term agreements for these rigs at current market rates. And then Tony talking about the LOE said that we were unbundling the water transport and water disposal -- well we are doing unbundling on the capital side too, in the stimulation area. And we've recently started this where we're contracting separately for pressure pumping, sand chemicals and diesel, taking out the markup of the bundling. And while it's new and we don't have a lot of data yet, what we're realizing what we see right now is about 10% saving from that unbundling. So we're probably -- we'll look to do maybe more of that but we're very encouraged with those results.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just say, and Sue talked about the probably high single-digit type service cost increase. Again, we think we can offset that with all these internal efficiencies we're doing. So she mentioned some of the efforts. There's a lot more than that going on
componenttext: I'll just say, and Sue talked about the probably high single-digit type service cost increase. Again, we think we can offset that with all these internal efficiencies we're doing. So she mentioned some of the efforts. There's a lot more than that going on, just a continuing design of the wells. I think Tony may even like to brag on a few wells we drilled out recently in the Delaware. And I'm sure you're going there Tony, but I see you're holding a piece of paper that you're proud of.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I'm trying to let you go and say your few words and then let me get in here. Pete, I would tell you, I'm really excited about the work we do. And we talked a little bit about the passion for the technical work that our operating teams do. But o
componenttext: Yes. Well, I'm trying to let you go and say your few words and then let me get in here. Pete, I would tell you, I'm really excited about the work we do. And we talked a little bit about the passion for the technical work that our operating teams do. But on the drilling side of the business, we just stood up a Delaware rig and have now drilled 3 wells from spud to TD. Those used to take 17 days to complete. All 3 of these are averaging about 10 days now. That's really an approach to an optimized designs that we've had the luxury of tying to a lot more subsurface data that we've had in the past. It's also reflective of the really the granular detail towards the execution of our business. And Pete, I think we talked to you about the WellCon center there. So we're getting a lot of efficiencies both on the drill side of the business but also on the completion side of the business. And all that passion for data acquisition and integrating that into 3-dimensional earth models and picking the right landing zone and designing more optimized or better frac designs, all that's paying off. And we're also putting a lot of attention into the execution portion of that completion space. We monitor all of the operations on the frac. We monitor all of the data on the flowback of the wells in great detail. We have also recently incorporated the drill out -- coiled tubing drill out data in our WellCon center. So we think that's another potential savings there. So while Sue has mentioned that the industry is going to have some tension on cost, we think from a technical work that we're doing, we got the ability to offset that in '17 and very excited about additional enhancements that will be available to us for more of that type of work in the second half of '17 and '18.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great answer. One quick follow-up, more on the efficiency side, though. In the STACK in particular, as activity levels continue to increase, what do you see is the biggest gating factors there, maybe for the play in general but also Devon in part
componenttext: That's a great answer. One quick follow-up, more on the efficiency side, though. In the STACK in particular, as activity levels continue to increase, what do you see is the biggest gating factors there, maybe for the play in general but also Devon in particular? Is it midstream? Is it water availability? I know the play doesn't produce much water, but is there any concerns you have looking forward for any of those items?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pete, it's just not on take away out of the basin. I think Sue can talk to us a little bit of detail about that, but we're not worried about that through '17 and into '18. A lot of the pace of activity right now is more associated with just doing good qua
componenttext: Pete, it's just not on take away out of the basin. I think Sue can talk to us a little bit of detail about that, but we're not worried about that through '17 and into '18. A lot of the pace of activity right now is more associated with just doing good quality work, getting all of the pilot work under our belt before we finalize our development plans going forward. And just like we do in all of our areas, we'll have a good buildout of infrastructure there. So we know that -- say on the water handling side of the business, there could be a time when we have 20 rigs running just in STACK, but there's heavy demand on water, water handling. We'll be mimicking some of the work that we've done in the Cana-Woodford project and also in the Delaware Basin to make sure that's very efficient and our operating cost going forward are low and well-thought through. And Sue, I don't know if you want to add any comments to that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me add a little bit to what Tony was saying about takeaway. We don't have any short-term concerns regarding core Devon processing or takeaway constants in the STACK. And we have been working with EnLink to ensure that they will have adequate proc
componenttext: Yes. Let me add a little bit to what Tony was saying about takeaway. We don't have any short-term concerns regarding core Devon processing or takeaway constants in the STACK. And we have been working with EnLink to ensure that they will have adequate processing capacity for us on our forecasted production. In addition, we've got firm takeaway for our oil and our NGLs. And actually until 2019 at this point, I would say, though, that longer term when you think about the growth in this area, we think that there needs to be an industry solution for residue gas takeaway and we're actively working solutions with multiple midstream companies to address this. But given the time frame that we think that will be needed, we believe that there is enough time in order to get that in place when the growth is met.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Heikkinen with Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Heikkinen with Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing that we've been thinking about is the industry ramp in the Permian and just thinking about Devon advantages around securing oil and gas NGL and water takeaway capacity with the EnLink relationship. Can you talk some of that over the long term wi
componenttext: One thing that we've been thinking about is the industry ramp in the Permian and just thinking about Devon advantages around securing oil and gas NGL and water takeaway capacity with the EnLink relationship. Can you talk some of that over the long term with the 30% ramp in production in 2018 and beyond?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it absolutely is an advantage when we're in growth plays. We have a very close relationship with EnLink. They are our midstream provider in the STACK play and it gives us great comfort we have -- that they are, that they have that -- we have that
componenttext: I think it absolutely is an advantage when we're in growth plays. We have a very close relationship with EnLink. They are our midstream provider in the STACK play and it gives us great comfort we have -- that they are, that they have that -- we have that relationship so we can have teams working on a -- essentially on a daily basis on looking at what the long-term needs are and making sure that they have the right gathering processing and takeaway capacity at the right time to ensure that we can execute our capital plan and get our wells hooked up on a timely basis and get that value. So certainly when you're in a growth mode in a basin, I think a tight relationship with your midstream provider is very important. We have that with EnLink.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: A secondary thought and question, with your well level return focus, how do you think about the shift in Devon's corporate returns as you become more light oil, is it kind of return capital employed? Or what metrics should we use? And have you done any th
componenttext: A secondary thought and question, with your well level return focus, how do you think about the shift in Devon's corporate returns as you become more light oil, is it kind of return capital employed? Or what metrics should we use? And have you done any thoughts of well level economics translating into corporate economics?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We tend to talk about the incremental well level economics in these calls, but I can tell you that we actively look also at the what we would consider full cycle returns in each of our key project areas. Just trying to look at return on capital employed.
componenttext: We tend to talk about the incremental well level economics in these calls, but I can tell you that we actively look also at the what we would consider full cycle returns in each of our key project areas. Just trying to look at return on capital employed. We have all these write-offs as kind of just if you just look at that, it's kind of hard to get in calculation of the financials. But we look at it just from a pure rate of return, all cash spent, all cash we're getting back at each of our key plays to make sure that we're not only delivering on good incremental well level economics. But from a total investment level, we're generating good returns on our -- each area we work.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Scott really quick. I mean to further address that question. You absolutely start seeing these high rate of return wells in the future years to impact our ROTE calculations in a very positive manner. And also another proxy for that would be on a c
componenttext: This is Scott really quick. I mean to further address that question. You absolutely start seeing these high rate of return wells in the future years to impact our ROTE calculations in a very positive manner. And also another proxy for that would be on a cash flow per debt-adjusted share basis. It's certainly something that we view will be a very differentiating metric for Devon going forward.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess what do you think that the full cycle returns are in your STACK and Delaware?
componenttext: I guess what do you think that the full cycle returns are in your STACK and Delaware?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to give you that number right now because the play is still changing so much and how much incremental resource are we going to have over our original assumptions because the economics of each individual well is improving and we'll have a lot mor
componenttext: It's hard to give you that number right now because the play is still changing so much and how much incremental resource are we going to have over our original assumptions because the economics of each individual well is improving and we'll have a lot more wells than our original acquisition assumptions. So it's certainly improving, but to give an absolute number I think at this point would be very difficult.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I'll just add a little bit of a description of what we do on the operating side of the business. And on a quarterly basis, we get the senior leaders from across the company together on a by business unit basis, and we do a look-back of the work tha
componenttext: David, I'll just add a little bit of a description of what we do on the operating side of the business. And on a quarterly basis, we get the senior leaders from across the company together on a by business unit basis, and we do a look-back of the work that we just finished for the quarter and how that infers the forward look. We also have a very detailed look-back project from a project basis but also from an annual investment basis. So I think we've done -- we do a really good job of ensuring that we have an accountable approach to the work that we do. It's all based on historical results shaped with a forward and continuous improvement look. So it's a pretty detailed process here in the operating teams.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Portillo with TPH.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Portillo with TPH.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the Woodford. I wanted to see if we can get some color or context around your development plans on the Jacobs row. Obviously, quite interesting that you plan to utilize 10,000-foot laterals to try to get a better sense of the size and s
componenttext: Just going back to the Woodford. I wanted to see if we can get some color or context around your development plans on the Jacobs row. Obviously, quite interesting that you plan to utilize 10,000-foot laterals to try to get a better sense of the size and scale from a section or well count perspective that you might have and the development it seems like it could be a pretty material growth plan for you going into 2018.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, I think we're getting information in on the Hobson row that will help us understand and infer the magnitude of a performance improvement by going from the normal laterals to the 10,000-foot laterals. So we're going to utilize that to our advantage,
componenttext: Matt, I think we're getting information in on the Hobson row that will help us understand and infer the magnitude of a performance improvement by going from the normal laterals to the 10,000-foot laterals. So we're going to utilize that to our advantage, where we can as we go into the Jacobs row. So I think over 800 wells now have been drilled and completed and are producing. Each of the new vintage completions that we see we tend to outperform the past or previous type curves. Costs are continuing to come down. So another step change here in addition to the Ricky Ridge and the increased oil content of our fluid going forward is really just incorporating that 10,000-foot concept into the works. I think the returns on the Woodford play are beginning to shape up as being dramatically better than they have been in the past -- it really has been in what we call the core portion of our field.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don't hold me to an exact number but there are roughly 60 wells in the Jacobs development.
componenttext: Don't hold me to an exact number but there are roughly 60 wells in the Jacobs development.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great and then just as a follow-up question. We talked a lot today about the Delaware and the STACK as kind of your core oil development. Just curious on your thoughts on the Eagle Ford as you potentially return to activity in the play. Any opportunity to
componenttext: Great and then just as a follow-up question. We talked a lot today about the Delaware and the STACK as kind of your core oil development. Just curious on your thoughts on the Eagle Ford as you potentially return to activity in the play. Any opportunity to continue to optimize completion design as the basins kind of have been in a frozen moment here for the last year or so? And are you changing any of your views on kind of the spacing? I know you have a new spacing design that you may be testing here with the diamond formation.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, I'd tell you, we're really pleased with where we are in Eagle Ford. And when you go back and look at the pace of our activity, it's greatly slowed down in 2016 versus '14 and early '15. In fact, we're bringing on about 70 to 75 wells per quarte
componenttext: Yes, Matt, I'd tell you, we're really pleased with where we are in Eagle Ford. And when you go back and look at the pace of our activity, it's greatly slowed down in 2016 versus '14 and early '15. In fact, we're bringing on about 70 to 75 wells per quarter in that time frame. In Q1 of this year, we're down to 22 wells brought on in the quarter. Second quarter is only 5. Third quarter is only 5. So we've seen the rate drop off there, but it has now stabilized and we have 4 frac crews in the field that are lowering our DUC inventory down. That's being done for a couple of purposes, but the primary purpose is to get information on the staggered lateral approach to the development end which is incorporating the upper Eagle Ford. And that information we're looking forward to having in '17 which will shape, what I think will be, an accelerated pace of activity in the second half of '17, which will have the potential for a material rate impact going into '18. We are looking forward, we are continuing to improve our completion designs. Historically, we have pumped pretty much -- roughly 2,000-pound per lateral foot type of job. We've moved that to more of a hybrid type fluid and we're increasing the proppant load up to close to 3,000 pounds per lateral foot at this point, so a substantial change to the completions. The wells are just now starting to flow back on a few of those new completions. We're not ready to talk about that, but we're highly encouraged that some of the well rates that you've seen as reported in the past, we're going to materially beat as we go forward. So that play is setting itself up for what I think would be an accelerated ramp-up in the second half of '17.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from James Sullivan with Alembic Global Advisors.
componenttext: Your next question comes from James Sullivan with Alembic Global Advisors.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of stuff asked and answered. I just wanted to quickly ask you guys to touch on, if you could, you mentioned just in passing, the Powder River. I know you're adding a rig back there, an area that you guys have spoken positively about -- obviously a n
componenttext: A lot of stuff asked and answered. I just wanted to quickly ask you guys to touch on, if you could, you mentioned just in passing, the Powder River. I know you're adding a rig back there, an area that you guys have spoken positively about -- obviously a number of times [indiscernible] an acquisition over there. Obviously, you're adding the rigs, so you feel good about it. But what gets that area, a big percentage of the limited capital pie? Is it just you guys need a longer runway on infrastructure and permitting? I know you're going to work on both those things. But what is it? And what's the state of play over there right now?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: James, thanks for bringing that up. We've been really pleased with the work that we've done in Powder River Basin in the past and we've been operating that area for quite some time. If you recall back before commodity prices dropped, we were drilling prob
componenttext: James, thanks for bringing that up. We've been really pleased with the work that we've done in Powder River Basin in the past and we've been operating that area for quite some time. If you recall back before commodity prices dropped, we were drilling probably the highest return wells in the portfolio were in a special [ph] department in the Powder River Basin. And so we did take a pause in our activity as commodity prices ramped down and our focus has gone to STACK and Delaware. We've continued to work the subsurface portion of that. We have an extensive 3D coverage across that entire basin. So we have what I think will be unparalleled knowledge about the subsurface there. After the acquisition, we doubled our position there and it's all Tier 1 opportunity connected, and we've got about 3 rig lines ready to go. It's a matter of managing the portfolio and staying within our cash flows. So we think it's a great -- an asset. You've seen some transactions happen in the Powder, which further confirm what we think the ultimate value in the Powder position will be. So while it won't ever have the scale and materially that we'll see in the STACK or Delaware Basin, it's got outstanding returns, and we're looking forward to showing you additional subsurface results.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bob Brackett with Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bob Brackett with Bernstein.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on the track development plan in the Delaware. Can you talk about the trajectory of wells per pad last year to this year, going into next year and what that steady-state number looks like?
componenttext: Question on the track development plan in the Delaware. Can you talk about the trajectory of wells per pad last year to this year, going into next year and what that steady-state number looks like?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, we've historically -- and I don't know it's more than just Devon but industry has really been prosecuting 2 and 3 well pads across the Delaware Basin, and the areas where we have a larger contiguous position, we're going to employ this new design con
componenttext: Bob, we've historically -- and I don't know it's more than just Devon but industry has really been prosecuting 2 and 3 well pads across the Delaware Basin, and the areas where we have a larger contiguous position, we're going to employ this new design concept. And so there are up to about 14 nonproductive intervals in that Delaware Basin column, Bob. And so when you look at the number of unrisked locations that we've highlighted of 20,000, there's got to be more compelling development play going forward to accelerate present value. So that's the concept that we are looking forward to. The way we're designing the track process is highly flexible between what we need to get done in the Delaware which has some additional challenges with the federal permitting, but the concept between -- the concept of track will be applied both in the Delaware and STACK on both of those STACK developments. So it's hard to tell you exactly how many wells per pad, but I could see us putting may be up to 30 wells in a given section. We'll utilize very efficient drilling pads coupled with a more of a centralized tank battery. So we'll see quite a few advantages. We tried to highlight the advantages in our operating reports, so you can take a look at that.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: But will you do a pilot track sometime in the next years? Or how do you get from where you are today to rolling out track?
componenttext: But will you do a pilot track sometime in the next years? Or how do you get from where you are today to rolling out track?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to push forward in 2017 employing this concept. We think it'll be -- you can call it pilot or really just go forward development plan, but we think there's a lot of flexibility in this. So we're going to be pushing forward to a more creative s
componenttext: We're going to push forward in 2017 employing this concept. We think it'll be -- you can call it pilot or really just go forward development plan, but we think there's a lot of flexibility in this. So we're going to be pushing forward to a more creative solution for our developments going forward.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then kind of a last follow-up. If I look at your 7.5-ish rigs for 4Q, you're calling for about $400 million in CapEx for the quarter. If I just scale that and say you're going to run double those rigs next year and there's 4 quarters next year, I get
componenttext: And then kind of a last follow-up. If I look at your 7.5-ish rigs for 4Q, you're calling for about $400 million in CapEx for the quarter. If I just scale that and say you're going to run double those rigs next year and there's 4 quarters next year, I get closer to kind of a $3 billion, $3.2 billion CapEx spend, but you're talking about $2 billion. How should I think about that?

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, included in the $400 million will be also a larger component of -- include the OBO component plus we have other just leasehold expenditures, things like that are not actually Devon-operated drilling rig components. So really when you talk about going
componenttext: Yes, included in the $400 million will be also a larger component of -- include the OBO component plus we have other just leasehold expenditures, things like that are not actually Devon-operated drilling rig components. So really when you talk about going to the -- and I've been talking about on The Street for quite some time today we're going to be at a run rate of around $1.6 billion with the 10 operated rigs, so going from the 10 to 15 to 20, you're not increasing all these other components that are in our capital program. You're just increasing the operated rig component. And if you do the math on that, say, on average, it's another 7.5, over 0.5 year, so maybe that's more like 4 rigs, so you take 4 rigs and average working interest, you get somewhere around that incremental $400 million that gets you to around $2 billion.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there are no further questions at this time. I'll turn the call back over to Mr. Coody.
componenttext: And there are no further questions at this time. I'll turn the call back over to Mr. Coody.

headline: Devon Energy Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well. Thank you, and we appreciate everyone's interest in Devon today. And if you have any additional questions feel free to reach out to the IR team at any time -- myself or Chris Carr. Once again, thank you for everything.
componenttext: Well. Thank you, and we appreciate everyone's interest in Devon today. And if you have any additional questions feel free to reach out to the IR team at any time -- myself or Chris Carr. Once again, thank you for everything.
